reviewText:
Dragons Dogma is a wonderful RPG with a unique pawn system, awsome combat, and intimidating exploration. A must have 4 year old classic that ages very well with its current art style and hopefully will be for the days to come.

Pros:

Pawn System( When each player starts the game, they not only create their own charater. but a side kick that will not only help the player but also travel accross other worlds to aid other players accross the world.)

Rift Credits( When a players pawn is rented out by another player, they earn rift credits and gifts from other players, which they can spend mainly on the dark arisen expansion for epic gear, as well on other ods and ends at a certain encampment early game. Because of this, you should equip your pawn with only the best gear, so people rent out your pawn more, therfore gaining the player even more rift credits.)

Combat system( Between the many different switchable classes at anytime, and the ability to climb giant monsters, and nighttime being really dangerous for a newer player, plus the solid combat it self, Dragons Dogma nails the combat department on the head.)

Lots of gear and loot( especially with the newely added dark arisen expansion, soooo manny chesstsss)

Story is kind of a toss up, overall, the concept is really cool and I guess very well implemented in a americanized japanize way?

Enviroments are really really cool and imersive, but basic.

Music is pretty awsome.


Cons:

Lip movment is nothing to sing about( to be fair it is a older game)

Story is a toss up, it has a lot of alternate endings and such. A personal opinion really.

Alot of basic go do this and escort quests. However, there are still some very long quests with rewarding story and gameplay leading up to them.



Overall a really solid game which saddens me to see around 200 negative reviews for such a awsome product, come on guys lets up those positive reviews!!!!

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen was not a title I ever heard about, nor one that I was wishing to buy as I normally steer clear of these types of games. However this was an expection, and probably one of the best I have made with games.

From the very start, you can feel this game is close to alot of other titles in features and gameplay, namely Dark Souls. However it also grabbed my attention in other ways, such as the landscape, soundtracks and general feel of the game, that made it feel a bit like Zelda in those aspects, which was quite suprising.

Getting down to the game itself, the graphics, I wouldn't say, is 'stunning' but the scenery is very beautiful and the way certain locations are compositioned gives it alot more quality. Character customization is fairly lengthy if you chose to edit the facial, body, stance and voice features of your said character, though it felt a bit lacking, in that certain customizable things such as the hair and body could have been expanded upon.

The gameplay as I mention before, feels alot like Dark Souls so not much to be said there. The animation most of the time is fluid and looks p. good. Though the apparently 'battle defining' feature of climbing a creature to get to its vital points feel more like someone went and modded it into the base game, as it produces some strange character placement bugs when climbing certain enemies.

The soundtrack and audio fidelity of the game is p. good in my opinion, having alot of customization in your characters voice, the soundtracks adding alot of character to many of the areas and the overall effects are nice.

To sum it all up in basic -/10 format;

Graphics (Objects, meshes, textures): 7.5/10

Combat: 8/10

Sound: 9/10

Storyline(obviously haven't finished yet): 7/10

Overall, I think this game deserves a 8/10 because it does feel very nice to play, look at and listen to. If you enjoy hording loot, farming monsters, completing quests, working your way towards a main questline and playing with an interesting AI and Combat system, then this game is probably for you :).

reviewText:
When Dark Souls had a sex with Shadow of Colossus, then Monster Hunter joined in for a threesome, Dragon's Dogma : Dark Arisen was born.

Epic combat system, great party management with pawn system, and great dark fantasy atmosphere will keep you entertained for hours. Despite of its somewhat mediocre story that would make you skip most of dialogues, I consider this game as one of the best for its genre.

Dragon's Dogma : Dark Arisen is also one example that you don't always need a great story to make a great RPG.

So what are you waiting for? Grab it NOW.

reviewText:
This game has to be my favorite Action RPG or game of all time, But it's impossible to decide the latter when you play so many games

The improvements from the original console versions include somewhat better textures (NPCs actually have faces? They were black blurs to me!) and no letterboxing, there is also the option to mute pawns if you get tired of them, There's probably more stuff I can't remember now. As for content the game comes with the base game and the Dark Arisen expansion which brought balance changes, new items and a new explorable area which I didn't get to explore on console but I hear it's pretty difficult. A bunch of the armor and weapon DLCs are also included, you also get the eternal ferrystone which allows you to teleport to portcrystals but doesn't disappear after using it. However there is some content missing from the original version, the main menu theme song, Into Free, japanese voice over and the armor sets from the manga Berserk

The game tries to be an open world game but it remains mostly linear, getting too immersed in exploration while straying out of the roads might make you feel otherwise though, most of the scenery consists in mountains and forests, there is only one city (pretty much your base since it's where you change classes, get most missions and where the masterworksweapon shop is) but there is also a small fisherman village and a couple strongholds and ruined castles out there, and of course there can be no medieval fantasy RPG without dungeons or caves

So, you are a normal person living in a fisherman village and one day a huge dragon comes from the sky and attacks, you fight it but it steals your heart, the physical way and you become the Arisen and can command warriors known as Pawns who obey your every command

Into the gameplay, you have a light attack, strong attack and then by holding your trigger buttons you can use your skills, can equip up to 6, simple right? It is for the small enemies, when you are fighting cyclopes, chimeras or drakes you might want to climb on them ala Shadow of the Colossus and start poking at their weak points if any. A big component of the game are the Pawns, they are indeed your fellow party members, but they learn from you, from how to do quests or what are enemies vulnerable to to imitate your behavior, if a pawn sees you holding an enemy down, they will start doing so when playing a melee class, the most common imitated behavior will be how you climb and where you attack big enemies. You are the hero of this adventure and as such if you die it's game over, but if they do you can revive them infinitely, you have your main Pawn and can hire 2 more from other players, of course, expect them to be pretty talkative, they say important stuff however

Like most RPGs, Dragon's Dogma has a class system, there are 3 classes with 2 tiers each and then 3 hybrid classes (Arisen only) the classes are fighter (sword & board) warrior (greatsword, 3 skills only), mage (healing, support and minor attack magic), sorcerer (offensive and devastating magic like meteors and tornadoes), strider (daggers and shortbow) ranger (daggers and long bow with a focus on longer distance and stronger arrows) assassin (sword/daggers + bow/shield), mystik knight (swords/maces + magic shields/staves, unlike fighter, MK shield skills are more based on parries) and magick archer (daggers + magic bow/staff, homing, bouncing arrows). To unlock classes and skills you need to earn Discipline Points by killing monsters, you can change classes at the Gran Soren inn for free after you unlock them so no need to feel pressured, when you gain a character level your stats growth will depend on your active class, for example you gain more stamina as strider but more magic as mage, however it's mostly about the gear and the level cap is 200 (stat gain halves from 101-200)

In conclusion, this game is flawed and probably even rushed but it's well worth a try, it has action based combat, bg monster climbing, good archery, manual spell aiming mages and can summon huge meteors, what's not to like? ask the people who bashed it for not being Skyrim, but they probably didn't even play it

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. After I played over 20 hours expecting it to get great any moment, it never did. It has some great ideas but most of them just fall flat. Rather than give a long winded review, I'll list my likes and dislikes below to summarise.

Dislikes:

* Boring side quests - Mostly fetch and escort quests
* Poorly told main storyline without much character development or in depth RPG storytelling
* Lack of rewards for exploration - I saw chests in hard to reach places multiple times or hidden away, I opened them excitedly to find.. some basic healing potion? -_-
* Loot - after 20 hours I think I found one gear upgrade to the stuff I'd already bought at the blacksmith. Even in hidden away places, useful loot was nowhere to be found.
* The huge expansive world was just trees, rocks, water over and over again. There was no interesting changes of scenery or hidden amazing places to see. Every cave was just a cave with a few monsters in it.
* Average voice acting
* Character animations and mouth sync were just.. worse than any other open world RPG I've played.

Likes:

* Combat is responsive, has great variety and feels well polished.
* Magic classes can do some really cool looking spells. Probably cooler than any other game I've seen before.
* Fighting large enemies has an interesting mechanic which requires you to climb them. I must say it does feel a bit janky in practice though.
* You're not tied to a class, you can switch any time at no real penalty and for free after you've already done it once. The game encourages this.
* The pawn system is really cool. You can recruit followers and they learn what to do based on your actions in/out of combat. For example, they learnt that goblins were weak to flame so they always buffed my weapon with fire. That was pretty impressive.
* The climbing of ledges and stuff when scaling buildings/mountains is well polished.
* Fighting animations look great.
* The game has barely much of a tutorial system at first glance, but if you listen, your pawns actually give you a lot of advice about the world in your travels. This is a very organic way of teaching/helping the player and maintains immersion quite well. I'd like to see this concept in more games.

All in all, the game has so many great mechanics and concepts which makes the game fun.. at first. But after that, you need a world worth exploring and a story worth following. Dragons Dogma offers neither.

reviewText:
Dozens of feet up, my gauntlets digging into the mane of a livid griffin, I knew I'd made a huge mistake. The beast was grounded when I'd hopped atop his back in the hopes of introducing his eyes to my sword, but he'd shot up so high afterwards that I could have seen the main character's hometown if I'd dared to look (and if it popped in in time). One slip, one splat, and it'd be game over. Below, though, a mage's spell set my group's weapons aflame. My ranger companion let loose a mighty arrow, alighting the monster's wings and bringing us slamming back to earth.

I already knew how all this would end: I spent many sleepless nights with Dragon's Dogma's appealing mix of Western RPG stylings and Monster Hunter-inspired combat years ago when it first dropped for the Xbox 360. Graphics have advanced, scores of better and lesser RPGs have come and gone, but there on the stones of the Bluemoon Tower, I still relished the return of the same rush of victory that overcame me in 2012.

Now, at last, we have the PC port, which takes its guise from 2013's Dark Arisen, a retooled version of the initial release with a ridiculously tough endgame zone and numerous tweaks to various annoyances. It's a port, all right, which is to say that it's here and it does little to distinguish itself from its console forebears aside from nifty features like better textures and uncapped framerates. (A single crash over 50 hours aside, it ran beautifully.) Still, that's cause for celebration. Scarred with imperfections but entertaining to the end, Dragon's Dogma is easily one of the most memorable RPGs of the last decade.

It achieves this distinction almost in spite of its story. It's not bad, and it's capped on one end by a dragon who eats your heart as though he's sucking Nutella off his claw and on the other by a deliciously bizarre conclusion preceding the New Game that still makes for good discussions when less than sober. In between, though, it relies excessively to backtracking and indulges too many humdrum sidequests. It clings to predictable Western RPG conventions: in one corner there's the dastardly secret society, in another, the artifact-stuffed ruin.

It works, though, because it's all told with enthusiastic gravitas. For all the chimeras and dragons, Gransys is a land that tries to stick to the real, favoring utilitarian armor designs over flamboyance, and the interactions impart a dutiful ‘let's do this’ sense I admire. This extends even to the open-world landscape, which boasts coastal cliffs, mountains, and towering Norman architecture but never quite inspires the kind of visual rapture you get from, say, The Witcher 3. (Worse, it's prone to pop-ins and muddy details at long distances.) Saving the world is a job, dang it, and Dragon's Dogma makes you feel it.

Jobs can be fun, of course, and Dragon's Dogma delivers a challenging brand of action that's rousing regardless of whether it's played on the keyboard or with a gamepad. Greatswords crash with hefty weight, arrows fly with satisfying thwapps, and spells impale ogres with icy tendrils. So many RPGs could learn from how fun this is. The appeal isn't just the fighting (which could benefit from a lock-on); it's also the way it lets you scramble up the arms of cyclopes and slice off the tails of lizard men. Sick of one of the main three classes of Fighter, Strider, and Mage? You can easily switch out to another and level its skills or those of six hybrids. Some fare better than others; Warriors, for instance, perform pitifully in Dragon's Dogma's many ranged encounters.

Dragon's Dogma still feels enjoyably unique four years on.
Enter the pawns. Nothing sets Dragon's Dogma apart quite like them. They're mysterious beings with classes and skills that fill the blanks of what you need, thus allowing my Warrior to bring along, say, a bow-toting Ranger, a healing Mage, and a powerful Sorcerer—for a price. You get a main pawn that other players can summon, and you can summon up to two of theirs as well. There's a satisfying Pokémon-like appeal to trying them out (which you'll need to since they don't level with you), and having to let go of a well-geared, well-skilled pawn sometimes stings like the death of a fleshed-out character in another RPG. Alas, they're prone to spouting obvious, ceaseless chatter such as These stairs serve as a useful route in their own right
date:
but happily Dark Arisen lets you switch that off.

If that's what it takes, do it. It's rough in parts, and numerous other RPGs tell a better story or inspire greater awe. But Dragon's Dogma still feels enjoyably unique four years on and that's something few of its genre cousins can claim. And the best thing I can say? Even now, I'm already itching to get back in.

1 of 4
Dragon's dogma 1




THE VERDICT
81/100

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is a third-person action RPG made by a japanese company for a western market.
It has pretty solid combat, that was obviously borrowed from Demon/Dark Souls series (not as hard though). There are some crazy big monsters and beasts that were definitely inspired by Monster Hunter. And there's that ability to grab and climb onto large monsters from Shadow of Colossus. Plus some RPG elements that are quite common in japanese games, but were re-shaped to resemble western ones.
Sounds a bit strange, but plays pretty damn awesome. At least mechanically.

Story-wise it's quite plain - as most of JRPGs the main story is quite linear. Side quests are mostly plain as well - go kill those guys, bring that thing, nothing exciting here. The writing (or maybe translation?) is not fantastic as well, so after some time playing, you'll forget about most of the quests at all.
Which is fine, because the combat is still fantastic.

Loot system works in a very similar way to Souls games - there's a limited number of weapons and armor, but almost every one is a significant upgrade over the old ones. You can also use money and gathered materials to upgrade your gear - that's quite important too.

You also have pawns (minions/followers) to help you. You'll create one yourself and will be tasked with watching over her - getting better equip, buying and assigning skills, leveling up, and all that other stuff.
And then you'll have a way to hire two more pawns to help you - either of same level as you for free, or higher level for some RCs (which drops from mobs). All hired pawns was made by someone else (your pawn can get hired too!). Hired pawns don't level up, so you need to change them frequently.
The cool bit is that if you hire pawns that already completed that quest, they'll actually help you with some tips and guidance.
Annoying bit is constant chatter and wolves hunt in pack!" stuff (which you luckily can turn off in options menu).

Downsides
date: aside from plain (maybe even boring) storyline/quests include a couple of minor things like dated UI (the game was after all originally released in 2013)
recommended:
a bit wonky camera in places and not-that-HD graphics (which hopefully will get fixed by some crazy modders in future).

If that sounds like your kind of game - grab it. It's probably the most epic RPG about fighting large monsters I'd played. If you only want story - I wouldn't bother with this one.

A bit more detailed look at mechanics and combat in video below:
https://youtu.be/8tfF3JrVnsM"

reviewText:
The Good
Addictive! Running around, exploring the world, encountering epic battles wherever you go. It’s a sandbox done right. Combat feels good, Combat Animations feel good. The pawn system feels good as well. The player creates his own party member (pawn) that will follow him throughout the entire game and can be leveled and skilled just like the player character due to a very extensive class (vocation) system. The players main pawn can then be summoned by other players into their game to receive additional skillpoints and knowledge about the world like quests, monsters and locations. Two more party members (pawns) of other players can be summoned into your game as well. That way you can adjust your party depending on the situation or travels you undertake.

The Bad
You can over level easily! If the player explores too much or fulfills all available side quests before entering certain story quests then it can happen that the story quests are laughable easy. This took away the challenge to accomplish the main story. For example: The player can fight a Griffith (giant bird monster) in the open field and later encounters one as part in a story quest in which this easily in 2 minutes defeatable Griffith is pictured as undefeatable foe due to the scripted quests progression.

A ton of items! There are hundreds of items in the game. Each can be combined to create new or different items. There is so much of them that the player will feels overwhelmed at first. The more you explore the vast amount of item combinations you will figure out that most of the items you can create are useless stuff you might never gonna use on your travels.

The Ugly
Characters the player meets during the main story or the side quests are boring as hell! Throughout the entire game I gave a ♥♥♥♥ about those characters. Badly written quests and characters invite to simply skip the obsolete dialog and just do what the quest marker tells you to do! If Dragon’s Dogma 2 will happen, then I hope they will increase the writing and the likeability of the presented characters.

You can only have one savegame! Which means you can only play one character. If you want to start a new game or Hard or Speedrun Mode then you will need to delete your existing character to start all over. To avoid this you have to locate the savegame and copy it somewhere else otherwise you will lose the character and the progress you made with it. Bad move Capcom!

Why Recommended?
If not the characters or main quests but the gameplay is what carries the game!  Capcom created great gameplay mechanics like the combat, class & pawn system. Even though some items seem useless, experimenting with items and item combinations can be fun regardless of the outcome. Once you got the hang of what item combinations are important or in which progression you should skill and build up your characters the game will surprise you with a great post-game experience in which you will fight new monsters, explore new dungeons for new items, new boss battles and more quests with hellish good rewards! If that is not enough, then you can try to beat the game on Hard or Speedrun Mode!

If you are someone that wants to 100% this game, then I highly recommend using the games wiki for. Simply searh for the wiki on google and you'll find it.

reviewText:
One of the greatest and most overlooked video games of the 7th generation gets a fantastic and much needed PC port.

Personally, Dragon's Dogma is my favorite game of all time, but it is FAR from perfect, even with this port. The main issues, the framerate, the awful textures, and the strange aspect ratios are resolved. However the pop in that was awful in the console versions is still present, and I think is even more noticable since it clashes with the improvements. NPC's still take a little while to load, another annoying bug of the console versions.

However, minor nitpicks aside, this makes what was already a tremendous game even better. Yeah you can't FLY INTO FREE, a change to the original Dark Arisen due to licensing issues, and you can't do Berserk OTP fanfic cosplay, again, to licensing issues, but that doesn't change the fact that this game is a must play. Give it a go, and if you're not sold by the time you get to Gran Soren then it might just not be for you.

Edit: After more playing I've found a couple annoying gripes. For one Capcom didn't include the Eternal Ferrystone*, originally a gift for those that had played the original Dragon's Dogma before the Dark Arisen expansion. They still kept the price dirt cheap for Ferrystones at The Black Cat, but it's just annoying having to even worry about them in the first place. Secondly, it might just be a bug for me, but my visual settings reset whenever I exit the game, again just a minor gripe but it still shouldn't have to be bothered with.

*You have to get your first Ferrystone and then the Eternal Ferrystone will appear in your inventory.

reviewText:
I don't think I have enough words in my vocabulary to describe how fantastic this game is, but I'll try.

After pumping over 200 hours and 17 playthroughs into this game on Xbox, I was a bit skeptical about spending $30 for a PC port that I wasn't sure would have lived up to the original.

I want to go back in time and slap myself in the face for thinking that.

Everything that I loved about this game is still there, and boy does it feel great to be back.

The graphics, while by no means fantastic, are great for setting the mood of the game. Its dark, its gloomy, there is absolutely nothing good about the situation you're in. Having the constant need for a lantern just about everywhere you go helps drive this point home.

The gameplay feels like a dream. Like something that I had thought up as a kid, and hoped that one day it would become a thing. I mean, a sandbox rpg with bosses big enough that you can climb on? Shut up and take my money

The story seems lackluster on the surface, but deep down... holy ♥♥♥♥. I mean, name another game that found a way to make New Game+ canon. Do it, I dare you.

The difficulty is at that perfect level of not too hard, but not too easy.

The pawn system was genious. It broke my typical I always run solo" mentality that I got from other sandbox rpgs

reviewText:
I have played Dark Arisen on ps3 way back when and sunk 150+ hours in it. Game is nothing short of a masterpiece.

Fast and fluid combat with a lot of variety and great deal of customization of playstyles of each vocation. Party based combat, soloable, take your pick. destroying body parts yields rare materials for crafting.

My favorite parts of the game are post game dungeons and roaming by far, also the dark arisen dungeon (best played after the main story).

Story is hugely underrated in this game. Several fake" endings and post game epilogues are simply jaw dropping. Final final final boss and the way you deal with them is an amazing moment of videogame narrative.

Music is very atmospheric and battle themes get you hype every time.

Photo mode is a great thing to capture those cool moments when you are about to jump on a griffons back or stab a cyclops in the eye.

No JP voices and no Berserk gear is a bummer and awards -200 otaku points. But its not a huge deal

reviewText:
I bought this game on release day for PS3. Got pushed by the wind, trolled by the griffins, matured tons of steak, hired a bunch of sultry pawns etc etc. Then I started a new game because I wanted to create my character again. Yes, just regular RPG fan symptoms. This process repeated itself like a few days and I still had't even got to Gran Soren yet.

Then somehow I finished my first playthrough in about 100 hours. Got pushed by the wind too much.

Hundred of hours more, and 4 years later...

Dragon's Dogma is finally on Sssteeeaaammm yeeeaaarrrghhh!
Seriously, this game is overall better than even the likes of Dragon Age, Skyrim, Witcher etc. It is my most favorite RPG of all time alongside Dark Souls and Kingdoms of Amalur.

+ Very nice graphics for a game developed in 2011. The texture details are not wonderful but the overall scenery is beautiful. The atmosphere of the game also gives the it a very unique feeling.
+ Great music and sound.
+ Nice variety of quite-balanced character classes. They feel very different from each other. Look at the scale of those spells from the Sorcerer! Feel like a boss with the Assassin! Tower defense mode with the Mystic Knight! And how are you not feeling satisfied by that earth-shaking slam by the Warrior's greatsword? Some may not fit your playstyle like others but they are all very nice overall.
+ Awesome combat system and boss battles. I think the most popular opinion about this game's selling point is the interesting combat system. The regular hack-and-slash combat has a nice arcade feel with it, while the big monster fights do give you the sense of a real hard fight. Climbing on top of a Chimera and hack the goat off, shooting the Griffin off the sky, throwing a fire bolt at the Orge's knees to make it fall down, wrestling a Harpy down so your teammate can finish it off, bashing a wolf's head to stun it when it's charing in your direction, etc etc
+ Monster varieties and designs are simple but very effective. RPGs nowadays tend to go for over-the-top designs that actually make the monsters look too cheesy. Look at the monsters in this game: dragon, griffin, ogre, chimera, cyclop, gargoyle, golem, hydra, harpy, lich, undead etc etc They look exactly like what you expected but still very impressive.
+ Zombies at night! The game turns into a bit of a survival horror game at night which is very interesting. Your lantern runs out of oil, then you see those glowing eyes of the zombies in the dark... Muahahahah good luck!
+ The pawn system is very nice, just don't mess up the inclinations.
+ The fast travel problem has been dealt with, with the introduction of Eternal Ferrystones.

- Quite boring NPCs overall.
- Voice acting is lacking both quality and quantity.
- Quests are a bit dull and sometimes the directions are not clear.
- If you are not used to one-dimensional classes like the Warrior for example, you will find it very boring and repetitive compared to the likes of Assassin and Mystic Knight.
- A few bugs here and there but let's give it time, patches and fixes will come.

All in all a very nice port. Hopefully we can get the Berserk armor back XD
Moooaaarrr DLC please! Yes! Yes! Yes!

The wind is pushing me

9/10"

reviewText:
I love Dragon's Dogma. It's one of my favorite games from the last console generation. It's something akin to Monster Hunter, but a little less... bizarre. Like Monster Hunter you create a person and play with them, but unlike Monster Hunter there's levels, classes, magic, skills and an assortment of quests to complete in a (mostly) open world. Going to split this into two parts: port report and game review.

Port Report:

One of the best ports I've ever played, especially for a Japanese developer. 144 hertz support right out of the box, stable, runs well. I tried mouse and keyboard for a bit, but I played the game orginally with a controller and it still feels best for being a melee fighter. The game looks LOADS better than it did on the last generation and thankful isn't capped at 15 or 20 FPS or whatever it was last time. Some of the textures are a little muddy, but otherwise the game looks rather good for a last gen title.

Game:
Dragon's Dogma is one of the coolest one-offs Capcom ever did. The story is rather decent (expecially once you get through multiple playthroughs for the meta" aspect) for a fantasy game

reviewText:
Completely hooked on this.

The enemies (even if somewhat cliché) are glorious and intelligient, just wait untill you have your first fight with an Ogre or Cyclops and embrace the epicness. The AI, in my opinion, is top notch.

The Pawn system is brilliant. Your followers actually feel useful instead of just wandering around and occasionally hitting something. You can influence how your main pawn acts in and out of combat and how their speech is affected.

Class system, really good. While looking a bit bland on the outside the game actually encourages you to try different vocations, aquiring numerous Augments (which are passive abilities) to add to your preffered class.
All the combat skills feel fluid and the power of the skill normally matches the animations. Nothing feels out of place.

The World itself is Huge, There are so so many places to go. There are no mounts, but there is a ferrystone (hearthstone) and there are portcrystals you can shove into the ground to make your own return points.
Night = Pitch black, nuff said.

A must have for anyone who loves the Elder scrolls, Zelda or Souls Games.

Solid 9/10

Tis but a scratch!

reviewText:
I honestly don't know how I missed this Capcom game on the ps3 xD.
I've only like 10hrs atm, but omg this game is fun!
Create your main char.
Create your sidechick/man.
You can change your vocation in towns, so if you get bored as a knight, lets try a mage! :D ( you can change your sidechick/man vocation as well )
You can add/change 2 pawns in your group. ( max party group 4 )
Open-world, epic fights, *F* = grab on to enemy and start hacking at them.
Only con I see is that fast traveling seems rather weak, but it doesn't bother me as I like killing stuff, gathering loot, and exploring areas as a I go.
Overall great game!

reviewText:
Allow me to start this review with some shameless advertising:

TAKE ANNAYA! A brilliant level 20+ ulitarian/ medicant mageling who enchants your weapons, cooks your enemies, heals your papercuts and rubs your feet (though the last happens when offline.) Annaya, the mage for all your needs! I certainly won't regret you taking her!

*ahem*

The game. I love this game for the following reasons:

*Pawns: The pawnsystem I like a lot. Pawns are awesome. Compared to most games where you get conpanions/servants/ pets they are actually incredbly usefull as well. Where a companion in Skyrim mostly serves as eye-candy they really augment your main (and each other) here. Teamwork FTW.

*The graphics help me immerse myself in the game, especially the day and night cycle (and the dawn and evening transition) really enhance the game's appeal for me. No sudden day or night for you sir/ lady.

*Day and night cycle. I often stay out to late and aside from missing dinner I suddenly get tested to the hilt in areas I skipped through laughing during daylight. Where bandits and goblins hunt during the day I ran into undead and weird whispering mages in the night on the same spot.
And how about the dead rising all around you because you just had to cross a graveyard at night? I loved it.

*I like the way you can armor and arm your character, every part is represented layered armors are awesome. I wish more games had this.

*Physics. Seeing a berserk flaming enraged ogre rush off a ledge and then getting a fat xp reward is pretty rewarding. Shame about the loot though. There also is a lot of interaction with the environment.
Climbing on enemies is a really, really nice touch as well. I always wanted a Chimera mount and it's a pity they don't want me as rider!

*ANNAYA (awesome pawn now for hire)

There are things I like a bit less as well ofcourse.

*The game's combat mechanics need some getting used to and the starting buttons on the keyboard need a master of yoga to handle properly. Or someone with six+ fingers (per hand that is) perhaps.

*Save a lot. You can die swiftly and since loot is random that may mean losing that awesome cloak you found just before. *sobs*

*Quests have no difficulty indicator. Especially escort quests can be hard; having to pass a cyclops, chimera and dragon in that order to reach a durned fortress was a weeee bit much for my level 18 group. They can be a little vague as well at times.

*Occasionally pawns can be derpy. Having a pawn rush ahead when you stand on a ledge and watching it fall isn't a good thing. Pawns picking each others bodies up when I am trying to get them back up and trying to dodge an ogre at the same time isn't good either. This never happened to Annaya ofcourse, it always happens to other pawns. Honest.

Conclusion:

I love this game. It has its flaws but they are tiny compared to the good bits and its even better when you hire ANNAYA as pawn!

reviewText:
(Instead of basically saying the same things everyone else has already said, I’m going to write a short story about one of my many noteworthy experiences. You will have stories like this and many more if you decide to pick up this fantastic, under-appreciated action RPG.)


It’s been a day and a half since we left Gran Soren.

Although my pawns were putting forth a brave face, I knew they were tired. I could feel it, too—though my daggers were still as sharp as ever, the arms that wielded them were sore from the constant conflict of the night. When night fell, we had been crossing the ridge into southern Gransys, and quickly found ourselves accosted on every side by bandits. We were prepared—many journeys along the road to Gran Soren from my hometown had taught Senna, my main pawn, the best way to deal with these rogues. She had taken a fancy to grabbing them from behind, leaving them open to a flurry of scarlet kisses from my blades.

But our destination still lay ahead of us, deep in goblin country. Larger, more powerful goblins infested these roads, yelling broken obscenities at us as we approached. They wore armor that made it difficult to assault them, but the mage pawn I had recruited worked out that they were weak to fire, enchanting our weapons with burning heat that cooked the goblins’ shriveled skin on impact.

We happened across a large pack of goblins at the foot of a tree. I sneaked forward and took out my bow, aiming upward. I fired a cloudburst of arrows into the sky, which came down like rain on the unsuspecting enemies. They scrambled about wildly, looking for the source, finally spotting me.

It immediately became apparent that there was something different about these goblins. A few of them rushed me, as I was expecting, but more still hung back, pulling out crude horns, blowing discordant notes into the air. Some sort of war horn? A call to battle? It mattered not the purpose—I instantly knew that these horns must be silenced.

My pawns sprung into action, engaging the goblins at melee, while I went to work as a sniper, pulling the bowstring as far back as it would go to inflict massive damage at range. One after another, they fell as my arrows find their marks.

I felt the ground tremor under my feet. What was that? My eagle eyes scanned the horizon, looking for the source. It was only then that I noticed that a cyclops that was on the other side of the knoll had heard all the noise from the horns, and was coming to investigate. It stood at fifteen feet tall, and carried a club that was as tall as he was. Seeing us, it let out a cry and jumped a surprising distance, joining the fray.

My pawns noticed the new combatant immediately. Only one of us—the powerfully built female warrior pawn that reminded me of Senna—had ever fought a cyclops before. “Assault its eye!” she cried, charging into combat with her five-foot greatsword in tow.

The battle raged. The cyclops was a terrible foe, as it had gargantuan reach with its club and power to match. Being walloped with it was like being hit by a falling tree, but you had to pick yourself up quickly, or risk being stomped on.

For once in my life, I was frustrated with my daggers. Their blazing fast speed availed me naught against such a foe. However, by a stroke of luck, my mage pawn summoned a lightning bolt, which stunned the beast and brought it to its knees, leaving its eye vulnerable to my flashing steel. As it recovered and pulled itself to its feet, I began to hatch a daring scheme.

I sprinted at it from behind, taking a flying leap and grabbing on tight. I scampered up its back as it flailed like the world’s most wrathful mountain. Once I reached its crown, I began to bury my blades in its eye over and over as the cyclops screamed in pain. Reveling in my cunning, I didn’t notice its wandering hands until they were upon me, pulling me off its head and holding me in its ever-tightening grip.

The warrior was the only one to realize the danger I was in. “’I shall scale its back and help the Arisen!” she cried. She grabbed on to its back as I had, and began climbing slowly, her giant claymore held in her free hand.
I struggled to break free, praying my mage would use another lightning bolt to stun the beast so it would drop me. But, the bolt would not come. I strained my neck to see what she was doing, and noticed her incanting a spell. Was… was she healing me?

The warrior was halfway up the cyclops' back before it grew tired of my struggling. It pulled back its hands, and then clapped them together with all its strength, shattering every bone in my body and killing me instantly. But right before that, as I saw the palm rushing toward me, I had only one thought…

What an idiot pawn. All they had to do was use Levin, but instead they tried to heal me?
I know someone who’s going home with a Sour Scrag of Beast and a one-star rating.

reviewText:
A hidden gem of a game. It has a lot of flaws, but what it does right more than makes up for them, There are lots of little mechanics that all add to an overall sense of adventure and role-playing that few modern RPG's can compare to. Also, you get all the DLC with this bundle. This is also a really good PC port, but I think it is best played with a console controller.

The bad
-Pawns are silly. Their AI makes them good for little more than packmules or meatshields. Don't give them any valuable curatives.

-no dodge mechanic for all the classes. Only one class has a dodge move, eveyone else has to ackwardly jump out of the way of attacks they don't want to eat.

-Really bad UI. The user interface is really bad. Managable, but bad.

-Long walks from point a to point b. This is somewhat helped by the fast-travel system, but traveling across long distances can be a chore sometimes.

-No co-op. A co-op mode to play with friends would be amazing.



The meh
-Predictable monster spawns. This can be annoying to encounter the same monsters in the same areas, but if you need to hunt that one type of monster, you know where to go.

-The story. Not great, not bad, just good enough to make sense.

-One save file. You can get items to change your appearance and start the adventure again once you beat it, but you're stuck with your stats forever. Equipment will really be what defines you in the late game and new game+, but having the ability the make stat changes without starting over would be nice.

-Not much variation on landscapes and monster design. There are lots of monsters, but many are stronger reskins of things you've fought before with a new trick or two. Landscapes could also do with more variation. 60-70% of the time, you'll be wandering through a forest with pine trees. The rest you'll spend in caves, swamps, and ruins.


The great
-Best character creator I've played with in a long time. Customize everything from your height to your voice! Want to be short, tall, skinny, or fat? Go right ahead! Want to make a dwarven giant-slayer or an kid-sized wizard? You can! Want to have Shrek adventure alongside Harry Potter? You can! It's so easy to use to. Simple menus and plenty of templates allow for easy use.

-Play dress up. Armor and clothing are layred on top of each other and allow for some very unique outfits. Also, capes, lots of capes to flow majestically in the breeze.

-Class-based warfare. Unlike most modern openworld RPG's, you class matters. Play a warrior and channel your inner Guts as you cut down entire packs of monsters with sweeping blows from gigantic weapons; or take up the mantle of the fleet-footed strider and scale gigantic foes to strike their weakpoints. Or just be a mage and hang back to heal your team and enchant their weapons.

-It's dangerous to go alone! In the early game you'll die if you don't bring a few pawns to support you. Monsters often attack in huge packs and giant foes will bite your head off. You'll also need specific elements to attack specific foes. Magic is the only way to hurt ghosts and some foes need physical might to bring down.

-Action packed battles! Climb up giant foes to punch them in the face! Put smaller monsters in a head-lock so another member of your team can punch them in the face! Unless you're charging up a spell or a skill, you're likely moving to attack or get out of the way of an attack. Even some ofthe biggest monsters will be constantly on the move, requiring you to keep up to be effective.

-Lots of little machanics to keep you on your toes! Weight management is key, the heavier your load, the slower you move. Unlike other games where you only have two speeds, overburdened and not overburdened. Dark nights and darker caves will make carrying a lantern key to sucess. Make sure to carry empty flasks for any interesting liquids you want to take home, bring picks to mine, and be sure you've got airtight containers to preserve foods as they ferment to their restorative peeks. There are a bunch of little things to keep track of that other openworld RPG's would omit for the sake of mass appeal.

-Big, open world. This game world is huge. You can explore just about anywhere you like, but chances are you'll get one-shot by monsters if your not careful, or if you stay out during the night. Night is dangerous too. The undead rise and ghosts and worse will prowl the lands.

-Amazing boss fights. Tackle monsters of all size and shape in thrilling encounters. Flying beasts need to be knocked out the air and armored giants require powerful attacks to stagger. Also, the best Hyrda fights around.

reviewText:
Great open-world-sandbox hack'n'slash RPG! Even if the setting is utterly generic fantasy, the story is meaningless until the end and the map isn't actually as huge and varied in say, the Elder Scrolls games. The combat isn't like Dark Souls and yet it still works really well, there's a lot of physics-based fighting with knocking enemies down cliffs and grappling and climbing on top of huge monsters. I was thoroughly entertained all the way. Don't get this for the story, get this for tossing goblins.

The biggest unique twist is that you get to design your sidekick character who will be completely AI-controlled and who will learn from your actions. Even though this is a single player game, your sidekick will be uploaded for other players to hire and you can hire two more sidekicks in the same way, completing your 4-character squad. Your sidekick will earn gear and levels only while traveling with you, but it will learn quest knowledge, combat strategies and world navigation while traveling with other players. Mostly it will be repeating the same lines you've heard hundreds of times but eh, sometimes it mentions something useful and I like to travel with talkative minions. Don't expect any Bioware style character storylines though.

Another great idea is that there aren't any QTEs or press X to be awesome" scripted moments in boss fights
date: they're very freeform and if you want to stab a huge monster in the eye with your sword
recommended: you need to manually grapple the beast and hang on and climb over to the head and hope you don't get shaken off. It makes the boss fights feel really awesome and clever
hoursPlayed: especially as there's plenty of tricky monsters where you need to figure out what the weak point is.\n\nThis PC version has all the DLC included
voteText: so once you get close to finishing the main story or start to get bored with the main world map
helpfulPercent: you can head out to the Bitterblack Isle expansion area. Instead of open outside areas
votesHelpful: it's more like a sequence of dungeons
votesTotal: a bit Dark Souls inspired
votesFunny: with lots of randomized variants (and increased difficulty). It's a great expansion
commentsCount: while using the same lovely combat system as the main game the areas and enemies are quite different
column16: so it feels almost like a different game. Plenty of optional stuff to repeat and grind to gain overpowered endgame items
column17: if that's your thing.\n\nI had zero problems and zero crashes with this PC version port and it even runs smoothly on my older hardware so tech-wise too I think it's a damn fine job. I guess I should stop calling them "Crapcom" from now on."

reviewText: One of my favorite games of all time. Dragon's Dogma is a game with a tremendous story, terrific gameplay, and one of the best experiences I've had playing a game. It was one of my top games for the PS3 and I'm so happy to see it come to the PC with enhanced graphics and framerate that make the game even more stunning compared to the PS3 version. I recommend this game to anyone that enjoys a third-person style RPG with real-time engaging combat. The Pawn system is a unique companion system that allows you to share your companion with other players to help aid them on their quest and help your companion learn to handle different scenarios. The class system in the game allows you to enjoy the game however you want whether it be archery, greatswords, magic, and more. Combat is intense and thrilling making it bound to bring up memorable moments. The story is incredible and so well put together it brought a tear to my eye! I can't recommend this game strongly enough!
voteText: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I just finished the main story and holy molly the game was something awesome so ill just start the review!

Story: The whole story revolves around a dragon that threatens to destroy the Kingdom and you ( The Arisen) who has been entrusted by Pawns ( warriors appointed through spirits to defeat beasts) to kill the dragon and destroy any who worship it, as well as steal back the heart that the dragon stole from you.
(+) The story keeps you going  ( keeps you motivated)
(-) Sometimes you just dont know whats going on in the story or why something is happening
(-) Its not the most well executed story but in the end its there
Gameplay: This is where Dragon's Dogma truly shines...Most of the game youll be traveling on foot to locations and fighting varied enemies across a huge landscape. Youll be fighting Goblins, wolves, ogres, cyclops' and some human enemies as well. Youll have the most fun with the bosses and in this case its a mix of Shadow of Colossus and Monster Hunter. You can climb bosses and stab them in the eye as they try to shake you away and weapons and armor are leveled up instead of using XP points. Your pawns can be both helpful and quite stupid at the same time. They mostly start to shout the same things at you and theyll get in the way alot, but when they are helpful, they throw helpful spells to strengthen your blows or hold enemies down while you deal the killing blow. There are so many class variations to choose from each with their own abilities, weapons and fighting styles that are very different. For example a Strider class can do a frontflip in the air and slam down hard effectively hurting the enemy, while a Fighter can rush in and push multiple enemies back with a single bash. Because of how different the fighting styles are, everyone is going to have a different experience playing.
(+) Great Boss Battles
(+) Great Level Up system
(+) Loads of customization
(+) Combat is addicting and satisfying bacause of how fast it is
(-) Lack of Fast Travel
(-) You sometimes have to fight the same enemies multiple times
(-) Pawns can be dumb sometimes
Graphics: The graphics arent amazing but they sure do beat the Xbox 360 versios. Theres no more horrible frame drops and alot of the textures and lighting effects have been revamped. Theres no cost to this as it runs very smooth 1080p 60fps and is a great Pc Port.

In the end you got a great action RPG that is cinematically exciting and not too much of a challenge. Its always addicting to find better gear to fight with and to find pawns that are usefull and that can turn the tide of a battle. The boss battles are amazing because of the almost unlimited freedom that you have in them and while this game isnt perfect its still one of Capcom's greatest achievements.

But seriously that love scene at the end was so awckward and out of place lol damn it Capcom!

reviewText: Dragon's Dogma is a bit of everything, depending on your gaming-background and preference it could be seen as something that is kinda close to Monster Hunter, Dark Souls, average JRPGs and even western openworld-rpgs. At the core it is japanese through and through, it's first and foremost a game about mechanics - meaning it excels at combat and mastery of movement and well as grinding for equipment and building your arsenal is mandatory, but even when you are not having an understanding of the systems at work or what is going on, it stays accessible and kicking ♥♥♥ feels good.\n\nOnce understood that the fun of Dragon's Dogma comes from powerleveling and killing huge creatures and not a movie-like experience, you can truly start losing yourself in the game. If you are in it for varied characters, epic" questlines
date: story or a vast and interesting world - you might as well think about skipping the game
recommended: all these elements are only here to support the mechanics. You don't fight for the next cutscene or bit of storyline
hoursPlayed: instead cutscenes and story prepare you for your next fight.\n\nWith that out of the way

I've barely slept since its release, give it a try, its well worth the money. my personal 7.5/10

Long PRO/CON version:

PROs:

Lots of customization.

Spells/skills feel amazing to use, even the non-magical ones.

Very agreeable price. They could have taken the ubisoft route with this one, I'm glad they didn't.

Very good combat mechanics. I dont feel bored, even when fighting smaller mobs instead of the bigger baddies.

The game runs smooth as silk.

Open world without feeling completely copy-pasted.

Berserk references.

Exploring is fun, because:

Players that stick around and explore are rewarded with loot from hidden chests.

Holy f*ck did the dragons turn out to be hardcore.

Very likeable main adversary. I'd invite him to a party.

Finger of the Maker.

The first quick-travel system I could appreciate in an open-world game, as opposed to the skyrim way of just teleporting everywhere you have to go.

You can romance anyone that isnt the duke or your pawns. Anyone.
You're a masochist? Aelinore.
You're a masochist. but also a paedophile? Symone.
You like fat, hairy, corrupt merchants? Fournival.
Would you like to cuck the duke? Aelinore.
Annoying french muscle-girl? Mercedes.
Annoying french muscle-guy? Julien.
Hobos, knights, peddlers, kids, pensioners, they're all ripe for the taking.

CONs:

Too little gear. The best gear availiable is more often than not the gear in the shops that unlock at certain points in the game, and that takes out a lot of fun out of the looting (pre-bitterblack).

NG+ isnt harder.

Pawns feel kind of like autistic robot children with a hatred towards all things wooden, rather than actual characters. Several times in the story you're told of the interesting differences between the pawns and humans, and you get to meet some pretty cool characters that used to be pawns, but your pawn? Nah, he's just telling you for the thousandth time that wolves hunt in packs or how humans have a lot of expressions. This is more just my opinion, but it kinda irked me.

Gee, thanks game for not telling me that this seemingly pointless escort quest for affinity-points would define just how sh*t my immediate future would turn out, gear-wise.

The characters expressions freak me the f*ck out. Half-life 2 had much better facial animations in 2004.

Extensive craftingsystem for arrows/heals/cure-whatevers, but not for gear.

Guts and Griffith armour taken out due to licensing issues ... ? The f*ck?

It doesn't look as good as it could have, even for a game from 2013.



Most of my gripes with this game are just nitpicking. The game could have been my perfect game with some slight changes, but it is still a very, VERY good game.

reviewText:
For some reason i was playing this game almost non-stop for the past week, trying to complete BBI with fresh charachter.
Basically a vageta311 BBI challenge(https://www.reddit.com/r/DragonsDogma/comments/41xsvw/bitterblack_challenge_if_you_feel_the_game_is_too/).
Was very entrtaining, at least until i got good gear and become ridiculously overpowered for the main game even on hard.
I somehow starting to come to realisation that japanese-developed games that trying to emulate western style may be one of my favourites.
People who developed DD completly understand that story in games is irrelevant.
Games should be good games in the first place.
And it is a good game.
Combat is top notch...(who was director on this? - Hideaki Itsuno, also was director on Dmc 2,3, and 4, and was actully involved in reboot) well no surprise here.
You have 9 different classes with tons of abilities, combos and weapons. A game where being mage actually feels good and like actually being a mage.
Hybrid classes  done right. And dont forget good`old tradition of japanese games like giving all major enemies and bosses a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of health so you can unleash on them every one of your trick before they come down.
Rinse and repeat. And it tastes great.

What else do you need?

Damn, this game is so good, I'm playing it since release every day and I can't stop playing.

Pro/Cons

reviewText:
TL;DR: The game plays basically like a fusion of Dragon Age, Shadow of the Colossus, and Dark Souls.  If that sounds fun to you, then you'll probably like this game.

As a somewhat tired and jaded gamer, it's become a rare treat when I play a game that really feels special.  Something crafted with a very specific idea in mind, something unique.  A labor of love, if you will. Dragon's Dogma is one of those games.

However, I wouldn't recommend it to everyone.

Dragon's Dogma:Dark Arisen (DDDA) is often likened to Dark Souls (DaS).  When people say this, they aren't referring to its difficulty, because it's certainly not as tough as the palm-sweatingly punishing experiences we associate with those games.  What I think they mean is, very much like Dark Souls, Dragon's Dogma is a western-styled RPG made in Japan.  This creates a few unique aspects to the game.  quirky voice acting, and innovative gameplay among them.

See, when a western developer (or any really) makes an open-world RPG these days, there's basically a checklist laid out for them.  Its been done so many times that many devs play a sort of mad-libs with features and build the gameplay around a predefined concept or story.  It often feels like the gameplay is taking a backseat in priority to the narrative or world building. This is especially true in modern western-RPGs (WRPGS).  Many of them are going to have some sort of base stat system reminiscent of Dungeons and Dragons (str,agi,etc). They're going to most likely have some form of action based combat, unless we're talking about the wave of kickstarted Isometric CRPGs that have been making a resurgence.  Even then, they're mostly still based on DnD style systems with dice rolls, a morality/alignment system, and some sort of tree, or wheel based dialogue system.  My point is, many WRPGs share a set of common game design features, a standardization, of sorts.

Dragon's Dogma, like Dark Souls, pays almost no mind to those time-tested and trialed standards.  In the same way, it also doesn't adhere to the even more strict" JRPG design guidelines.  There's no mandatory grinding
recommended: and no 30 minute cutscenes. It rides the same weird line Dark Souls does

reviewText:
I've really enjoyed this game so far.

Good Stuff    Open World: Wide open for the most part. Some areas are gated by the main quest, but there's a lot to explore, and exploration is usually rewarded.

Goodish Graphics: Decent character customization. The character models and textures could really have been a bit more detailed. The customization UI is okay; not as many options as I'd have liked, and it's far easier to create a hideous character than a beautiful one. The gear is much better quality. The world is well designed and interesting; again, textures could have been higher quality but this was a console game.

Progression: Lots of gear. You're always on the lookout for upgrades, and these are reasonably well distributed across levels. I hear that at some point you sort of outlevel the gear grind itself, and can dress more how you like. Levels and vocation ranks are quick, and skills are distributed well.

Classes: Major class archetypes are covered, with the exception of healer" (more on that later). You can change your vocation (class) at any time

reviewText:
As a PC port, the game is very faithful to the PS3 version, with some really slick upgrades, like running virtually flawlessly at 60FPS in my 1900x1200 monitor at the best settings. The terrible draw distance and the dated textures are still present, but overall don't detract from the full experience in a major way.

As a game, this is one of my favorites from the PS3 library. The combat is great, the story is decent, though not noteworthy, and the AI actually isn't half bad. Granted, it's not great, but in a cinch, a well-trained and equipped pawn can dig you out of trouble. The soundtrack is wonderful (I recommended buying it, if you have the extra cash) and the voice acting is pretty cool. The dialogue has this very unique Old English feel, and it definitely feels like a cool new world.

Support this game so Capcom will continue making awesome stuff like this in the future!
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is definitive proof that a game can amount to much, much more than the sum of its parts. Graphically, it's stunningly mediocre, but it manages to be amazingly good-looking at times, especially in dark dungeons and night scenes where your lantern is the only source of illumination. The art direction too is pretty solid in a Japanese ARPG sort of way, managing to make up for the technical limitations. The environments, polygonal and bare though they may be, can be surprisingly pretty at times, too, making up for the lack of precise details by invoking a grand sense of scale and possibility.

Altogether, the presentation does what it's supposed to: it doesn't hinder anything - big monsters are suitably imposing, the animations are suitably smooth and non-distracting, and it evokes the scale and character of the fantasy world you're exploring. This game doesn't really have a story so much as a bunch of Berserk references strung together against the backdrop of an American straight-to-VHS medieval fantasy film world. (That also being the sequence of words I'd use to describe the general art direction.)

People talk in a cheesy old-timey way, your pawns constantly dispense helpful advice, and everyone just sorts of mills around all day in a duchy with seemingly only two small cities. You'd think all of these things would be immersion-breaking, but the fact that the game plays itself completely straight works massively in its favour. I really can't help but admire Dragon's Dogma's boundless sincerity - helped further that it doesn't force you to sit through endless exposition or attempt to infuse its story with artificial drama or cheap attempts at emotional manipulation. It knows what it is and it doesn't make excuses for it or try to be cute about it. I have endless respect for that.

Instead, the story is parceled out in easily digestible bits, just enough to give you a taste so you can make up your own mind about whether you want to chase the rest of it down yourself. And, more than that, by the end of it all, everything sort of clicks together and what appears at first to be unadulterated schlock instead turns out to be an alloyed core of interesting writing under a heavy coat of schlock-flavoured paint. Marvelous! Plus, the villain of this game is fantastic.

What of the gameplay, then? The important part, or so they say. Well, there's 9 classes and all of them seem to play fairly differently. I've only spent a lot of time in about three of them, but fighting monsters, casting spells and moving around the field feels intuitively simple and can get quite satisfying. In all of the parts of the main game that I've played, there really weren't any heart-pounding skin-of-your-teeth struggles to the death that you might get out of something like Dark Souls, but it's not afraid to throw a little whupass your way when the situation calls for it, and consequently when you get stronger, you can really feel it in the gameplay. It's also just fun to do things in general, whether clinging to monsters as they thrash and jump and spasm and you get the odd stab in, or calling down fiery meteors on little packs of goblins with your wizard powers. And, speaking of character progression, there's really not that much of it in the way of traditional RPG advancement - you don't allocate stat points or anything of the sort - you just level up, buying skills as they become available, while progression outside of that is mostly based on gear.

That said, what this game does wonderfully is evoking a sense of child-like wonderment. The dumpy-looking NPCs have just enough agency to them that there's a bit of human-like inscrutability to them, like there might be something guiding their decisions that we're not privy too. More than that, this is a game where for once I was actually curious to see what lies behind every corner and unturned stone of the game world. If you go on a long trek with limited resources, you can get boned, forced to limp away through the night to the tune of wolf's howls. Unexpected things happen, and the whole thing feels like a grand adventure. As you keep pressing forward, it always seems like something worthwhile awaits, whether new stories, new monsters to fight, new clothes for dress-up, new weapons to kill monsters with, or something else that isn't a copy-pasted cave full of draugr.

I got Dragon's Dogma expecting a fun little romp to distract me from my perpetual existential despair, but instead I got something that could very well be one of my favourite video games of all time. And I learned a lot about wolves.

reviewText:
It's funny how a game from 2012 (technically) is better than most games that have been released since then.
The combat is a marvel and I can't believe nobody decided to copy it yet, climbing a chimera and then setting it's goat head on fire with a flaming dagger is just too much fun.

The story is fun, the characters/enemies/dungeon are varied and you can share your waifu with your friends.
What else can you possibly want from an RPG?

My only gripe with the game is that there are no quicksave options. Sometimes you just have to leave suddenly and that means restarting a rather long journey in this game (depending on where you were going), hopefully that would get modded in somehow.

Otherwise it's one of the best games I've had the pleasure to play, well done Capcom!

Each class got 9 ranks that unlock skills and augments and you can use augments between the classes which makes it worthwhile to spend sometime maxing your classes before you tackle the harder content in the game(Dark Arisen DLC).\nWorth noting that when you level up you get stats depending on your current class(lvl1-100 gives higher stats per lvl

than 101-200). On the other hand mobs dont seem to scale with your level(even in NG+ I think the mobs got the stats from previous game which I find kinda cool) so its expected to have really hard time at the start and later on to find the whole world a piece of cake.

Map and running

Map may look big at first glance mainly duo to the stamina usage because you can either run(slow/fast depending on your inventory weight) or sprint and with the latter you need to use stamina(which you use also on skills) so you may want at the start to take it slowly until you learn where what spawns(which pisses me off a lot

column18:
there is day/night cycle which offer different challenges and resources to find if you dare.
Now in PC release once you reach the capital(Gran Soren) you are given Eternal Ferrystone that allows you to teleport from portcrystal to portcrystal though at the start you will have only 2 available: the one near the fishing village and the capital. Later on you can buy/find portcrystals through out the world and place them wherever you want which is helpful if you dont want to keep running left and right or dont want to bother with escorts(since NPC rarely talk during escort and also seems to obtain the desire to be punched by a cyclops). Still there are some interesting places to be found(most of them are quest locations so its worth doing all side quests).

Combat

column21: a cost that may cost you dearly .... long spell casting. So while you cast that sweet sweet meteor shower on your enemies you may get interrupted by a random mob which will make you run away and start casting again but once you cast the spell

you may just go have a break and then gather the loot. In my first fight with chimera I spent good time trying to kill it when my pawn decided to just destroy the chimera with 2 direct hits from meteors(good times) .

USP(Unique Selling Points)
For me this game offers 2 USPs - the well made boss fights and Pawn system so lets talk about them.

Boss Fights

While boss fights later in the game can feel like a chore
column23: the first impression is great. Every boss got weakspots and being strong/weak to certain elements so while playing you may want to experiment a little to learn those weaknesses and exploit them in combat.\nAlso lets not forget the really unique part of the boss fights : climbing on the bosses. This can be priceless at times

especially against bigger monsters where you are climbing your way to their weak spot and then start stabbing them while they are trying to get rid of you like the little bug you are to them.

Pawns

Now thats something that can make the game hilarious or bothersome depending on the AI. So what are pawns? Pawns is companion that is given to you because you are an Arisen. You can customize your pawn the same way you customized your character. You can give them class and equipment
column25: teach them skills and so on. And by teaching skilsl I dont mean only set their skills but also their behaviour. You see
column26: pawns will often mimic your skills once you perform them long enough in front of them. So its worth it to pick the class of your vocation and try to teach your pawn how to reach in different situations.\nYou can also hire up to 2 more pawns created by other players. Its important what level pawns you hire - hire higher level and will cost you Rift Crystals(currency that you receive from drops

pawns can give you good insights about different encounters and quests instead of googling it.

Overall
Its a game that I truly enjoyed even though it didnt offer the RPG depth I prefer(aka in questing and decision making) but that doesnt stop the game to be something worth playing if you want well made boss encounters."

reviewText:
Dogma is a large game spread over a sizable map that is quite insistent you explore fully. Though the Dark Arisen update makes exploration easier by providing collectible portals you can strategically place around the map to use as quick travel points, it really prefers that you go everywhere on foot. Such journeys are often long and fraught with danger, relying on Dogma’s night/day cycle to mix up the threats. Pedestrian worries like bandits and roving goblin gangs threaten travelers during the day, while the undead are more likely to be found seizing the night. Initial exploration into unknown territory is often an adventure in itself, with long forgotten camps or razed strongholds to sometimes stumble across and explore. Or you can just wait for a quest to come along and force you in that direction. There’s always some excuse to head west, but moments when you find something new are exhilarating. Discoveries bleed into one another, daring you to risk pushing a little further into the unknown.

Fifty-hour me had outgrown all of that, though. Fifty-hour me had explored the entirety of the map, had stormed hobgoblin strongholds and used the mounted ballista situated atop cliff faces to peg explosive bolts at the small army waiting to ambush him. He had chased off a magically resurrected cockatrice, and only got half his traveling party petrified in the process. He had tracked a gargoyle down to its hidden lair high in the mountains because the bloody thing had stolen someone's post!. He sat on the edge of game completion. There were just a couple of missions left to go. It was time to venture to Bitterblack Isle.

Full Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12921/pc/dragons-dogma-dark-arisen/review.html

reviewText: If you are any fan of action RPGs then this game is definitely for you. Honestly there isn't much choice for this genre outside the Souls games. However this game was directed by Hideaki Itsuno who also directed the Devil May Cry series so this game's combat and mechanics are hands down second to none. The combat is better than any souls game and the variety in play styles will keep you entertained for dozens of hours. The combat is also very challenging and Hard Mode is only recommended for veteran players, you WILL be one shot by large monsters even with decent gear. You've been warned.\n\nThe only thing that keeps this game from me is the game's story presentation. This game is all about the action and lacks polish in that department. It's not bad at all, but comparatively it could be much better. But that doesn't mean this game lacks in content, with Bitter Black Isle and the main game content you can easily spend over 100 hours before seeing everything. This game was made on a budget and considering what they did with how much money they had it is insanely impressive. If Dragon's Dogma had even close to the budget that Skyrim had then this game would be heralded as the best game of all time by nearly anyone. Such a shame.

reviewText:
One of the best RPG's I've played in the last 10 years. One of my favorites alongside Skyrim etc. What makes this game different is the use of pawns (companions) much like paper and pencil D&D. In fact this game very much reminds me of Dungeons & Dragons more than other game out there. It has a very strong influence from that game and the developers also mentioned Fighting Fantasy gamebooks having inspired the artwork. It has a very medeival combined with dark fantasy feel to it.

The game features many addictive qualities like building your character and pawn, replayabilty, sharing pawns amongst fiends, exploration, romance options with NPC's, dungeon delving, dragons, classic D&D monsters and a very immersive world due to the fact that fast travel being slighlty restricted when compared to other games. Combat is one of the best features in this game and is hands down the best (and funnest) in the genre. Once learned, it can almost compared to action games such as Devil May Cry with combos, thrusts, dodges and take downs. Climbing huge beasts also almost never gets old.

It's got flaws which prevent this from becoming a mainstream hit (expecially amongst review sites) but those flaws and the great features I mention above combine to make one of the most cult classic games of a generation.

This port is a fantastic job, the graphics are smooth (I'm running an older GTX 580) and many improvements have been made.

D&D fans, this is a must own. Casual RPG players.... take your time, stick to it, get better at the game and you will be rewarded with a  hidden gem of an RPG.

reviewText:
What can i say about this game? A lot to be sure, i never had a PS3 or Xbox 360, so when it first came out, i couldn't play it so the PC port alone earns praises from me, specially due to how well it was ported, higher fps, higher resolution, KB+M controls that aren't downright terrible(in fact, they have their own advantages in the hotkey function) and very well optimized running in many kinds of PCs.

As for the game itself, it starts slowwwww, the game tells you where to go regarding your main quests, but thats it, no hand holding on anything else, and i LOVE it, in an open world game YOU should be the one discovering, YOU should be the one learning about what to do, the NPCs shouldn't all magically tell you the what-do of the place and the best part, when you discover what to do, theres no guarantee you can actually do it, because this game's enemies don't scale with you, they have a fixed strength, which will make you notice your own growth even more as you go from puny fisherman to Dragonslayer demigod.

My main praises for this game go towards the combat, as many people would say as well, hack n' slash will most likely only get you killed and you need to properly learn what to do against each  of the stronger monsters, each of the vocations feels and plays great, but sadly due to how stat growth is done, you can't really have all vocations in one character unless you go the balanced route and that is my only problem with this jewel, 1 savegame and no way to reroll your stats(not a legit way at least), which leaves  a bad taste, i leveled as warrior/assassin, which means i can play the physical classes just fine, but sometimes i get the itch to play magick knight/archer/sorcerer and i am quickly reminded of how low my magic attack is.

No game is complete without a soundtrack and in this one's case, its magnificent, the combat soundtrack just adds to the epic feeling you get when fighting big monsters, gets you going when the theme changes after you meet certain requirements and basically says STRIKE NOW!" to you with the change

TLDR; version >>> if you like Action based RPGs with unique and interesting mechanics and lots of replay vaule, then get this game. For $30 bucks / 30eur it's well worth your time and money.
