reviewText:
TL;DR: Score 8/10 overall. For more detailed review, look below.



Dragon's Dogma is one of my favorite games of all time.

From the music to the pawns this game is fantastic and is still fantastic from the time that i spent playing it on the 360. I will be going into more details about the game as this review goes on but for now allow me to tell you a tiny summery of the games story. I will try to avoid spoilers.

The Beginning of a Legend. -A Short Summery-
You are Arisen. Born in a small fishing village on the coast, you think your life will be simple and care free until one day it all changes. A dragon attacks the village and takes your heart and says to you, if you want it back you must face him. Now it is your destiny to fight the dragon and take back what was yours. Through grit, determination and the help of those known as the Pawns, you will take the fight to the denizens of the land. From goblins to drakes, your mettle will be tested and your skills put to the test.

The Music of Dragon's Dogma. -A Review-
The music in this game is wonderful. Plain and simple. From a calming melody as you walk the land in search for adventure to epic orchestral pieces for boss fights that will have you on the edge of your seat, the music has a answer for every occasion and all the thanks goes to Tadayoshi Makino, Rei Kondoh and Inon Zur!

Here is some other work these great artist have done!
Mr. Makino: http://vgmdb.net/artist/7165
Mr. Kondoh: http://vgmdb.net/artist/13
Mr. Zur: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0958735/

From Swords to Staves. -A gameplay review-
The gameplay in Dragon's Dogma is great but it does have its quirks as well. In the beginning of the game you start off as either a Fighter, a Mage or a Strider. Each one has its own unique style and as you use that class more you will unlock abilities for each Vocation" and later on you can even upgrade to a different Vocation.
The Fighter use a sword and shield and are great for soaking up damage due to the use of the shield and their abilities are based around both around offense and defense. Great for the player that wants to have a good balance of power and defense.
The Strider is the Vocation that uses a short-bow and two daggers. Their abilities are based around a nice balance of close range support and long range damage dealing. This class is great for ranged combat but can also dish out high damage at close range. This vocation is great for players that wish to dish out high DPS and hit a enemy where it hurts.
The Mage is a magick based vocation focusing on support via healing
date: buffs and enchanting your party's weapons with a multitude of elements buy using a magic staff. Not only can they support you those ways but they can also bring the pain via magick attacks in multiple forms including a LIGHTING WHIP! This vocation is great for ranged combat but for up close combat you could do better. A great vocation for players that wish to be more support focused but want to be able to do damage as well.\nThe game also includes a upgrade system for your gear which at times can become a grind fest. See
recommended: the way the system works is you will need money AND materials from monsters

Your Best Friend and Ally. -A Pawn Review-
What is a Pawn you ask? Well

reviewText:
Pros:  Capcom did an excellent job of creating the PC port
60 FPS gameplay on ultra settings, 2540x1440, on a R9 290. The game also supports 4K resolution
The music is very Japanese rock, and very much adds a heroic atmosphere to a battle
Good variety of quest and mission types, especially Ambush quests where larger than average creatures such as a Chimeras appear
A great variety of armours, weapons, and clothes to make you feel like an Arisen
The combat system, particuarly the Magick system is something I haven't seen much in RPGs. I love the sheer amount of spells and how each spell behaves (the animations are over-the-top incredible).
9 vocations to choose from: [basic] Fighter, Strider and Mage; [advanced] Warrior, Ranger and Sorcerer; [hybrid] Mystic Knight, Assassin, Magick Archer
You can have up to 2 pawns, excluding your main one. Usually you are shown pawns your own level, though you can search for higher level ones. Bear in mind, higher level pawns will cost rift crystals.The work around is if you are friends with the pawn's Arisen, you can hire the pawn for free!
Little details such as: needing a lantern to see if you travel during the night; creating heavily muscular characters can jump higher and carry more weight, something which hasn't been done much in RPGs; smaller build characters can fit into tighter spaces and move faster.
A simple and easy to understand UI
Cons:  Graphics and particular cut scenes can look outdated, though there are several mods available on Nexus Mods to improve this. ENB is a popular one at the moment: http://www.nexusmods.com/dragonsdogma/mods/searchresults/?
Voice acting isn't the best, and can take away from the moment
There isn't much in the way of a fast travelling system. You can find a handful of portcrystals in the game, and can place them anywhere, apart from caves or the likes. Having said this and taking into account the size of the map, this can be a negative if you don't like walking great distances. The positive is once you enter New Game+, you can buy portcrystals in Gran Soren for 200,000G
The story can be a little lackluster/not impact your emotions much
Conclusion: I had an absolute blast with Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen on the PS3, and with its near flawless transition onto the PC, this is a recommended game if you like a decent RPG with great music! For £23.99, it's a steal for the amount of hours you can sink into it.


Related games:  Dark Souls series
Elder Scrolls series
Dragon Age series

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying this game was originally released in 2012 for consoles.
Things like textures, particle effects, etc. have been touched up, but not completely redone.
If graphics are a huge factor for you and is going to totally kill your immersion, look at some gameplay on YouTube before purchasing.

Dragons Dogma features advanced customization of your character and is a mix between Skyrim and Dragon Age.
The game itself is extremely well done, runs well on PC and the controls for PC are well done.
There's no input lag from the keyboard / mouse, which most other ports seem to struggle with fixing.

When I originally played Dragons Dogma on the PS3 I immediately looked it up on PC, because it feels so much like a PC game.

Dragons Dogma also supports up to 150FPS and 144hz monitors, which most modern games struggle with *cough* Fallout 4 *cough*. The game also only officially supports 16:9 aspect ratios. (1920x1080, 2560x1440, etc.) You can check google for a list of 16:9 aspect ratios. Please read the FAQ on the discussion before buying.

Dragons Dogma does not officially support any mods, but Capcom has stated they will not suppress any sort of modding of the game. So, perhaps we may see some fan-made mods, regardless of how small.

If you enjoy games like Dragon Age or The Witcher, you'll enjoy Dragon's Dogma. The story is fantastic and features a unique combat system that will provide you with hours of entertainment.

reviewText:
I finished this back in 2012 on PS3 and loved it. I never played the Dark Arisen version though so I decided to buy the game again for the WinPC. I haven't regretted it 20 hours in. I'll write the review for those that have never played the game.

The good...

Presentation is good with a classic RPG feel even with a title track with classic RPG vocals. I'm playing the game on a Surface Pro 3 (SP3) and it runs well even at 720p with a mix between medium and low settings. To get a better framerate even in the 40 - 50FPS range on SP3, go with 800x600 (oh noes! lol) but turn settings up or down as desired. The game still looks good at that resolution and it allows for a better framerate with good quality even at full screen.

The combat starts off slow obviously because you're weak in the beginning. But once you start learning skills and your pawns gain experience fighting more powerful enemies, the combat is some of the best I've ever experienced.  Truly epic. It's like a faster paced, easier to get into Monster Hunter inspired system. The ability to climb enemies is well presented here and adds a extra layer of strategy to the gameplay. Using craft plays a big roll too. For instance, throwing a flask of oil onto an enemies and then using blast arrows to light nim on fire. There are options in how to tackle a battle.

The world seems limited at first with specific distinctive paths. But there is a lot to explore with quite a few instances of traveling too far away from town finding yourself lost in the dark of night with all manner of enemies creeping in the shadows. The game does a great job with day and night cycles. Bring a lantern because night time is pitch black in the dead of night. The flora and fauna, the wild life, the hills and valleys...Dragon's Dogma does a lot to convey a living breathing environment. It's not uncommon to go exploring in the countryside only to have a Chimera run up on you. Or to be ambushed by a pack of Direwolves or even fall prey to a Wraith. But the exploration is satisfying because you'll find all kinds of things tucked away among rock formations, under bridges, among trees, far out in the countryside. This is a world that deserves a sequel just for the exploration aspects alone.

Enemies are the classic RPG variety. Cyclops, Chimera, Griffins, Drakes, Dragons, Goblins, Saurons, thieves, bandits, zombies, mysterious robed figures that want you dead...etc. The AI isn't perfect for them but overall, the enemies are a geniune threat. Death comes swift for the careless. The animations are generally good and breaking off monster appendages is always satisfying.

Character creation is detailed allowing for a lot of depth in customizing your character and your pawn.

The main quest seems typical at first. Meany Dragon attacks, hero is weak but sets out to slay the meany Dragon. But it's not that simple with a great plot twist at the end that inspires at least another playthrough. The Red Dragon isn't even THE dragon in the game. The Ur Dragon is the one to see. Good luck with defeating him though lol.

Weapon and armor customizations and upgrades are generally well done. There is some grinding but it's nowhere near as bad as Monster Hunter.

The Bad

The environments can be vast with a lot of detail but there are some texture glitches I've seen and spotty draw in for various objects in the environment. Some enemies and trees will suddenly appear, Hills will shift slightly as the 3D engine gets sorted when you enter the environment.

Enemy AI can sometimes go from being incredibly stupid to incredibly intelligent in a heartbeat. One moment the Chimera, as an example, will walk into a wall and walk in place for a few seconds and then suddenly do a series of attacks that will decimate your party if you're not careful. Bandits and thieves will walk around without attacking even though you're hitting them, then suddenly, they will attack in force with archers hidden in the distance and melee fighter dealing precision hits.

Load times can be a bit slow at times

Some of the animations for the NPC can be comically weird.

There's no way to actually make camp when out in the wilds in the dead of night.

The game could have used one more town or another major city. Gran Soren is as good as it gets even though to be fair there are forts about as well as some castles and then there's the tower.

Overall Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a great action RPG game that goes a long way to give the feeling that you're in a living world that's tethering on the brink. Seeing so many NPCs and other warriors (as Pawns) out and about helps flesh out the environment too. I highly recommend the game for action RPG fans that like exploration, epic battles and watching your characters turn into monster destroying gods.

reviewText:
I have countless hours for this game on the PS3 version.
This port is phenomenally well made.

The FPS is smooth no matter what on max settings.
The graphics have been improved (though not tremendously).
The gameplay itself can be a fun challenge, though I play straight on hard mode out of the gate.
The amount of party combinations is fair though I've always felt it could use work, however this is a bit 'nitpicky'. Some dated minor animations and voice work, minor nuances.
I would say my biggest complaint would be the difficulty in customizing your pawn, however again this is a minor nitpicky concern.

All in all, if you enjoy ARPGs or if you enjoyed the original, this game is a great value.

reviewText:
Overview:
This is an easily overlooked gem. It looks like another Two Towers or Gothic, yet it is one of the most innovative RPGs I have ever played.

Pros:
- Great visual customization: gear, face and body.
- 9 classes and full control over specing buffs and abilities.
- Tactical elements with your 3 pawns.
- Boss battles are big and rewarding.
- No level scaling. You won't always win.

Cons:
- Strange console menus.
- No co-op, in a game where you share characters and have them fight with you.
- Badly presented story/lore.
- Map is small, and mostly littered by the same mobs.

Verdict:
I recommend this game to almost anyone. It's a deep hack-and-slasher RPG with plenty of unique baddies. Fun. Fun. Fun. Do you want engaging characters and a well presented narrative? Don't play this, go play Torment.

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a TPP action/adventure RPG.
Think an arcade cousin of Dark Souls with some original gameplay elements.

PROS:

+ combat
+ varied vocations(character classes)
+ pawns(your followers)
+ character and pawn customization(dozens of pieces of equipment to choose from)
+ climbing gargantuan monsters
+ quirky English translations typical for Japanese productions


CONS:

- voice acting is occasionally off
- sometimes pawns' AI is irritating
- travelling can be bothersome until you get a particular teleportation artifact


I haven't had so much fun slaying goblins, skeletons, hydras and giants in a while.
And man, there are so many ways of carrying out the executions of your foes.

Be Guts- slash your way through, wreaking havoc with a huge two-handed sword.
Be Legolas- rain volleys after volleys of arrows and shank the bad guys in their backs.
Be Merlin- call down lightning storms, summon shearing tornadoes and set the monsters ablaze.
Be anything in-between and more. And climb the huge atrocities. So good, so intense.

The pawn system is fantastic- it has a Pokemonish feel to it.
You can borrow and rate other players' pawns.
If you get bored with a particular follower(apart from you main pawn), you can always change him/her for a different one.
Your main pawn learns from adventures with you.
So, if you happen to borrow a pawn from a player who is further on in the game(or vice versa),
the pawn will provide you(or a fellow player) with valuable quest advice.
How awesome is that?


Less reading, more dragon hunting, Arisen.

Look Master! Goblins!"
"

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a 3rd person party RPG game.  You control your character and your main pawn.  Your main pawn can get used by other players including your friends on Steam.  In addition to your main pawn you have 2 sub pawns that round you out to a party of 4.  It follows the traditional rpg elements in that you want a tank, healer and damage dealer.

The game is a port of a game that came out some years back on the PS3/360 and includes its DLC.

Story/Progression: I wasn't really worrying too much about this for most of the game.  The main story is pretty short and very simple.  There are a lot of quests, some of them are good and developed and others are just typical RPG fetch quests.  You and your pawn level up at the same rate whereas your other hired 2 pawns don't level up with you, they level up in their own games (whoever created them).

Gameplay: It's a 3rd person game and you can start the game as a ranged fighter (strider) with bow/arrow, a melee tank or a mage.  There are some expanded classes as well.  The combat is a lot of fun and offers different ways to approach fights.  See that troll?  You can climb on him, attack him, climb up to his head and stab his eye.  The gameplay is a lot of fun once you get the hang of it which doesn't take too long.  The different classes offer a range of skills and let you use some cross skills as well.

Graphics/Audio: (Running an i5 with 780 graphics card and on board audio). Game ran really smooth but the graphics haven't aged greatly mostly because they weren't that great to begin with I think.  Overall for what it is, they're fine.

Overall: I had a lot of fun with this.  This game above all else does one thing better than a lot of games out there.  New Game +.  When you start NG+ you have everything from the first game, you're leveled up and you have all your awesome weapons so now you can go wreck stuff.  This is how I like NG+ to function.  If you want a challenge there is a Hard Mode and a Speed Run mode as well built INTO the game!  Would love to see more games do this.

reviewText:
This game is a real gem. The combat is intuitive, you can and will fight everything from runty goblins up to and including giant dragons. Each foe has a different skill-set and it manages to stay fresh after many, many hours. It handles well, it runs better on the PC than it ever did on the PS3 and it doesn't look half bad either. It's a must have for RPG fans and one of my favorite games of all time.

On a cooler and sillier note; I was fighting a griffon and decided to climb onto it so it can't escape, so I climbed onto a giant rock and leapt from it to the griffon's back. Naturally griffons can fly so it took off with me on its back, all was well until I lose my grip and begin what would certainly have been a fatal fall, only to be caught by my companion just before hitting the ground. She shared a few words with me and then it was back to the fighting.

TL;DR: ♥♥♥♥ing get it and play it.

reviewText:
Dragon Dogma is a fun filler game while you wait for Dark Souls 3. I've put anywhere from 200-300hours into this game on the PS3 alone years ago. And now on the PC, something around 120. I was a bit shock of how good of a port this is from consoles to PC. The keyboard and mouse do not feel out of place..... Looking at you Dark Souls.....

I recommend Dragon's Dogma: DA to anyone looking to play something a little different, but a little like DSouls+Shadow of the Colossus, than take out Souls PvP.

Pros++
++Runs great for a port. I will never touch the PS3 Version again.
++Combat, you just won't find any combat like this in another RPG at this time.
++ A bunch of armors and weapons to find.
++Very interesting character creator, Weight and Height effect things like knockdown resistance and stam regen
++Pawns, you'll need to teach your Pawn. You'll need to do some reading and really put in the effort if you want a good Pawn. Think of Pawns as Companions, but they learn and adapt. If you jump a lot in combat, they'll jump a lot, if you combat loot they'll learn to do the same
++Good amount of classes Vocations"
++Spells are beast.
++NG+
++Hard Mode
++The DLC Dark Arisen

which reminds me of Gothic games. Anything that reminds me of Gothic 1-2 is a plus in my book.

reviewText:
tl;dr: A better RPG and a better game than Witcher 3

Let's get the port crap out of the way first. DD ran like absolute ♥♥♥♥ on consoles. It chugged to keep the framerate steady even in a normal situation and if anything cool happened, it quickly became a slideshow. An awful showing for Capcom's MT Framework engine, whose perfect performance mythos became a meme for so many people who understood nothing about it.

The PC version? Smooth as butter. I can't make this game chug no matter how hard I try. Dragon's Dogma finally plays like it should.

Dragon's Dogma is a game of contradictions. It's about the times where you are battling goblins in a field only for a griffin to swoop in unexpectedly and surprise you with a boss fight, but also about the times where you are fighting goblins in a field and nothing cool happens so you walk to the next field and fight some more goblins. It's about a hero slaying a dragon and saving a colorful fantasy kingdom and at the same time it is about none of those things. It's an open world adventure and then a closed copy-paste room arena fighter. Then it thinks it's Demons Souls for a while or something.

You have not played anything like Dragon's Dogma. What DD does, nobody else comes close to. Your character, and a party of three other AI controlled characters, picked from a half dozen swords and sorcery classes, go out and wail on monsters. No, no, bear with me. This isn't some Diablo-esque clickfest or Souls-style somersaulting knight-fighter. Everything feels visceral and just right. Powerful sword swings, flurries of arrows, wizards causing giant ice spikes to slam up from the ground, the rogue climbing the monster and just stabbing like a madman at the softest spot he can find on the creature... The combat here is up there with some of Capcom's most satisfying stuff. This isn't just an RPG where you are swinging at health bars, it's a bona fide action game. Every single monster in the game gets just as much care. They all have a lot of character, are instantly recognizable, and are satisfying to fight.

The problem is, almost everything else DD does isn't even as close to as good as the core combat. The world-craft and writing are charming, with shrewd merchants, crafty plotters, busybody nobles, a secret cult, dragons, knights, the church, a mysterious witch in the woods... the theme is spot on and yet... everything comes out kinda rushed. Quests aren't highlighted at all, and you are only going to find half of the story important side quests on a normal run, if that, without a guide. Which is fine enough because almost nothing you do has any real impact by the time the ending rolls around, which I shall not spoil but to say it is almost the video game equivalent of your DM suddenly having a fit of CREATIVITY during your D&D campaign and ruining everything.

The world does not reward exploration (Which is another contradiction. In the original DD release, fast travel was not only extremely limited but quite expensive. You were expected to want to explore the world on foot. Dark Arisen's rerelease loosened the restrictions a little.). Chests and loot are everywhere, but you better be excited to find yet another flower that can craft with another flower on the opposite end of the map to make an alright healing potion that you just found in a chest anyway. Oh boy, another 30 second magic defense buff hooray.

Worse still, the leveling system is a huge part of the game, so before long you'll be leveling massive cyclops monsters in three hits, removing all the fun you used to have in those fights. High end play is almost completely busted as the class variety just sort of fades out to each class's most damaging engine. Crank it over and over and the game's toughest bosses are a joke.

Nowhere is this more obvious than Bitterblack Isle. BBI is the post-game content added into the Dark Arisen rerelease of DD, and since it is technically add-on content, the game keeps trying to tell you it's there despite every one of us playing on PC being way underleveled for anything on offer. Don't take that bait. Come back in NG+ after beating the story.

Where Dragon's Dogma reveled in the fantasy theme with a bustling medieval town and a grand overworld, BBI is just one dreary dungeon (Laughably, about half of the areas in this dungeon are copy paste and there aren't more than 15 zones total in the dungeon from entrance to exit.) filled with frightfully overleveled monsters, trying to catch on to the Demon Souls craze. Even some Souls-style just make another completely out of place knight and call it another enemy." stuff arrives. A full on loot-grind slot machine system shows up here and here alone

reviewText:
Note: Over 300 Hours play time on the Xbox 360 version:

Dragon’s Dogma Dark Arisen was an impressive game a few years ago on Xbox 360 and PS3 and so its arrival on PC is most welcome. Whilst there’s competition on the PC platform from other similar games, you’ll find a rewarding and adventurous experience here that’s well worth picking up if you’re a fan of solo action adventure role playing. With massive epic battles, free-roaming lands to explore, many days, weeks, and months of suitable challenge – all at a budget price – means this is a grand game despite its somewhat aged appearance and well worth the price of entry.

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is a game released as a console exclusive in 2012, and has finally come to PC in 2016.

It has an interesting mix between a party-based game like Dragon Age: Origins and Pillars of Eternity and a solo-adventure with potential companions such as Skyrim. In this game, you will spend the entire game with a party of 4, although you can only control your main character. Thankfully, the followers are fairly clever and enjoyable.

The combat is fun, definitely an improvement in comparison to games such as Skyrim and Kingdoms of Amalur. Boss battles feel epic - bosses have unique weaknesses, you can climb up onto the wings of a dragon and hold on as it tries to shake you off.

The class system is simple enough yet has enough different abilities for it to stay interesting for multiple playthroughs.

Took me about 25 hours to complete the game for the first time on the Normal difficulty, and I immediately went back and made a new character to play it through on Hard. Haven't completed the expansion area yet and I gather that will gain me some more hours. If you enjoy the game enough, I'd say at least 50 hours is guaranteed here.

Cons? The game only supports 1 save file at a time, though with some PC magic and mods it is easy enough to have multiple save files. The game isn't really as open world" as it might say
date: you spend most of the game following the main quests with some side quests and tasks to do on the side. I don't feel like there was a problem with this
recommended: but if you are looking for a true open world game this isn't quite the one.\n\nAdditionally this game has some end game grinding for those who want to obtain the absolute best gear
hoursPlayed: but this is completely optional and exists for the grind-obsessed folk out there so don't feel like you have to do this!\n\nOverall I rate the game a solid 8/10
voteText: it was enjoyable for many hours and a recommended pickup for any RPG fan"

reviewText:
Rating: 8/10

Great Action RPG! I was on the lookout for a decent Fantasy Action RPG after being bowled over by Skyrim, and this seems to fulfill my demands to a certain extent. I expected a huge open world with lots of enemies to kill and quests to complete. This game does indeed have a huge open world and also an array of quests to complete, but not in the way you expect.

On comparison to Skyrim, the world is lifeless. The NPC's are generic and don't have any personality whatsoever that distinguishes them from the others. The ones you get quests from are like interactive notice boards since they don't give you any other information which would give you their backstory (Though some of them tend to express their miseries at times). The quests also feel monotonous after a few hours because they are either escort quests or kill X amount of enemies.

In terms of graphical fidelity, this game is heavily outdated. Textures feel washed out and the animation doesn't ameliorate the woes either, since the developers really did a terrible job on the character lip sync.

However, even after all these problems, I love this game and feel that I've got my money's worth. Reason being, addictive gameplay and an impressive soundtrack to boot. The gameplay shields the game from being a boring, repetitive mess as the combat is unique and will keep you glued during the entirety of the game. I would however like to point out that the difficulty curve tends to be steep at points as the game throws difficult bosses at you (Especially during escort quests when the NPC is usually suicidal and likes to get near the monster to be killed at an instant). However after reaching a certain level, this problem ceases to exist. The pawn system is quite enjoyable despite the Pawn AI being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and over-talkative most of the times (Thank god there is a setting to shut them up). The soundtrack keeps the world feel alive even though there are long walks where you find no actual life.

I would certainly recommend a buy if you're looking for an Action RPG that doesn't end soon. Well worth the asking price.

reviewText:
This is my first time leaving a steam review, but I just love Dragon's Dogma too much not to. I first played Dragon's Dogma on xbox360, so while I don't have a lot of hours on the pc version, I have quite a lot of experience with the game in general. I can't really comment on the quality of the pc port because my pc is crap and can't handle it on lowest settings (like i said. crap pc) but from what I've heard from people with functioning gaming pcs, the quality is great.

Dragon's Dogma is one of my favorite games, in one of my favorite genres. It has its faults, and it took me a while to really get into it, but I think it's pros definitely outway its cons. So here's an in-depth view at different aspects of the game, with a summary at the end.

Story
At first glance the story of DD seems really basic: you're the chosen one on a quest to kill the dragon. Progress through the story and past the 'ending' though, and you find a rich and deep story. Alternate endings open for you to explore (before being taking back to the 'true' path) completely change how you view aspects of the story, further adding to it. DD also manages to incorporate common video game features such as NG+ and ai companions (refered to as 'pawns' in DD) not just into the main plot, but into its best parts. They have their own rich lore and role in the plot, and while I can't really describe what makes the story so different without spoiling large portions of the game, to me it was 100% worth the time I put into it. While there are times when the game seems to be mostly 'filler' quests that don't really add to anything, they're well worth getting through to the parts where the story is amazing. When Dragon's Dogma gets its story right, it gets it really really right. When it's lacking a bit, the other aspects of the game more than make it up for it, especially the combat.

Lore
I'm putting lore seperate from story here because of one very specific reason. While the lore surrounding the main plot of Dragon's Dogma is really really fleshed out (and part of why the story is so great) everything else is really only hinted at. You know your country has neighbors and there's complex political stuff going on, but the game doesn't give you anything beyond that. If it's not relevant to the main plot, you don't hear much about it. Whether that's good or bad really depends on how much you care about lore. On the plus side, no lore hidden in books and codex entries you end up spending 40 hours reading (looking at you bioware).

Combat
My favorite aspect of DD would have to be the combat system.

Short version: I love it so much that I don't mind going on fetch quests as long as there's combat.

Long version: It's much more fluid and I feel much more involved than I do in other 3rd person fantasy rpgs. Enemies don't scale with you and there is no auto heal so the beginning of the game is fairly difficult- accessing certain plot important areas can be difficult to nearly impossible without the proper practice and class set up. As you progress the game certain enemies become easier and easier, while new, stronger enemies take their place to keep the game interesting. Each enemy has specific tactics you need to defeat it. Some, like wolves, are easy. Others can only be harmed by specific elemental damage or in specific places on their body- and you need to figure that out (with a bit of help from your pawns). You can climb enemies and target any spot on their body. If you're fighting a cyclops- take out the eye. A large monster is holding a club- attack the hand. More difficult enemies require more detailed and well thought out strategies, keeping you on your toes the whole time.
Each of the different classes is unique and interesting, and can be switched between at any time (which in turn can be used to strategically for leveling up specfic stats). You start with three classes (called vocations), but soon get access to not only advanced classes (which are not necessarily better, e.g. only basic mages can heal, the advanced sorcerer cannot), as well as hybrid classes available only to you and not your pawns.
No scaling enemies, no auto-heal (and other healing limitations), and difficult fights make the game a real challenge, especially at first, but never unfairly so. The more you play the better you get, and not just because you begin to match the enemies level wise. As I learned when I started a new level 1 game on pc after playing to much higher levels on 360, the combat gets easier because you get better at it, and things that used to seem tough and challenging before are completely possible now. And honestly that feeling is a damn good one.

The Pawn System
The pawn system is one of the things that makes Dragon's Dogma so unique. It's tied in with the story and allows some aspect of connectivity to other players; you can recruit two additional pawns to your own for a 4-person party. Because you have hundreds of pawns to choose from, you end up being able to customize your party any way you need. Keep dying? Hire a stronger pawn. Stuck on a quest? Hire a pawn with knowledge of it. Same goes for foes and areas- pawns learn new information and tactics related to each of these, which they share with you (tis weak to fire" "wolves hunt in packs" get used to those two phrases) and implement themselves. While your main pawn never actually leaves you
date: when they 'return' from being with another player
hoursPlayed: location
voteText: or foe knowledge
helpfulPercent: as well as any items they recieved. Basically

benefiting them.

Character Creater
DD has one of the best character creators I've ever used

reviewText: Ambitious, grand, at once derivative and pioneering, Dragon's Dogma may not be a classic but it's an important title nonetheless - the first example of a blockbuster Japanese RPG attempting to marry its own heritage with contemporary Western expressions. Expectedly, coming as it does from an action game developer, its jewels are to be found in the dynamic combat, stat-tweaking party-building and defining boss battles. In this way, the game echoes the adventurous, dragon-hunting spirit of its (second- and third-hand) literary influences: that sense of unpredictable peril that could be lurking in every cave and thicket.

reviewText: With a few glaring issues (technical issues, pawn chatter, fast travel problems) cleaned up or put in players' hands, a bevvy of DLC content, and a lack of the restrictions and technical downgrades on console versions, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen on PC is perhaps the best way to play and experience the game.\nDragon's Dogma presents a vast, diverse open world with many very pleasant simulationistic elements, which tend to make the game harder in a realistic sense, as you'll always need to prepare for a journey, but as for the individual elements, for instance, nights and caves are actually dark, so you'll need a lantern to light up the darkness, but if water touches your lantern, it'll go out, and said water can also wet you, which can be exploited through ice or lightning elemental attacks to more easily shock or freeze you. I could go on about plenty of neat touches of reality in the game for an entire review, but I won't, because besides that, Dragon's Dogma has some truly visceral, genuinely fun combat, with plenty of customisation, strategy and freedom with how to tackle opponents.\nThe story is pretty boring despite an interesting overarching theme and a prolonged ending sequence that will knock you flat on your ♥♥♥♥, but Dragon's Dogma has some solid gameplay and dungeon-crawling to sink time into, especially if you're a fan of Dark Souls, Monster Hunter, and/or Elder Scrolls.

reviewText: Ambitious, grand, at once derivative and pioneering, Dragon's Dogma may not be a classic but it's an important title nonetheless - the first example of a blockbuster Japanese RPG attempting to marry its own heritage with contemporary Western expressions. Expectedly, coming as it does from an action game developer, its jewels are to be found in the dynamic combat, stat-tweaking party-building and defining boss battles. In this way, the game echoes the adventurous, dragon-hunting spirit of its (second- and third-hand) literary influences: that sense of unpredictable peril that could be lurking in every cave and thicket.

reviewText:
30 minutes in and I am very surprised at how fun this feels already.
Very glad I got this and looking forward to many hours of adventuring

Update: about a dozen hours in and it's awsome!
The best combat of any RPG I have ever played - it's just freaking awsome.
You can fly through the air and shoot while aiming your bow, then land and charge-bash your enemy. Then hurl him up though the air and flip around and send a volley of arrows up into the sky to fall in a group of other targets.The movement animations are spot on and smooth while doing all of this.
Oh baby the RPG Gods are good indeed. It will take some careful key mapping to accomplish this but when you get it sorted out you will be in heaven.

Update #2: Now i am about 30 hours into this game and it has to be said that this game features the best combat of most RPG's I have played.

It just captures the thrill of battle a bit better than other RPG's. This game was a PS3 game released in 2012 and now ported to the PC it's better than most of what the current PC games have to offer. For all that the newest Fallout 4 has to offer it does not come close to touching this game in the thrill of combat.

Dragons Dogma has got better combat than any MMO too. It's just so much fun running into a mob of enemies and thrashing the lot of them.

The story ... who cares. It's fun to follow the story but the real fun part is the combat and I just can't get enough.

reviewText:
300+ hours on the original PS3 Version before this port. 1 Complete playthrough on the PC.

This is a must have for anyones collection. From start to finish a gem and with new game+ it has near unlimited replayability.

A fantasticly crafted original world with lots of quests, some branching outcomes, and a party of Player created mind slaves! Did someone say Cannon Fodder? You guys distract that giant, scaleable monster, i'm getting outta here. Not to mention the referances to other games and anime. Even selling some of their gear from a certain hidden merchant.

The Pawn system is superb. You not only get 1 fully customizable pawn, but also access to every pawn created by other players. Not to mention they will help remind you what your suppose to be doing on quests or give you hints when your just can't remember what NPC you're suppose to be talking too. They also develp personalities based on your game play. GO COLLECT MY TREASURE, SLAVES!!

The amped up graphics look better than they did on the original release. It wasn't just some lame filter job into a port to PC. CAPCOM actually put in the work for this Port and it is noticable from the menu to the wolrd map.

So now the bad...

The game is true to the original release in which it still lacks character development in various NPCs. NPCs feel like they were strewn about, and matter in some way, but that project got left by the way side. Many of them have near to no purpose. The Dragon also chooses whom to display to you latter, but seemingly with no rhyme or reason. Threw multiple play throughs, I was shown characters I had little to no interaction with... still wondering about that...

Lastly... the Assassin is broken... YEAH I SAID IT! It's a broke OP class... I refuse to use it cause it takes away from gameplay and I cant wear my shmexy costumes with it. BALANCE THAT CLASS CAPCOM!

A must have... do it... push the purchase button, JUST DO IT!""

reviewText:
Quite possibly the best Action RPG I've played in recent memory; truly a work of art. I can best describe the gameplay as a combination of Dark Souls, Legend of Zelda, and Skyrim all rolled into one. Some may find the story a bit lackluster and the graphics aren't exactly cutting edge, but Dragon's Dogma more than makes up for it with it's engrossing combat and unique character develpment systems.

The base game is not too punishing, but if you're looking for a Dark Souls type of challenge the Dark Arisen portion of the game should more than satisfy your craving. There's also many things to keep you busy: crafting, questing, customizing your appearance, even raising npc affinity. If you love open world fantasy ARPGs, there is no reason this game should not be in your library.

10/10 would suicide again...

reviewText:
I'm sure other reviewers will go into more detail, so I'll keep it simple:

This is the single best action-RPG I've ever played, now in glorious 1080p at 60fps.
It's unforgiving, it has the best combat system you'll ever play with, and it's ridiculously fun.

Oh, and you can ignore my playtime. I've played over 400hrs and hit NG+6 or 7 on consoles.
I've finished every quest at least half a dozen times, and the only reason I EVER stopped playing it over and over was because my Peasant-Station 360 decided to die and delete my save!

What are you waiting for? Don't let your dreams be Dragon's Dogma! BUY IT! JUST BUY IT!

reviewText:
Well it's good to see a console game, albeit a very good one, coming to PC. However like its console-version, it has good/bad associated with it, which could've been improved for the PC easily. Having those issues/problems not only conjure up bad memories, but also with that the frustration that we DO NOT expect to see in a PC game. If you've seen any review for this game when it first came out on console, notably AngryJoe's video, you would not be suprised to see the same issues visible on this port. Here is the summary of what he said and what I've seen to be different from console version:

The GOOD:
- Improved gfx option
- 60+ fps
-  overall optimization
- option to shut the annoying yappers that repeat same sentences repeatedly.
- full use of multiple control setups
- comes with the artbook and music
- combat feels solid and the music and sound go well with it

The BAD:
This is where the frustration begins on several folds:
- like the original, no multiple save file options. you screwed up? Start over last checkpoint.
- you want to check your map? Press ESC, then select map option, press ENTER to use map. WHY? Is it that difficult to add a keyboard shorcut like say, M" for map
date: "Q" for quest and so on?\n- why separate the functions that pop up with ESC key from the in-game inventory menu? Remember oblivion's menu system?\n- lip does not synch with the voice
recommended:
but that's to be expected
- enemies you've killed still spawn where you killed them before


The MIDDLE:
- If you've played this game before and managed to ignore those problems
hoursPlayed: then it would be a fun experience for you. No doubt it is a great game
voteText: but that does not give us the excuse to overlook things that could've been fixed by Capcom easily. Perhaps a patch will solve it (finger crossed).\n\n- It's outdated by today's standard. But so are older classics that are still being played by us for the value they left in us. If that is not your cup of tea
helpfulPercent:
then you will not be seeing much that you haven't seen in modern RPGs.

I would recommend it to anyone who wanted to play it but could not or missed it somehow. It is far better on PC after all these years and worth adding to your library for what its worth. Just make sure you weigh in the good vs bad vs annoying aspects of the game before you decide to purchase.

reviewText: Party-based, open world exploration ala Dragons Age Inquisition with action oriented combat that cribs a bit from Shadow of the Colossus provides an incredibly satisfying gaming experience. You fill out your party of 4 with two additional Pawns

reviewText:
A decent game that leaves a lot to be desired; not from what is lacking, but the potential for improvements of what's currently presented.

I consider the main appeal of the game being the AI companions that can learn and be trained to an extent. Their inclination stats which influences their behavior is important to attend to since counterproductive behaviors are possible. I felt the inclinations has both placed some interesting constraints on playing, yet some restrictions to what I would've done to prevent some bad habits imparting to the pawn. Compared to average game AI, they're smarter and more capable than average, but still bound to make some stupid mistakes. Unconventionally, the whole deal with character building in RPGs, I ended up paying more attention to customizing the main pawn than the player character.

Mostly, each class has a weakness to be covered by companions. I.e physical damage only classes while there are monsters vulnerable only to magic, or being grabbed by an enemy and needing a teammate to the rescue. However the AI companions, really depending how well trained, can be unreliable for some situations; worst case I can remember is Metal Golems and archers not attacking the floating medallions when I needed them to.

Another appeal is the attention to detail in non-generic ways. Examples, heads actually regrowing on a hydra- delayed by burning the wound. Character weight being a factor in weighing down or being carried off by a flighted monster. Counterfeited quest items can have some fun results later on and in other quests.

My first playthrough, I felt the challenge was fair. Later on NG+, the challenge expires as the enemies don't scale. Even for Hard Mode recontinuing after completing the game, the only thing noticeable is the greater XP and Gold rewards. Ultimately at a high level, one area in the game remains as an appropriate place where the player isn't overpowered for, and even then some of the bosses are leaning towards the easy side. The story gets questionable at first sometimes, but it turns out to be consistent.

Expectations     Dragon May Cry: The RPG, considering the director and team behind it. There's some similarities, but a lot of the character's effectiveness relies on stats and equipment because of the way damage is calculated. I felt the countering attacks and dodging was quite easy and the timing required was lenient.    Other Opinions    For the RPG aspect, I felt the means of upgrading equipment and character were simplistic. For the action, only 6 skills per weapon (3 if Warrior) loadout were limiting.
Inventory items shared the same icons in an annoying way.
The game only has one save slot for a character, I'm mostly fine with it since a lot of character details (like appearance, class, augments) can be changed without starting over.    Experience     Played the game on Normal the first time. Then for NG+ switched the game difficulty to Hard.
Most played vocations are Assassin and Mystic Knight; played the least of Sorceror and Mage. Had some fun with Magick Archer, but I didn't like magic bows skills as much I did the regular ones because of the lock-on and target tracking.

reviewText:
At this point, Dragons Dogma is probably my favorite game of all time.  The combat is phenomenal, and definitely lives up to the hype.  The skill system, classes, and gear have significant depth and are well done.  The pawn concept is also really well done.

The story is very bare-boned, and there isn't much in the way of character development.  But, the mythology and storyline does have some interesting twists, so its actually solid...just not a deep narrative.

The monsters are also fantastic D&D inspired types, but I do wish there was some randomizing of spawns in the world.  Also, the game sometimes feels a bit empty (only two real towns).

The key for me is that this game is just so FUN to play.  If they could just get everything from DD into a world the size of Skyrim, I would probably never play another game.

reviewText:
Review partially based on hundreds of hours in both PS3 releases.

The dark fantasy ARPG ruled the seventh console generation, Demon's Souls the crown jewel of a new, unforgiving niche. Many others followed in its wake, though none were able to fully match its finely-tuned balance and difficulty or otherworldly mystique.

Then came Dragon's Dogma, late spring, 2012, a new project from some of Capcom's brightest talents.

I had no idea what to expect the day this game came in the mail, expectations low coming off the heart-wrenching disappointment of Dark Souls. What I got was this: desolate solitude in a visually stunning, base infusion of Monster Hunter and Shadow of the Colossus, polished to perfection, offset by what was and still is one of the most brilliant and impressive A.I. companion systems I have ever seen.

It was a needed breath of fresh air, one that ceased to leave my PlayStation 3 for many months to come. The Dark Arisen rerelease only added to the pleasure, addressing minor complaints while significantly adding to the already high replay value with Bitterblack Isle, a punishing, seemingly endless dungeon crawl -- risk versus reward at its finest.

Belated as it might be, this PC conversion is amongst the best ports Capcom has ever done, fabulously optimized and fully integrated into Steamworks right from the get-go; I would have sufficed with simply being able to play the game at a higher framerate (Dragon's Dogma pushed the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 *well* past their limits), but the addition of significantly increased distant LOD, higher resolution textures and improved post-processing are more than welcome additions to an already excellent game.

That's not to say it's entirely free from error; side quest progression is as annoying as it always was, guaranteed to push new players to reroll over canceled objectives. If that doesn't do it, then configuring one's pawn will, one of several gameplay mechanics that requires planning and foresight for best results. Dragon's Dogma has never held hands -- online reading is a must when it comes to the likes of crafting consumables or pawn inclination and personality.

While some have derided the game for the above issues (and still do), I've always found myself torn in a different direction: this is a significantly misunderstood ARPG, forward-thinking and made with a lot of heart, qualities that, for me, outweigh its small missteps, no matter what they might be.

reviewText:
I played Dragon's Dogma on PS3 and I absolutely loved it. It was my GOTY in 2012 without any contest whatsoever.

I can't praise this game enough. For me it was the type of game that affects you profoundly, that sets you in a different mood, a wonderful mood, and makes you crave and think about the game when you're not actually playing it, but just living your ordinary life. In short, it has an atmospheric and exciting world, superb combat, it feels original, innovative and intelligent, and just lovely in every way.


EDIT: game works perfectly now! Not sure what fixed it, but right now I'm guessing my old gamepad wasn't compatible. I disconnected it and then deleted the games' config file, then ran in Win 7 mode.

[I just started the game a moment ago and for the first time ever with a new release I'm having technical problems (must have been lucky). The game has extreme lag. Fraps says 25fps but I can see that the animations run at only 5 frames per second or less. Unplayable. And I can't access the Option menu, it just blinks back (it seems to have been auto-set to highest settings). My GPU is an AMD Radeon R9 290, so it might be a compatibility issue we've seen with AMD products before (I love AMD though and it's not neccessarily their fault).

Don't let my technical problems scare you from contemplating a purchase of this fantastic, glorious and epic game. I am sure this will be fixed with a patch soon.]

reviewText:
A few problems, particularly graphically, and a rare crash, but I'm surprised at how well this port turned out, with some real effort put into the UI to aid PC players. The game as of the latest patch is running fairly well for me, and I'm having a blast with it.

The environments are particular design standouts, with attention given to realistic biomes, plus immersive audio, though not any real weather effects that I've seen so far. Combat is nice, but I find spellcasting aiming difficult. I play with an XBox One controller. Lots of nearly useless stuff to pick up makes this self-confessed Junk Looter very happy. Writing is OK; dialogue is less than OK. Pawn system is interesting. Bethesda could actually learn a thing or two from this title, and Capcom can learn a thing or two from Bethesda in turn.

I wonder what the mid and end game will feel like. I'm afraid grinding may become necessary and too much of a chore. But right now I'm happy to come back to this title for hours on end. Oh, just a note. In order to make travel less annoying, when you start a new game for the first time, it's actually like NG+ apparently, with an eternal ferry stone, and some of the dialogue you hear may be NG+ dialogue (such as Selene's opening dialogue, perhaps?)

Capcom, you've come a long way from your Resident Evil 4 port. I pray you will continue to respect and develop your PC audience. They want to play your great games. Give them all the chances you can. I hope your success here will one day bring a Dragon's Dogma sequel to PC.

reviewText: 3/10 story, 9/10 gameplay.  This games felt a little like Dark Souls with a mix of some other titles.  Not nearly as punishing, but still very rewarding.  Combat felt pretty smooth as I played a melee class.  I had started as a mage, but it felt a little clunky for me so I started over.  Low and behold, you dont actually need to start over if you dont like a class.  The game allows to to adjust throughout it.  So you never really feel cuffed by your choices.  Great monsters, great loot system, lots to see and do and replayability.  Had I been a console gamer, this would have been a solid pick up.  Thankfully they brought this to PC or I would have missed out on a great RPG experience.

reviewText:
A fast paced action game for casual, hardcore players with mild RPG elements. 10/10

What's in the world of Gransys?
- You, as a heartless Arisen, go on a journey to find a heart, keeping a lookout for hot waifu materials to gift a ring to
- You trek through dungeons finding superior equipments or materials for enhancing your current equiments to take on tougher enemies
- You do sidequests by finding stuff people are looking for or escorting NPC from town to a specific tourist location
- You choose to hire 2 pawns built by capcom or other players to help you complete the game and improve your own pawn as veteran pawns teaches you how to deal with certain enemies
- You go to forum, interact and add friends who are active to use their party member and get them to also use yours to gain a type of currency at a faster pace and improve your pawn's knowledge by travelling with them
- You go to Dragon dogma's wiki to figure out why you don't have certain material and what enemy to slay for it
- You collect all manners of clothing to fashion you and your pawn to make them look different from others
- You beat up a townsman or date a married nobelwoman and get jailed for it
- You cross-dress, go to the barber shop just to convince another tribe to gain you special priviledge and access
- You travel in both day and night with the choice of whether to bring a lantern along
- You slay weak enemies to gain more skill points to improve your skills and strong enemies to gain more experience points
- You take on the online Ur-dragon and compete with others for the kill

Difficulty of the game?
Casual - Easy/ Normal mode with 4 party members and curatives
Experienced - Hard mode with 4 party members and curatives, enemies partially slain
'Prepare to die'  - Hard mode solo, limited curatives (maybe 15 herbs that work like Ashen Flasks?) no picking up herbs or chest for curatives, all enemies slain, no item buffs, no lantern, no arrow

What's in the combat?
- Perfect block (parry)
- Dodge
- Launch (skills that elevates party members or yourself in the air to fight airborne enemies or escape slaughter house)
- Climb (scale the beast, show them who is the boss)
- Invisibility skill (unnoticed deals double damage, no backstab in this game)
- Mild stealth elements (hitting one enemy of the mob draws everything to you, no hiding one corner and sniping everyone)
- Headshot (double damage on hitting their brains) and arrow is unlimited
- Double jump and levitation
- Consumable damage items (Bombs, scrolls alike)
- Physical/ magic immune enemies
- Bar fights (You can grab flame barrels, pawns, crates and throw at enemies)
- Restrain techniques (You can submission hold a monster while your pawns slit their throat)
- Conjure a tornado, meteor shower, avalanche (This is a good example of spells done right)

What's in the Dark Arisen expansion aka Bitterblack Isle?
- Randomized enemy encounter
- OP weapon/ armour in the dungeon to remove the need to min/max
- Finding macabre sculptures (this will test how well you explore dungeons)
- Gears which alter your existing skills and Bloody Nails that make unarmed combat viable

Verdict?
This game is a compilation of Shadow of Colossus, Monster Hunter, Resident Evil, Devil May Cry mechanics, nowhere else will you find titles like this which is daring enough to add so many elements to gameplay. I played this because of the same feel it gave me from Dungeon/Dragons Shadow of Mystara. I rotted my childhood away at video arcades to 4man co-op with my classmates.
I've listed how to make the game harder and definitely the hardest game I've played. Difficulty is exactly how difficult you want the game to be. The storyline is short and predicatable, if looking for a great storyline then this will disappoint. The sound effect, music, spells, combat has nothing to disappoint. They are great for the price considering you don't need to buy Dragon Dogma and Dark Arisen as with console release in separate prices. The port is great, constant 55-60FPS on Win10, 980Ti, full gamepad support on LogitechF710. No broken server connection on 100Mbps.
10/10, I love the challenge-runs. The community is awesome too, real helpful.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma : Dark Arisen

You beat Dark Souls 1, 2 and SoTFS. You miss Monster Hunter? Well Dragons Dogma is a nice mix of the two and a damned good game/port besides!

Out of the gate you have access to all the DLC that was released with the game, that means the extra voice packs, hair, armor, weapons, etc. You also have access to Bitter Black Isle which i suggest waiting to visit for anyone new to the series as it is ten fold harder than the base game at a low level.

Pros: (there are a lot here)

The port has been vastly upgraded from its original ps3 debut. It supports 4k upscaling and runs at 60fps or higher if your monitor can do so.

The fighting is smooth and fluid.

Many weapons, classes and enemies to fight. There is even a very dark night cycle that may scare you at first. Especially when you see the glowing eyes of a Chimera off in the distance just staring at you.

There is a lot of customizing for those of you that love making your characters look unique in game and during character creation.

The game itself is solid and while the story is not the best you really play for well the challenge as the game boasts a hard mode plus a new game plus mode that adds a lot of replayability. Not only that but there is a second cylce after you originally beat the story which causes the game to rehase enemies making them new versions of themselves. Much harder and they will chew you up and spit you out.

Cons:

None that i can think of except from a port standpoint which is it doesnt support wide screen monitors or super wide screen so keep that in mind.

also the J-pop song is not the title song as the original game had due to licensing issues but with mods i think that will change soon!

Overall the game itself is great. Im horrible at writing reviews, but i can whole heartedly recommend this to anyone that loves high fantasy and a bit of a challenge. Always carry a lantern and a bit of oil.

TO ALL THE OTHER GAME PUBLISHERS MAKING ♥♥♥♥ PORTS AND KILLING OFF GOOD IPS TAKE A LOOK AT CAPCOM BECAUSE THEY ARE GONNA WALK TO THE BANK WITH THIS PORT!

Thank you Capcom for bringing this game to the PC and if you do decide on another installment of the Dragon's Dogma series, please consider a PC release as well!

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I am a PS3 owner of both the base game and the Dark Arisen expandalone re-release, and yes, I am again on the PC. I'm that big a fan :)

Arguably the better dragon-slaying game during the time of Skyrim's release, finally on PC, and finally in its well-deserved 60FPS+. A hidden shining gem from CAPCOM that wholly deserves a look, and is certainly deserving a position in any action RPGer's library. My personal console GOTY 2012-2013 :)
+ The game is finally in its deserved 60FPS+(uncappable), instead of the barely 30FPS stutteryness on the consoles, and its a joy of motion all around!

+ Consistent world design gives each location found in the game, major or minor, its own feel and gameplay, combined with a day-night cycle that changes the entire mood and difficulty as well.

+ Solid sound direction that sounds right, when its right, how its right, supported by fitting, masterfully delivered background music.

+ Expansive character creation that is more extensive than its competitor, Skyrim, with ensuing gameplay effects based on character weight. Heavier, larger characters burn and regenerate Stamina slower, can carry more, can grapple more effectively, but at cost of being bigger in hitbox, having trouble climbing onto a larger enemy, and opposite is true for lighter, smaller characters.

+ Unique Pawn system that becomes your shadow throughout your adventures, assisting and learning from you, and are the main presense you have online, with other Arisen online can hire your Pawn for their own adventures, akin to a card trading game. Pawns are smart in combat, and informative outside of combat. Well-trained Pawns can become the crux that turns the tide during difficult times.

+ Devil-in-the-details game mechanics one usually gets from a Japanese developer. Flask of oil thrown at the enemy coats them in oil, a debilitation, and makes them weak to fire. Getting wet makes you weak to lightning. Need to grapple a small enemy to open it for a partymate? Go for it! Need to climb a large enemy to get at its weak point to strike for massive damage? You can do that too!

+ Combat is very well animated akin to the flashy combat of Devil May Cry's own series of games, and as such it constantly looks interesting and fitting for the situation. Magic is finally given its due in this regard, beautifully animated and powerfully impactful, which gives weight to the fact that these are powerful spells at their fingertips.

+ Lengthy play similar to the length and size of Oblivion/Skyrim, on your first playthrough. Then you finish the game, and the rabbit hole goes deeper. Then you finish the game. Then you start the next with New Game Plus and learn even more. Then you try Dark Arisen content...

+ Decisively Japanese take on a Western-based fantasy genre setting, complete with lore that goes above and beyond the game's borders, both in-universe, and out.

+ Dark Arisen expansion content is for the dedicated player who wishes to master the heights of the game, learn more from the lore, and gain the best of loot and skill, easily another 50% to a very lengthy game.

==========

- Its a game from 2012, and even with the 1080p/60FPS+ support on top of reworked textures, upscaled fidelity, and the lot, its still obviously an HD rework re-release of a 2012 game on PC, even with the uncompressed textures. Chief issue here is the pop-in distances for NPC's and entities is still laughably short, and can be very noticeable.

- Missing the real title theme song of Dragon's Dogma (B'z - Into Free [Dangan]), shamefully so.

- The original game's incessant voice prompts for the Pawns became one of the main complaints of the game, and it can be again with the PC port, if you do not switch that off in Options or actively train your Pawn to be more quiet.

- As well voice-acted the game is, lip sync outside of cutscenes is haphazardly silly.

- Difficulty can run the gamut from challenging, to obfuscatingly difficult. Hard Mode for first-timers is not recommended. Requires a modicum of player skill and dedication to progress. Save points are few and far between, and can be punishingly far from one's destination.

- Story is very plain at first glance, without any overruling drive for the player other than reclaiming the heart of the Arisen from the Dragon. Story only opens up after the defeat of the Dragon.

- Dark Arisen expansion content is easily unlocked when the player is arguably not yet ready, and thusly can lead players into a spiky cliff of difficulty. Doesnt help the lore for Dark Arisen assumes you have completed the base game and thusly wont make sense to newcomers.

reviewText: Really can't recommend this game enough, for $30 it's an absolute steal. It's a bit slow at the beginning but once you get to the first city it takes off. reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma : Dark Arisen

You beat Dark Souls 1, 2 and SoTFS. You miss Monster Hunter? Well Dragons Dogma is a nice mix of the two and a damned good game/port besides!

Out of the gate you have access to all the DLC that was released with the game, that means the extra voice packs, hair, armor, weapons, etc. You also have access to Bitter Black Isle which i suggest waiting to visit for anyone new to the series as it is ten fold harder than the base game at a low level.

Pros: (there are a lot here)

The port has been vastly upgraded from its original ps3 debut. It supports 4k upscaling and runs at 60fps or higher if your monitor can do so.

The fighting is smooth and fluid.

Many weapons, classes and enemies to fight. There is even a very dark night cycle that may scare you at first. Especially when you see the glowing eyes of a Chimera off in the distance just staring at you.

There is a lot of customizing for those of you that love making your characters look unique in game and during character creation.

The game itself is solid and while the story is not the best you really play for well the challenge as the game boasts a hard mode plus a new game plus mode that adds a lot of replayability. Not only that but there is a second cylce after you originally beat the story which causes the game to rehase enemies making them new versions of themselves. Much harder and they will chew you up and spit you out.

Cons:

None that i can think of except from a port standpoint which is it doesnt support wide screen monitors or super wide screen so keep that in mind.

also the J-pop song is not the title song as the original game had due to licensing issues but with mods i think that will change soon!

Overall the game itself is great. Im horrible at writing reviews, but i can whole heartedly recommend this to anyone that loves high fantasy and a bit of a challenge. Always carry a lantern and a bit of oil.

TO ALL THE OTHER GAME PUBLISHERS MAKING ♥♥♥♥ PORTS AND KILLING OFF GOOD IPS TAKE A LOOK AT CAPCOM BECAUSE THEY ARE GONNA WALK TO THE BANK WITH THIS PORT!

Thank you Capcom for bringing this game to the PC and if you do decide on another installment of the Dragon's Dogma series, please consider a PC release as well!

reviewText:
First off,a huge thanks to capcom for listening to us to bring this great game to the PC platform even though they are late to it but however they did it and results were paid off great.

Now,i'm gonna keep this review simple with a pro and cons format as i don't really want to write an essay because i really want to go back in there and play this.

Pros
+PC port
+Pretty good optimized (Rarely drops fps and even if it does,doesn't drop too much)
+Combat mechanic is so epic and fun
+Story is....good but nothing mind blowing though
+Improved from 30 fps (console PS3/360) to unlimited fps or can cap to 60 fps
+FOV options (i love this)
+Controls is suprisingly good and comfortable at least for me on keyboard and mouse ( i have not tried out controllers yet but should be good)
+ Pawn system is unique and i love it
+Extremely huge world probably about the size of skyrim or even bigger
+tons of content such as quest,armors,loot,etc
+Challenging game
+1080p to 4K resolution support
+Being able to romance any NPC in the world

Cons
- A.I pawns are sometimes dumb such as going straight into enemy attacks and get killed
- some NPC have some path finding issues such as walking into a wall or a log and never goes around it
-Some frustrating moments with the end game content  (such as melee class players like warrior cannot reach a certain enemy in the everfall but has to rely on climbing and then attack and repeat for minutes or hours)
-The Font in the menus are unpolish such as being blurry

The final verdict for this port is a 8/10. It's a great port made by capcom and i highly recommend to get this game.

To simplify all things, it's basically Shadow of the Colossus,Devil May Cry,Elder Scroll,Mass Effect,Dark Souls and Monster Hunter all had group sex and gave birth to a baby called Dragons Dogma.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I am a PS3 owner of both the base game and the Dark Arisen expandalone re-release, and yes, I am again on the PC. I'm that big a fan :)

Arguably the better dragon-slaying game during the time of Skyrim's release, finally on PC, and finally in its well-deserved 60FPS+. A hidden shining gem from CAPCOM that wholly deserves a look, and is certainly deserving a position in any action RPGer's library. My personal console GOTY 2012-2013 :)
+ The game is finally in its deserved 60FPS+(uncappable), instead of the barely 30FPS stutteryness on the consoles, and its a joy of motion all around!

+ Consistent world design gives each location found in the game, major or minor, its own feel and gameplay, combined with a day-night cycle that changes the entire mood and difficulty as well.

+ Solid sound direction that sounds right, when its right, how its right, supported by fitting, masterfully delivered background music.

+ Expansive character creation that is more extensive than its competitor, Skyrim, with ensuing gameplay effects based on character weight. Heavier, larger characters burn and regenerate Stamina slower, can carry more, can grapple more effectively, but at cost of being bigger in hitbox, having trouble climbing onto a larger enemy, and opposite is true for lighter, smaller characters.

+ Unique Pawn system that becomes your shadow throughout your adventures, assisting and learning from you, and are the main presense you have online, with other Arisen online can hire your Pawn for their own adventures, akin to a card trading game. Pawns are smart in combat, and informative outside of combat. Well-trained Pawns can become the crux that turns the tide during difficult times.

+ Devil-in-the-details game mechanics one usually gets from a Japanese developer. Flask of oil thrown at the enemy coats them in oil, a debilitation, and makes them weak to fire. Getting wet makes you weak to lightning. Need to grapple a small enemy to open it for a partymate? Go for it! Need to climb a large enemy to get at its weak point to strike for massive damage? You can do that too!

+ Combat is very well animated akin to the flashy combat of Devil May Cry's own series of games, and as such it constantly looks interesting and fitting for the situation. Magic is finally given its due in this regard, beautifully animated and powerfully impactful, which gives weight to the fact that these are powerful spells at their fingertips.

+ Lengthy play similar to the length and size of Oblivion/Skyrim, on your first playthrough. Then you finish the game, and the rabbit hole goes deeper. Then you finish the game. Then you start the next with New Game Plus and learn even more. Then you try Dark Arisen content...

+ Decisively Japanese take on a Western-based fantasy genre setting, complete with lore that goes above and beyond the game's borders, both in-universe, and out.

+ Dark Arisen expansion content is for the dedicated player who wishes to master the heights of the game, learn more from the lore, and gain the best of loot and skill, easily another 50% to a very lengthy game.

==========

- Its a game from 2012, and even with the 1080p/60FPS+ support on top of reworked textures, upscaled fidelity, and the lot, its still obviously an HD rework re-release of a 2012 game on PC, even with the uncompressed textures. Chief issue here is the pop-in distances for NPC's and entities is still laughably short, and can be very noticeable.

- Missing the real title theme song of Dragon's Dogma (B'z - Into Free [Dangan]), shamefully so.

- The original game's incessant voice prompts for the Pawns became one of the main complaints of the game, and it can be again with the PC port, if you do not switch that off in Options or actively train your Pawn to be more quiet.

- As well voice-acted the game is, lip sync outside of cutscenes is haphazardly silly.

- Difficulty can run the gamut from challenging, to obfuscatingly difficult. Hard Mode for first-timers is not recommended. Requires a modicum of player skill and dedication to progress. Save points are few and far between, and can be punishingly far from one's destination.

- Story is very plain at first glance, without any overruling drive for the player other than reclaiming the heart of the Arisen from the Dragon. Story only opens up after the defeat of the Dragon.

- Dark Arisen expansion content is easily unlocked when the player is arguably not yet ready, and thusly can lead players into a spiky cliff of difficulty. Doesnt help the lore for Dark Arisen assumes you have completed the base game and thusly wont make sense to newcomers.

reviewText:
EDIT: So, I just found my eternal ferrystone in the inn storage. Scratch the gripe about limited fast travel, this game just went from gold to platinum, in my book.

The age of the game might be showing in its graphical assets and some gameplay design choices might seem like they don't belong in a modern game, but if you can live with that, this game offers a very enjoyable adventure. The battle system is fun and action packed. Especially entertaining is the massive mountable boss battles, which IMO put even God of War to shame. The classes (vocations) are varied and even offer skills that'll help you traverse the world and explore it's hidden corners.
The story is neglible at best and you can feel the age, but it still des enough to set it apart from a lot of other popular RPG's, offering engaging gameplay and a lot of character customization.

I have over 200 hours on the PS3 version and plan on going over that with this version. I don't feel like writing a huge review for a game that came out last gen but I will throw my two cents into the ring, which hasn't changed from the PS3/360 version.

Pros
+ Decently sized world
+ Interesting classes
+ Interesting story
+ Fighting large monsters is fun

Cons

- Could have had a larger variety of monsters

I wont talk about the end game since I never actually played Dark Arisen so I have no experience with it. I've just made 20 or so runs through the original game. I understand Capcom cut a bunch from the game. I really hope it gets a sequel or that we at least get the MMO over here.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic port, the game runs so fluid I feel like a senechal up in the heavens with a new smug reason to look down on consoles for butchering its potential.
Coming from hundreds of hours of playtime on the 360, I was so hyped up to hear about the PC port and the wait was truly worth it.

Dragon's Dogma is a game that feels very D&D inspired and the art style feels like Tolkien had a hand in it. The Dark Arisen expansion blew my mind with its new zone, Bitterblack Isle. It seemed to burrow a bit from the Souls atmosphere but improved the overall soundtrack and featured its own lore and storyline which overall is fantastic. The early game can feel very slow paced at times, but getting to this content is well worth the effort.

We also got the fabled infinite ferrystone, some new costumes and plenty of new hairstyles and such for those dressup lovers. There's no doubt about it, the character customization is quite strong with this one. And it's all here on the PC port! No 10k RC, though. Ugh. Once you beat the game you can buy the infinite scroll to recustomize as much as you want! Dressup lovers rejoice!
Dragon's Dogma qualifies as one of those Flawed but awesome" types of games
date:
not everything is perfect but if you can look past what isn't so great you'll really find yourself immersed in this game with hundreds of hours ready to blow. It's totally worth the money.

So what's awesome?
The combat is fantastic
recommended: and steers away from some of those other mindless button masher "ARPGs" out there.\nBosses actually have mechanics. Chimera kicking your bum? Grab on to his goat head and cut it off preventing those annoying spells. Cyclops throwing his club around? Burn it out of his hand or paralyze him with lightning! Gryphon not landing? Throw a goblin corpse down or something similar and bring that jerk down
hoursPlayed:
latching on to him and eviserating his entrails as he tries to take off.

The classes are really fun and really offers a load of different playstyles to the RPG lovers.
The entire world and most of the items in it have their own innate properties which really adds a whole new layer of detail to the game. You can throw oil at enemies to make them take more fire damage
