reviewText:
SHORT REVIEW

PROS:

Incredible character customization
One of the best combat gameplay of the last generation
Pawns bring a unique and interesting charm unlike any other game of its kind
Very good soundtrack
Great boss fights
Bitterblack Isle offers extra challenge after main game
Monster hunting and exploration is fun
Hybrid classes
Cool magic spells and abilites


CONS:
Dated textures
Pop ins
Poor story up until the end
Bad camera on dragon fights
Uninteresting quests
Pawns A.I. could still use some tweaking
One save file
Poor explanation on certain features such as the knowledge chair
Awful romance system

Long version

Dragon's Dogma was one of my all time favorite games to come out last gen and is in my top 5 best games i have ever played. It is a flawed gem but a gem nevertheless.

You play as the Arisen, a fisherman/woman in the small town of Cassirdis when a dragon comes and raids the village. In your attempt to defend the village the Dragon steals your heart and choses you as the hero to go out and stop its destruction of your country Gransys.

As the Arisen you are able to command a mercenary race known as Pawns from the Rift Stone. Pawns are created characters that everyone can make and share with each other along the world. While having actual co-op would have been nice the pawn system is an interesting idea and adds charm to your game especially if you find a group of well made pawns with great skills, augments, armor, weapons, inclinations, and most importanty personality.

I named my pawn Chuckles an arrogant lanky Gentleman Bandit" with a deep voicewho frequently say that fighting ogres
hoursPlayed: and zombies was a waste of time and rob people along the path to Gran Soren
voteText: shot a bandit captian off a cliff. manage to push a bloody GORECHIMERA off a cliff to its demise with the help of another pawn named HANZ. robbed orphans of their meager money from a fountain in Gran Soren
helpfulPercent: and mocked a certain cousin of the Arisen who kept fainting on his doomed adventure to Witchwood\n\nAnd that was just for the 360 version
votesHelpful: this time on PC he tried to stab a merchant i was escorting simply because she was picking up money on the road.\n\nAnd this is one of the biggest reasons why i love this game
votesTotal:
Chuckles and my other friends pawns would always be entertaining to watch how their A.I would react and the Pawns can be really interesting IF YOU PUT THE EFFORT INTO MAKING THEM INTERESTING.

I strongly recommend new players to take their pawn to the knowledge chairs in either Cassidis or Gran Soren as these chairs allow to

1. Tell your pawn to shut up if you hate their chatter
2. Change how they act in combat (You don't want your mage acting like a warrior for example)
3. Change their personality (I've lost count how many Pawns just shout out STRENGTH IN NUMBERS ARISEN
votesFunny: DID IT!
commentsCount:
WE HAVE TRIUMPH) in battle it quickly gets old.

Once you have your party set up you then can head to Gran Soren and begin your adventure as mostly everything is unlocked for you by the time you get to Gran Soren.

You can then pick better classes for your pawns such as Ranger
column16: Sorcerer
column17: and Warrior while the Arisen gets hybrid classes such as Magick Archer
column18: Assassin
column19:
and Mystic Knight

By this point the story hits a dead end and basically stalls for you by finding missions the duke wants you to do while waiting to find the dragon even though its pretty obivious where it is.

Exploration is pretty fun and the world feels big there's alot of monster variety some of which i usually don't see in RPGs and oh boy is it satisfying to find one of the bigger monsters in the game like cyclops
column20: chimeras
column21: golems
column22:
and of course dragons.

You can climb up on to the larger monsters to get to their weakpoints similar to Shadow of the Colossus though they won't make it easy. Dragon's in particular can be a real pain to fight as the camera has trouble when near their weakpoint and tends to flip out making an already challenging fight frustrating at times.

The game has a surprising amount of depth to its gameplay with a large amount of status effects that can be applied to your character and the enemy with plenty of healing items in the game. Monsters tend to be more difficult at night and not having the proper equipment will spell failure for your party among your treks through the world of Gransys
column23: \n\nNow there are sone major issues with the game that can be deal breakers for some of you. One of the biggest ones is the story is rather bad until the end and the side quests usually are not very good. This is espcially true for the notice board missions which are mostly filler quests like escort missions
column24: fetch quests
column25: collect X amouint of this item and the like you've seen in so many other RPGs.\n\nThe game also has romancable characters in the game and you can probably guess who a few of them are
column26: your childhood friend Quina
column27: The captian Mercedes
column28:
The Princess Aelinore and while yes they are romancable inculing unique scenes for them. There is something darker in this game's romance system

What the game doesn't tell you is that EVERYONE is romancable. This is due to affinity which naturally builds just taking to someone let alone doing quests for that person. So what can happen is say you want to romance Mercedes okay you are doing her route and its getting near the end of the game. You want to rest up and manage your items before you go off to fight the Dragon. Well now Mercedes isn't your love interest anymore its the innkeeper of Gran Soren and there is no way to change it by that point. So remember  if someone is in love with you KILL THEM OFF lest you have the creepy midget jester as your damsel in distress.

Now you're actually getting two games on this PC port as Dark Arisen comes with its expansion into Bitterblack Isle. Bitterblack Isle is alot of fun to explore especially if you're a Dark Souls fan as its overall style and tougher challenge and monsters remind me of that franchise

I recommend being at least around level 50-60 on your first run through Bitterblack Isle. The second run however is a whole nother story as the main boss gets a huge difficulty spike and overall the monsters are much tougher this time around.

Bitterblack expands on some of the Arisen and Pawn backstory and offers two new NPC's and a bunch of cool loot and dark morbid locations to explore. This also has some of the best music in the game and is overall a very nice additon to the game for mulitple playthroughs

Overall i very much love this game. Yes its got some major issues but ultimately they don't outweigh the good unique experience Dragon's Dogma has to offer. I believe their is potential for there to be a heavy contender for best RPG able to compete with the Elder Scrolls

This game a strong following for those who played it and i know many would love to see a Dragon''s Dogma 2 or a Western release of Dragon's Dogma Online though most would prefer Dragon's Dogma 2 instead with co-op and having their pawns as well

Final verdict 7 out of 10 overall by my personal enjoyment out of the game is a 9 out of 10

Go and buy it!

reviewText: Easily my favourite PS3/360 era game. Combines Oblivion exploration with Dark Souls-ish control, while adding grappling and over the top skills. reviewText:
I'm running down a spiral dungeon and I come across a big troll like thing hiding behind some pillars.  After zapping it with a few arrows which don't seem to be doing much good, my minions are bashing it with their swords and spells, but I feel like I can do more, so I leap at it and cling onto its back and start digging my daggars into its neck.  It stumbles towards the edge of a deep drop and falls, with me still on its back to the floor below, cushioning my blow and killing the beast.  I hop off and run into the middle where a stone is waiting to be plucked from the ground, but as I do the room fills with giant tentacles and I have to run for it as there's no hope of staying in here alive for long.  As I head around the corner I come to a room full of tombs, with a treasure room at the end.  I can't get through the door, but there's a hole in the wall so I start pushing the lids off the tombs and from one a skeletal figure emerges.  We fight him for a minute of two and eventually down him at which point he drops a lever which fits into the wall and opens the door.  I plunder the treasure, run back into the tentacle room and blast hell for leather up the spiral passageway for what seems like an age, dodging more tentacles that are spring up in my path, but I can only run for so long without pausing for breath and I make it to the top just as my stamina runs out and I stumble out of the dungeon.  And that's just one short experience in the first couple of hours.

Holy crap this is a good game.  Imagine Skyrim with waaaaaaaaay better combat, better levelling and professions, better loot, deeper, more expansive dungeons, and you've basically imagined Dragon's Dogma.

I can't believe this one passed me by during the previous gen console era, but in some ways, I'm glad it did because I get to enjoy this fantastic HD port for PCs.  Capcom have done an excellent job on this - it flies along at a superb, stutter free framerate on my GTX970.  At the price it's an absolute steal.  I've barely been able to put the controller down since buying it, and I feel like I'm only just getting started.

Very very very recommended.

By far a better game than the two games mentioned above and also on, in my humble opinion, a level playing field with the likes The Witcher 3 and even a step above RPG's like Dragon's Age: Inquisition and Fallout 4, this game is most definitely worthy of your time and money, again in my opinion.

reviewText:
I'm running down a spiral dungeon and I come across a big troll like thing hiding behind some pillars.  After zapping it with a few arrows which don't seem to be doing much good, my minions are bashing it with their swords and spells, but I feel like I can do more, so I leap at it and cling onto its back and start digging my daggars into its neck.  It stumbles towards the edge of a deep drop and falls, with me still on its back to the floor below, cushioning my blow and killing the beast.  I hop off and run into the middle where a stone is waiting to be plucked from the ground, but as I do the room fills with giant tentacles and I have to run for it as there's no hope of staying in here alive for long.  As I head around the corner I come to a room full of tombs, with a treasure room at the end.  I can't get through the door, but there's a hole in the wall so I start pushing the lids off the tombs and from one a skeletal figure emerges.  We fight him for a minute of two and eventually down him at which point he drops a lever which fits into the wall and opens the door.  I plunder the treasure, run back into the tentacle room and blast hell for leather up the spiral passageway for what seems like an age, dodging more tentacles that are spring up in my path, but I can only run for so long without pausing for breath and I make it to the top just as my stamina runs out and I stumble out of the dungeon.  And that's just one short experience in the first couple of hours.

Holy crap this is a good game.  Imagine Skyrim with waaaaaaaaay better combat, better levelling and professions, better loot, deeper, more expansive dungeons, and you've basically imagined Dragon's Dogma.

I can't believe this one passed me by during the previous gen console era, but in some ways, I'm glad it did because I get to enjoy this fantastic HD port for PCs.  Capcom have done an excellent job on this - it flies along at a superb, stutter free framerate on my GTX970.  At the price it's an absolute steal.  I've barely been able to put the controller down since buying it, and I feel like I'm only just getting started.

Very very very recommended.

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is a fantastic game.

Seriously.

It doesn't have the deepest or most interesting story, but the world, creatures, and combat are just so well done that no matter what you're doing in the game it feels fun. There's plenty of classes to choose from to fit your style, and you can swap between them just about whenever you'd like. It's also one of the only games that does magic right for a mage.

My only regret is it's not really multiplayer, but the pawn system does a pretty good job of making adventuring feel less lonely.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely fantastic. Sure, there are a few issues with the UI, and the story is, while interesting, is not the best,  the combat is absolutely amazing; it borrows elements from all sorts of RPGs, from Skyrim to Dark souls and Monster Hunter. Nothing more satisfying than fighting a cyclops near a cliffside and slowly pushing it off the cliff to its death, would rate 8/8.

The pawn (companion) system is also amazing and is unique: you create and customise your own main pawn and they are sent out onto the rift for other players to borrow and use. While they are being borrowed, they can gain knowledge on quests, travelling in areas and most importantly, knowledge of how to defeat types of monsters, while also earning currency! You can also hire two other pawns, either offline from those within the game or other players' main pawns.

Class customisation and specialisation is also quite flexible: you can start in one of three basic classes (fighter, ranger and mage) and branch out into specialisations of those classes or hybrid classes which effectively combine elements of two classes together. The system allows for min/max if you wish or simply just experimenting and having fun with the different classes (as the slight cost of unoptimised stat growth).

All in all, that's all I have to say about it for now and I would definitely recommend buying it based on what I've completed so far. It truly is a breath of fresh air as a combat-focused open-world rpg in recent years.

reviewText:
The best action RPG in recent memory. I played Fallout 4, it bored me to tears from halfway through..I just couldn't handle it.
Played all 3 Witchers. Somehow it just doesn't click with me.
The Dragon Age series turned into a dating simulator. The first one was the best.
Tried a few more, the Divinity held my attention for a while, but just couldn't leave me wanting more.
Dark Souls is a dying simulator (didn't play 2 or 3, I just think they aren't worth $60+ )
Dragon's Dogma may start slow (almost stopped playing after an hour) , but it only gets better.  Fine, it can get repetative, but the respawning enemies on walked roads is there to hone your skills. Plus the PC version has the enternal crystal, which grants you fast traveling if you don't want to hack and slash through your way to your next destination.
This is a game, that makes me want to play day after day .
I hope Capcom is working on a sequel, tailored for PCs from the start.  Capcom knows what gameplay is, they are well known to make great console games for decades now. They have the know-how,  I wouldn't mind if they'd start shaming the PC giants (Bioware, Bethesda), they certainly capable.

reviewText:
So far it's a great game. The combat is the best i have ever seen in RPG or any other game especially with the big creatures.
The fighting is (cinematic) in a way that one climbs on to the creatures and attacks them there is no QTE it's all real time player controlled combat, this is the way i expect good next gen games to do Monster combat from now on instead of ankle slashing combat like Elder Scrolls and Witcher still use.

The character customization is great and it is much better than other games i have played.

Tho it's not all good there are some unnesessary problems with the game the biggest one is the awful save system.
You only have ONE save file for the entire game, it is stupid and makes no sense. To fix the save system you have to disable steam cloud for the game and manually copy and backup the save file from steam userdata location everytime you want to save the current savefile to your own location for later use.

Other big problem is you cannot edit your character after the game starts, yes there are two buyable artefacts that can do it but they cost a big load of ingame crystals and the other one is only available after the game is finished this is  dumb and over complicated mechanic. Just put the customization options in to the barber shop and dont make things over complicated for no reason.

Third problem is there is no normal fast travel system in the game there is some kind of weird fast travel buyable stone system that you have to drop in the travel points, again why so simple game mechanic needs to be over complicated especially as there is no mounts so traveling by running is very slow and becomes boring very quickly with the quickly respawning enemies.

Overall it's a really good game and i'm glad it found it's way to pc, the pc port is pretty decent no huge problems with it and i think the price at 30 euros is a fair amount as it includes all the dlc for the game.

reviewText:
Edit: I originally wrote this review 50 hours in, I've recently crossed the 120 mark and have some more insight to offer.


Dragons Dogma: Dark Arisen is one of the most surprising new PC ports that I've ever had the pleasure of sitting down to play the entirety of the 35 hour from beginning to finish. If you've found yourself enjoying long hours of exploration in games like Skrim, Dragin Age, and Fallout then this will suit your fancy. But where the greater bulk of the adventure in those games relies on objective markers and sad babysitting fetch quests to fill-in content to make you feel like its a full experience, DA puts you right there in fray of the situation-whether it be a puzzle or a tricky enemy without much of an explanation. What I mean by this is that the tutorials are either absetn or out right none existant. This both good and bad because the game's mechanics are plenty strong enough to hold up with out an explanation. Still though, a little hand holding would be nice for the noobies I suppose. Spend two hours figuring out that all you needed to do was pull the lever or turn the game off, no one gives a ♥♥♥♥.

There's far too much to explain in full detail to convince you why you should pick up this game, but I suppose I should start with the replayability.

Its there. Its really, really there. In Dragons Dogma you have a choice between 9 different vocations (Playstyles) that all include the Fighter, Mage, Strider, Sorcerer, Ranger, Warrior, Mystic Knight, Magic Archer, and Assassin. Each of these classes has various skills and augments that are awarded to you after a certain amount of time of usage with each class. Each one has a specific focus in combat and each one has a severe weakness opposed to the other classes.

For example the Mage vocation specializes in healing and buffing team mates, while sorcerer focuses on offense spells and buffing allies. There's a hundred different ways to build a main character, and even more ways to do it for a pawn.  Each vocation has a max rank of about 10 and after each level up in that vocation your given more skills to master, which will turn you into a better fighter.

These skills can be mapped to the controller (Or keyboards) quick memory button so you can use an array of different skills in battle. At any time you can customize the placement of each skill, and can even keep certain core abilities even if you've switched an entirely different class. Not only this, but you can customize your pawns appearance and skillset as well, opening up the game to so many friggen posibilities of Pawn and Arisen combination its crazy. Owing to the many categories and variety of vocation, you can switch to all of these classes at any time, no need to start a new game and waste more time playing what you don't wanna. On top of the level 200 cap (It takes dozens of hours to even get to rank 50.), you can also do new game plus for some revived carnage and character building.

It should also be mentioned that some of these vocations combines the best of each class into one for some even better character making. For example, the first three vocations are strider, fighter, and mage. Their advanced classes basically super charge what they already did well, but the final three vocations specialize in combing the essense of all three forms of combat into one (Magic, Endurance, and Mellee Work). The Magic Archer is just that-a guy/girl with a bow and a staff.

Weird combos. Totally  worth it when you find a class thats just for you.

What really gives you the idea that the game intends on you to repeat it is the mistakes it allows you to make for not doing enough in certain quests or not going the extra mile for pleasing certain people. For example I had an oppurtunity to babysit someone's overpriveleged kid and because I didn't adhere to ALL of her blasphemous tasks, I barely got good enough weapons and armor as a direct result of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t bronze Idol she gave me (The highest grade was gold). So you gotta pay attention and really give a ♥♥♥♥ about the NPCs (I'm not just talking about listening either, dude. You really have to follow the little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and not bump into her when she wants to race. Get her water. All that ♥♥♥♥. Totally unrelated to monster hunting. Only way to get the best gear the post main game.)

Very replayable game.

The combat is monster hunter with more open world stuff added to it to make the game comparable to games like Skyrim. Its realistic and everything has weight and momentum. Don't attack too much without a block or counter plan. Learn the ins and outs of combat as soon as you can and really have fun with the different styles of movement.

Trust me, I am.

I used to run with a Strider on New Game plus to get all my core augments and I'm learning some awesome things about that class such as its double jump ability and faster arrow pull on the short bow. Its also capable of climbing up and around monsters faster than anypone else so thats cool. The speed and precision make this character pefect for close to longer range combat both with a bow and with daggers.

I now run with an Assassin build with Gale Harness (Wind magic that buffs speed 20%), Master Kill, and Thousand Bites. This class has become my all time favorite because unlike the others it combines great ranged abilities with fantastic close range abilities not to mention great mobility with double jump and evade with the dagger ability. On that note, ranged weaponry in this game is fantastic.

Can't stress that enough. They really put thought and time into both magic and bow and arrow ranged attacks.

You'll feel as satisfied fighting a gang of bandits as you do fighting a cyclops and both enemies have secrets and tricks to easily being beaten. For example just blind the ♥♥♥♥ out of the Cyclops with arrows. Easy win. The enemies arent' always easy though and frankly require practice and style to bring down. This isn't a simple swing and kill scenario-the monsters can down you with one swipe of their claws or talons. There are also giant Chimeras, Griffins, Cyclops demons, and don't forget the 10 headed snake demon.

Tread at your own peril. Do not run into the fight with your balls hanging out and always maintain an everwatchful eye in the dark.

All in all, there's too much I think to explain why you should get this game. But above all I think the combat and replayability of the story are great points. The third and strongest point would be that its great fun creating your own character and pawn to compliment each other on the battlefield.

reviewText:
This is the third time I've bought this game and it's honestly one of the best games I've ever played.

The world is shallow, the voice acting will drive you to insanity with its repitition and half the quests are escort/kill quests. But the game probably has the most satisfying gameplay in the world. In no other game will you have so many different playstyles depending on your class.

Fighting a Griffin, for example.

If you're a warrior plant some bait on the ground, the second the Griffin lands slam your 6ft long greatsword into its skull and cleave it asunder. If you're a magick archer, shoot it out the sky with fire arrows and watch it crash into the ground swathed in flames. If you're an assassin bring it down with bait, then climb onto its back and hack away at it as it flies a hundred feet into the air trying to shake you off. Or if you're a sorcer just calling down a gigantic ♥♥♥♥ing meteor shower to flatten it, or trap it in a huge maelstrom that it can't escape.

The choice is yours. My favourite game of 2012, 2013 and will probably be 2016 as well.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game simply is amazing. I played the original game on PS3 and can't even begin to count how many hours I spent traveling through the world, herding enemies with my group of carefully selected pawns and collecting stuff I never need but still want to find cause that's how the Arisen rolls. It's not Skyrim, it's not Dark Souls, it's not another dull JRPG and most of all it's not a derivative of anything you can find out there. The closest I'm able to come up with is what would happen if Golden Sun and Dark Souls had a love child. And that would be pretty unique und hard to imagine, wouldn't it?

And why yes, this game is. I call it a fully fledged multi-companion action RPG with some platformable passages, an actual difference between day and night, tunables classes/AI for most of your companions and a massively open world. Gameplay wise, you'll find many similarities to JRPGs but presented in a way where situational awareness and skill choices play the most important roles. Hard to find something comparable! Kind of like Brütal Legend and it's squad command system. And tiny bit of Pokemon.

But don't expect any Hollywood type storytelling. The game is rather subtle with a necessity to explore the depths of things on your own. There will be no handholding, no obvious solutions and no spotlights telling you where to go. Plus, the main story doesn't make much sense until you're two thirds into it. BUT! That's also kind of the beauty since it gives you enough room to live in this wondrous world of yore. Japanese ideas of european medieval yore, that is - talking about boob plates and armor sexism.

Anyway, as many other people already pointed out before me, this is a very well-done PC port. It's faithful to the original visuals and works just as smooth as you'd expect from something that's been around a while. Plus, they got rid of the rather annoying title screen J-Rock theme which never contrasted well with the game's actual music. Highly recommend! In fact, there's naught to loose by buying it right now while it's hot and steamy.

reviewText: This barely-coherent, ♥♥♥♥ed-up mess of a game is the most fun an RPG has ever been. The combat feels great, all of the classes are useful and cool, climbing on monsters and stabbing the ♥♥♥♥ out of them never gets old, and there's just enough cool weird ♥♥♥♥ in the garbled fever dream haze of what this game calls storytelling to make the whole experience really interesting and unique. It's a flawed gem to be sure, but that's part of the appeal. Besides, it's the closest any of these open world fantasy RPGs has ever come to realizing the character action dream, and that counts for something god damn it.

reviewText:
Thank you so much, Capcom, for this flawless PC port without DRM (besides Steam).

This game makes use of the videogame medium like no other. Games are replayable, social, and explorable. Dragon's Dogma utilizes these idiosyncrasies perfectly in awesome fun game filled with thrilling combat, lore, and humor.

ReplayabilityMost games include New Game+ as an extra, but Dragon's Dogma’s story is ideally experienced in an infinite cycle. If you like to make the most effective character, make interesting characters, collect all the fashion items, unlock all the crafting recipes, pursue your one true Beloved, or just analyze a rich story and setting, you will replay the game many times. Initially, bandits will be nearly impossible to fight, but your character will be mowing through them before NG+. However, there will be a few challenges even after a NG+ or two in the main campaign. Bitterblack Isle and the Ur-Dragon, however, will be challenging, even at max level. Nothing besides your personal ability stops you from entering any area or facing anything, though, so feel free to prove me wrong by defeating Daimon before level 15!

Limited Social InteractionThis is a single-player game with online connectivity. (Off-line with pre-made pawns is always an option.) Dragon's Dogma encourages a cooperative community for us to share our skills, experience, and creativity without directly speaking. As the Arisen, you will have complete control over the development of one fully-customizable party member known as a Pawn. It will fight by your side, learn techniques from you via a complex AI system presented through Inclinations and Bestiary Knowledge, and automatically be hireable for RC by other players to benefit from your training. If that other player shows your Pawn a new strategy, it will bring the new information home to share with you! The Pawn system also allows for reviewing with helpful/humorous preset comments and trading via gifts. This way, you can actually earn recognition for the Utilitarian/Challenge pawn with a Triple-Dragonforged Delta Guard you poured days into building. You can also see other players’ amazing (or mostly shoddy) work. We all kind of play together as a community to achieve the same goals, which I find really sweet.

ExplorationThere are hundreds of hours of exploration. I’m still learning things after hundreds of hours across platforms! The map is big and extends far beyond the scope of the story. It also has a lot of hidden verticality for the platforming fanatic. The From a Different Sky quests really highlight this feature through a (frustratingly) fun minigame. If you like lore and story, Dragon’s Dogma has an inexhaustible amount of lore to investigate. The setting of Gransys has a rich history, evidenced in the variances of architecture, quest and NPC dialogue, and the costumes of the other Arisens. The characters are all interdependent and political. Many people accuse the game of having minimal story. It’s true that the main story line dialogue is mostly to-the-point about you being an undead hero of prophecy come to rid the land of an ancient dragon (or just run some errands for the Duke who wishes to delay you at all costs). However, dig deeper into their motivations and relationships, and there is definitely an amazing story.


Awesome Fun to Play
Combat in Line with Monster Hunter or Dark Souls
Also, the combat is actually fun. In a lot of games, I sludge through combat, waiting for more story. The combat is something of a story, though. Today, my Arisen oiled the wings of a Griffon with arrows, and grasped onto its legs as it lifted from the ground to flee. Holding on for dear life as the Griffon was gaining altitude, my Arisen gained a firm grip and drove fiery daggers into the beast’s flesh until both its wings were set ablaze. She rode the burning griffon to the ground where her pawns finished it off. I was so scared the whole time that I’d lose my grip. That wasn’t even a quest, just a random encounter! I'm not going to lie, though. Those random quick-time events were so much easier on the PS3.

The Most Quotable Game
The dialogue is all so well-written. After hearing the pawns yell “STRIKE THE TAIL!” in battle and watching your favorite cutscenes—“MY TALISMAN.. MY RING..”—thirty times, you will be quoting DD:DA with the rest of us. Unstinting
date:
you say?"

Romance!
Dragon’s Dogma subverts the Damsel in Distress cliché in a hilarious way. The Arisen can be male or female
recommended: and the “damsel” can be nearly any NPC in the game. By any
hoursPlayed: I mean you can seriously accidently get married to gross old men
voteText: already married women
helpfulPercent: and children. The game keeps track of your “affinity” with all NPCs
votesHelpful: which is affected by given gifts and interactions. There are tricks to getting who you want
votesTotal:
but something always seems to go wrong and you end up with Fournival or Caxton as your Beloved (mega ew). It's a hilarious feature that lends some anticipation and mystery to the climax cutscene.

Ridiculous People
The characters are as ridiculous as the dialogue. The cast includes a foreign rich girl who pretends to be a knight
votesFunny: an overly flirtacious girl who opens a shop with access to an exclusive master weaponsmith through unreturned favors
commentsCount: a villager who pretends to be an adventurer only to die along the easiest paths (voiced by Vic Mignogna no less! haha!)
column16: a rarity trader who frequents the local counterfeiter
column17: the dreamy Night’s Champion
column18: and so many others.\n\nIn short
column19: buy this game immediately. You are missing out every second you don't!"

reviewText: One of the best modern RPG. While some parts could use a lot of improvement, such as climbing, the pawns in itself and especially the UI, the game is more than the sum of it's parts. You can easily lose yourself for hours in this game while exploring, building your character or just enjoying the vistas the game has to offer.\n\nDefinitive recommendation from me, especially if you like playing as a spellcaster since the way spells are done in this game is very unique in terms of effect and presentation.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Dragons Dogma feels sort of like Skyrim and Dark Souls combined to make a Walking Simulater, so pretty much its just awesome 11/10

Being serious, this is a really fun game, at least what I have played of it so far. I am just playing on Normal Mode, and it doesn't feel extremely hard to the point that I get overly frustrated, nor do I find it too easy. I never played the original game on PS3 or Xbox 360, but I still wanted to get this as it looked like a really good game. From what I have experienced so far, there are only a few things that I think could have been better.

1) When you do the normal run, not sprinting, you move extremely slowly.
2) When you actually sprint, it drains your Stamina ridiculously fast.
3) There is no roll or quickstep feature, which I find to limit me in combat because I do not use a shield and can't block, I either have to jump and sprint away from the enemies attacks which puts me out of the action, or just let them hit me.

However I do want to say that the devs did a great job in porting this from console. It runs on 60fps, smooth as applebutter without any frame drops. Maybe if they had done a better job with the graphics that would have been even better, but I don't really mind that much, at least it isn't such I problem that I can't play.

Whether or not you played the original, I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys Action RPG's, or Open World exploration games.

EDIT: The slow walking is because of how many items you are carrying and your overall weight because of said items.
The fast stamina drain is because of the size of my character and that determining his endurance.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: This game is a ♥♥♥♥ing time hole. Level 70 27 hours in on my 4th Hard Mode playthrough. DLC and endgame go together nicely. Well worth 30 dollars. Make sure to put down portcrystals at key locations around your playthrough so that the nect time you go through you can shave off all the walking and 2/3rds of the time spent. Theres an Eternal Ferrystone some people forget about in your storage when you go to Gran Soren. Make sure to choose the right inclinations, look at stat growths, check out all the classes.\n\nI've spent 600 hours on this game for Xbox 360 and I do not regret one second of playtime.

voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma's best features are two parts. First, it's combat, the second, it's pawn system. Both unique to Dragon's Dogma alone.

What drew me into the game was when I first scaled a giant monster and start swinging attacks at it's head while holding for dear life. Though you won't be doing this all the time, it certainly is a combat feature that stands out. When fighting smaller mobs, the combat plays out similar to games like Dark Souls or Monster Hunter. You'll be using the learned combat skills and spells that you've acquired to wreck havoc on enemies that stands in your way. These skills will drain your stamina bar, so managing regular attacks and special attacks will be key to your survival. The combat overall is very player skill based, but has all the pre-planning of equipment and skill management that people have come to love about RPGs.

The ally system, or Pawn" system of the game is especially interesting. You create your own Pawn
hoursPlayed: and you'll be able to level it up while setting up it's skills to compliment your desired party make up. The interesting part of this is
voteText: that Pawn you designed will be uploaded into the game's server and exported into other people's games. Other players will then hire it and will bring back treasures given to it back into your game
helpfulPercent: as well as knowledge of quests completed in other people's games. You of course
votesHelpful: will also be able to hire other people's pawns into your game. This passive online feature helps create a connection to the greater world of Dragon's Dogma. It's one of the game's most unique features

one of it's best.

Oh look, 30 bandits..
Casts Maelstrom
Watches all 30 bandits fly in the air being tossed around
All my pawns admire me while wearing silk lingerie
Best game ever 10/10

This game makes your sorcerer spells FEEL LIKE THEY SHOULD.  No joke.  Definitely a game I am taking my time in because I don't want the epic times to end just yet.

reviewText:
I've been waiting for this game to come out since it was first released on last-gen consoles.I had no hope that it would come out on PC but it happened.Thus i'm writing this review.


When i first started the game,despite my Souls experience and also Bloodborn experience,i felt so uncomfortable and unfamiliar with the surroundings and i had a hard time finding what to do in quests and what's my role in this universe,i even had to start over after 1.5 hours of playthrough just to clarify the question marks in my head.

My first 5 - 6 hours had been a struggle,it took me so long to learn that i had an infinite source of fast travel,and how to use the port crystals efficiently.I had to step by the community hub several times just to see if people are also struggling like me or if i'm the only ♥♥♥♥♥♥.I read some topics where people who played the game in console said like Game gets good halfway through the story" and it was actually true.

After i gained complete knowledge on what to do
date: game felt much more enjoyable.I read the whole chronicle at some point
recommended: and the story felt also more in depth.I'm a Psychology Student and studying Philosophy as part of my major
hoursPlayed: the Philosophical touch in this game is quite impressive

reviewText:
Had this game when it came out in 2012. Wasn't sure how I felt about it at first, but within my first hour of gameplay I'd fallen in love with it. The gameplay is excellent, it's got a pretty decent story [People may challenge that one], a lot of post-story content to deal with, and it can prove quite challenging at times. I've been saying this game should come out on PC for 3 and a half years, finally got my wish

It's basically Skyrim meets Monster Hunter.

PC port is very well optimised, runs in 60FPS and 4k.

If you buy it, have fun!

reviewText:
Triple dipped on this game, no regrets.

Dragon's Dogma is a brilliant and fun RPG, where wolves hunt in packs and they hate fire.

It's also important to note that you SHOULD NOT go into this game thinking it's a Souls"-like. Many people made this mistake and their disappointment from the expectation hinders them from enjoying the game fully.

All in all
date: this is an amazing PC port of a fun 4-year-old ARPG cult classic which gameplay aged well to this day."

reviewText:
Great game, ported from consoles (good port)

It's sort of what you'd get if you mix Monster Hunter and Dark Souls. Japanese developed western dark fantasy inspired game with great action combat and good amount of character development/customization. Has some asyncronous multiplayer components to it that are pretty neat.

If you want an RPG with pretty heavy focus on the combat and it's mechanics then this is a pretty safe bet. Perfectly viable to play with keyboard and mouse or just about any gamepad, comes down to preference.

reviewText:
Better than any rpg I have played in years. Not better graphics, not better story but better gameplay and a true RPG experience.

Pros - Heavy RPG elements, open world, progression feels natural as does world.

Cons - Looks pretty awful. (Yet doesn't always. Just proves better graphics don't always mean more immersion. IN fact I prefer first peson games for immersion but this game has some great immersive elements.)

I can't quite put my finger on it yet but this game is unique and very special IMHO. Not perfect but I can't quit playing it. I own Fallout 4, Witcher 3, GTA V etc. and this is the game I want to play. It makes me think of Dungeons and Dragons for some reason - I don't know what I am saying, except everyone should give this game a chance. Kinda feels like Dragon Age Origins with better mechanics and actually fun to play, just doesn't look as good.

EDIT: It's the small things, like the world being just big enough for the lack of fast travel and difficulty spikes early on. Wolves attempting to roll in the grass to put out a fire if you set them ablaze. Only being able to tell if night is coming by the light in the sky, position of the sun and the ambient sounds in the game, For one thing, the graphics are NOT bad, just really show their age but the sound design is amazing. I see so many things the witcher 3 and DA:O get credit for, but really it's lifted from this game, or seems that way. I just CAN'T STOP PLAYING rhis game, I may need help.

reviewText:
Dragons Dogma feels sort of like Skyrim and Dark Souls combined to make a Walking Simulater, so pretty much its just awesome 11/10

Being serious, this is a really fun game, at least what I have played of it so far. I am just playing on Normal Mode, and it doesn't feel extremely hard to the point that I get overly frustrated, nor do I find it too easy. I never played the original game on PS3 or Xbox 360, but I still wanted to get this as it looked like a really good game. From what I have experienced so far, there are only a few things that I think could have been better.

1) When you do the normal run, not sprinting, you move extremely slowly.
2) When you actually sprint, it drains your Stamina ridiculously fast.
3) There is no roll or quickstep feature, which I find to limit me in combat because I do not use a shield and can't block, I either have to jump and sprint away from the enemies attacks which puts me out of the action, or just let them hit me.

However I do want to say that the devs did a great job in porting this from console. It runs on 60fps, smooth as applebutter without any frame drops. Maybe if they had done a better job with the graphics that would have been even better, but I don't really mind that much, at least it isn't such I problem that I can't play.

Whether or not you played the original, I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys Action RPG's, or Open World exploration games.

EDIT: The slow walking is because of how many items you are carrying and your overall weight because of said items.
The fast stamina drain is because of the size of my character and that determining his endurance.

reviewText:
Thank you so much, Capcom, for this flawless PC port without DRM (besides Steam).

This game makes use of the videogame medium like no other. Games are replayable, social, and explorable. Dragon's Dogma utilizes these idiosyncrasies perfectly in awesome fun game filled with thrilling combat, lore, and humor.

ReplayabilityMost games include New Game+ as an extra, but Dragon's Dogma’s story is ideally experienced in an infinite cycle. If you like to make the most effective character, make interesting characters, collect all the fashion items, unlock all the crafting recipes, pursue your one true Beloved, or just analyze a rich story and setting, you will replay the game many times. Initially, bandits will be nearly impossible to fight, but your character will be mowing through them before NG+. However, there will be a few challenges even after a NG+ or two in the main campaign. Bitterblack Isle and the Ur-Dragon, however, will be challenging, even at max level. Nothing besides your personal ability stops you from entering any area or facing anything, though, so feel free to prove me wrong by defeating Daimon before level 15!

Limited Social InteractionThis is a single-player game with online connectivity. (Off-line with pre-made pawns is always an option.) Dragon's Dogma encourages a cooperative community for us to share our skills, experience, and creativity without directly speaking. As the Arisen, you will have complete control over the development of one fully-customizable party member known as a Pawn. It will fight by your side, learn techniques from you via a complex AI system presented through Inclinations and Bestiary Knowledge, and automatically be hireable for RC by other players to benefit from your training. If that other player shows your Pawn a new strategy, it will bring the new information home to share with you! The Pawn system also allows for reviewing with helpful/humorous preset comments and trading via gifts. This way, you can actually earn recognition for the Utilitarian/Challenge pawn with a Triple-Dragonforged Delta Guard you poured days into building. You can also see other players’ amazing (or mostly shoddy) work. We all kind of play together as a community to achieve the same goals, which I find really sweet.

ExplorationThere are hundreds of hours of exploration. I’m still learning things after hundreds of hours across platforms! The map is big and extends far beyond the scope of the story. It also has a lot of hidden verticality for the platforming fanatic. The From a Different Sky quests really highlight this feature through a (frustratingly) fun minigame. If you like lore and story, Dragon’s Dogma has an inexhaustible amount of lore to investigate. The setting of Gransys has a rich history, evidenced in the variances of architecture, quest and NPC dialogue, and the costumes of the other Arisens. The characters are all interdependent and political. Many people accuse the game of having minimal story. It’s true that the main story line dialogue is mostly to-the-point about you being an undead hero of prophecy come to rid the land of an ancient dragon (or just run some errands for the Duke who wishes to delay you at all costs). However, dig deeper into their motivations and relationships, and there is definitely an amazing story.


Awesome Fun to Play
Combat in Line with Monster Hunter or Dark Souls
Also, the combat is actually fun. In a lot of games, I sludge through combat, waiting for more story. The combat is something of a story, though. Today, my Arisen oiled the wings of a Griffon with arrows, and grasped onto its legs as it lifted from the ground to flee. Holding on for dear life as the Griffon was gaining altitude, my Arisen gained a firm grip and drove fiery daggers into the beast’s flesh until both its wings were set ablaze. She rode the burning griffon to the ground where her pawns finished it off. I was so scared the whole time that I’d lose my grip. That wasn’t even a quest, just a random encounter! I'm not going to lie, though. Those random quick-time events were so much easier on the PS3.

The Most Quotable Game
The dialogue is all so well-written. After hearing the pawns yell “STRIKE THE TAIL!” in battle and watching your favorite cutscenes—“MY TALISMAN.. MY RING..”—thirty times, you will be quoting DD:DA with the rest of us. Unstinting
date:
you say?"

Romance!
Dragon’s Dogma subverts the Damsel in Distress cliché in a hilarious way. The Arisen can be male or female
recommended: and the “damsel” can be nearly any NPC in the game. By any
hoursPlayed: I mean you can seriously accidently get married to gross old men
voteText: already married women
helpfulPercent: and children. The game keeps track of your “affinity” with all NPCs
votesHelpful: which is affected by given gifts and interactions. There are tricks to getting who you want
votesTotal:
but something always seems to go wrong and you end up with Fournival or Caxton as your Beloved (mega ew). It's a hilarious feature that lends some anticipation and mystery to the climax cutscene.

Ridiculous People
The characters are as ridiculous as the dialogue. The cast includes a foreign rich girl who pretends to be a knight
votesFunny: an overly flirtacious girl who opens a shop with access to an exclusive master weaponsmith through unreturned favors
commentsCount: a villager who pretends to be an adventurer only to die along the easiest paths (voiced by Vic Mignogna no less! haha!)
column16: a rarity trader who frequents the local counterfeiter
column17: the dreamy Night’s Champion
column18: and so many others.\n\nIn short
column19: buy this game immediately. You are missing out every second you don't!"

reviewText:
This game simply is amazing. I played the original game on PS3 and can't even begin to count how many hours I spent traveling through the world, herding enemies with my group of carefully selected pawns and collecting stuff I never need but still want to find cause that's how the Arisen rolls. It's not Skyrim, it's not Dark Souls, it's not another dull JRPG and most of all it's not a derivative of anything you can find out there. The closest I'm able to come up with is what would happen if Golden Sun and Dark Souls had a love child. And that would be pretty unique und hard to imagine, wouldn't it?

And why yes, this game is. I call it a fully fledged multi-companion action RPG with some platformable passages, an actual difference between day and night, tunables classes/AI for most of your companions and a massively open world. Gameplay wise, you'll find many similarities to JRPGs but presented in a way where situational awareness and skill choices play the most important roles. Hard to find something comparable! Kind of like Brütal Legend and it's squad command system. And tiny bit of Pokemon.

But don't expect any Hollywood type storytelling. The game is rather subtle with a necessity to explore the depths of things on your own. There will be no handholding, no obvious solutions and no spotlights telling you where to go. Plus, the main story doesn't make much sense until you're two thirds into it. BUT! That's also kind of the beauty since it gives you enough room to live in this wondrous world of yore. Japanese ideas of european medieval yore, that is - talking about boob plates and armor sexism.

Anyway, as many other people already pointed out before me, this is a very well-done PC port. It's faithful to the original visuals and works just as smooth as you'd expect from something that's been around a while. Plus, they got rid of the rather annoying title screen J-Rock theme which never contrasted well with the game's actual music. Highly recommend! In fact, there's naught to loose by buying it right now while it's hot and steamy.

reviewText: This barely-coherent, ♥♥♥♥ed-up mess of a game is the most fun an RPG has ever been. The combat feels great, all of the classes are useful and cool, climbing on monsters and stabbing the ♥♥♥♥ out of them never gets old, and there's just enough cool weird ♥♥♥♥ in the garbled fever dream haze of what this game calls storytelling to make the whole experience really interesting and unique. It's a flawed gem to be sure, but that's part of the appeal. Besides, it's the closest any of these open world fantasy RPGs has ever come to realizing the character action dream, and that counts for something god damn it.

reviewText:
I was only 9 years old

I loved Dragon's Dogma so much, I had all of the soundtrack and artwork

I pray to Capcom every night before bed, thanking them for the game they have made.

“Dragon's Dogma is love” I say. “Dragon's Dogma is life”

My dad hears me and calls me a nerd

I knew he was just jealous of my obsession to Dragon's Dogma

I called him a fat cyclops

He shuts off my computer and sends me to go to sleep

Im crying now, and my face hurts

I lay in bed and its as cold as Rook's frazil spell

A cold breeze moves towards me

I feel something touch me

Its Rook

I am so happy

He whispers into my ear “Our fealty is sworn to you, Arisen.”

He grabs my laptop with his powerful Pawn hands and opens up Dragon's Dogma

I’m ready

I go to summon more Pawns for Rook

He changes the search to only mage

The search results suck, but i do it for Rook

I start tearing as I see wolves in the wilderness

I start mashing X

I want to please Rook

He casts a mighty spell as he sees the wolves

My dad walks in as the fight starts

Rook looks him straight in the eyes and says. “Wolves hunt in packs”

Rook leaves through my window

Dragon's Dogma is love, Dragon's Dogma is Life.

reviewText:
Monster Hunter X Shadow of the Colossus in an open world with ridiculously good character customization

PROS:
>very well optimized
>combat works surprisingly well with mouse and keyboard and is often better than controller
>fun combat with some very distinct classes
>climbing on big bosses to get to weak points is fantastic
>extremely high quality character customization
>pawn system lets you make AI characters and share them with other players
>pawns actually have very in depth AI and can learn how to do things like exploit i-frames if you show them
>story seems generic at first but has some very interesting elements related to Pawns

CONS:
>one character/pawn slot
>there's usually only one route to get to any particular place in the open world and you only get a couple stones to place for fast travel so you will do lots of walking through places you've been through a lot
>while I prefer the pawn chatter to silence, they really needed to record more lines or at least have an option for REDUCED pawn chatter rather than off
>mostly generic fantasy setting
>Berserk armor, Into Free opening, and JP voice acting removed from the PC version due to licensing issues
>menu does not work particularly well with mouse and keyboard

if that doesn't do it for you imagine the cheesiest engrish J-Rock you can think of, this game is the physical embodiment of that song.

reviewText:
I absolutley love this game. I played it to bits on the PS3 so when I saw it coming to PC I hurried and snatched a copy as well. The controlls on a pc controller works smoothly and the gameplay is fluid. It has a really high replay-value as there is alot to do and you might easily miss quests on your first run through (one involving crossdressing if there are any males in your current party). The normal setting is a good introduction to the game but if you try hardmode with the Bitterblack Isle dungeon you will really get a whooping if you ain't on your toes.

You also get Pawns that were made by other players that can assist you in a quest - if you get a Pawn that is experienced with certain quests they can actually help you with hints and if they have encountered a certain monster before they also give hints. Pawns can be a blessing or a freking annoyance depending on their behaviour though so learn them to stay away from Guardian/Nexus as it keeps them close to you and not our there killing monsters.

TL;DR
Fun adventure/fantasy/action game. Had to crossdress at a point to pass a certain area without murdering everything. Good times.

reviewText:
Great game, going to keep it simple for this one and just state the pros (who reads this anyways) and going into a little detail about the cons so if there is a sequal or something similiar these are the things I feel that need the most addressing to make it a more than viable contender against other huge open world games like the Witcher, Skyrim, etc.

Pros+

Dynamicly challenging customizable combat elements.
Boss fights feel like boss fights, they are awesome.
Pretty Large open world go wherever you like setting.
Very customizable class system with the ability to change anytime at certain locations.
Really nice graphics if tuned correctly
Awesome port in terms of performance and the like.
An insane amount of items and combinations for potions and gear upgrading!!!


Cons-

Hard mode:
Though I enjoyed the challenge and only played it in hard mode it did feel lazily implemented. I read that the only notable difference to the combat is that almost everything can one shot you in the early game which is true and while I did enjoy mastering it,it was a little frustrating at times. You do lvl up twice as fast and later it becomes a little less of an issue though so its not all that bad imo. My suggestion is to not start in hard like I did. From my understanding it was designed originally for new game+ and im sure you'll have a much better time playing normal. I'm an exception as I really enjoy challenging games and barely if ever start in normal xP Just wish it did more than just change dmg values.


Skillsets-
While not a con an extra skillslot or two per weapon wouldve been nice and added a bit more real time variety as apposed to having to go change them or your class at a certain location does.


Menu-
You spend way too much time in menus, Even though the PC version enables you to bind certain items" (another con) to the 1-5 keys I doubt many people play this with M+K. It plays well and all but the max fov I think is 75 so expect to get nasious if close to the screen. Luckily for me I use a Steam Controller and I had those keys binded
date:
otherwise i would've really hated it initially. It does get better once you learn your way around though so.... Yeah.


Story-
The little story it has is... Well just that
recommended: very little and doesn't exactly encourage you to keep playing the game for the sole intent of finishing the story alone. Hell I completed Bitterblack Isle first. which is alot harder and meant for endgame content
hoursPlayed:

reviewText: If skyrim, dark souls and dragon age had a threesome, this would be the outcome. A fun mix of all three, with the only downsides being a lack of variety in game assets. I feel I've only ventured about half the game world, maybe not even that but I've found you're either traversing forest/grassland, explorering oldschool dungeons or scouting castle grounds. Though this does give off a more realistic feeling to the environment whereas in dark souls, you may take a turn and the whole biome has changed in the blink of an eye.\nThe story sadly feels lacking and I have yet to feel immersed in the games world. A majority of the story quests are unrelated to the main plot, but are still enjoyable. I recommend to strictly follow the story questline till about level 20. I found if I strayed too far with a side quest, I found myself outmatched/outleveled and confused where to advance. Still yet to finish it, but having a ball :D Originally only bought this game to fill in the time for Dark Souls 3's release, but I've found something much greater than just a time filler.

reviewText:
I believe this is a great game, but should only be played by people who love RPGs or Fantasy games. I think it is an aquired taste, but should definetly be played by those who are RPG and Fantasy game fans. You will highly appreciate this game. It has a very strong role-playing aspect to it, with 9 classes to choose from, all with unique skills and abilities, and all can be played with the same character, and be switched with ease when you visit the inn in the big city in the game. Therefore, giving lots of re-playability, along with New Game Plus once the main quest is complete. Though what pissies me off is that you can only have one character at a time. I want a warrior, mage, and thief character, but I have to make a new steam account and family share if I want to do that. Back tracking and VERY limited enemy variations are also a setback. Also, the world is no Witcher 3 or Skyrim, so don't expect a HUGE open world. The combat however, is fantastic and super fluid. It works great with both keyboard+mouse and a controller, whatever your preference may be. But, if you can get past the negatives, which are fairy limited, this game will be a fantastic experience. This is a Fantasy RPG at the core, and done very well. Also, super addictive.

P.S. After the main quest, there are a lot more quests, some more dungeons, (and the DLC Bitterblack Isle) to complete and there are more enemy variations.

8.5/10  One of my favourite Fantasy RPGs.

reviewText: This game can be a bit repetitive as all hack and slash games are, and admittedly many quests won't specify exactly where the objectives are [I.E. They might tell you to kill skeletons, and will tell you what area, but not where the area is. Often you get kill quests that don't show up on the map because that's their way of saying that if you do some exploring, you'll run into them eventually.]. However, the story is pretty good, the fighting is fun as far as hack and slash goes, and there are many colorful characters.\n\nWhat really stands out about this game, is the pawn system. Party of 4, 2 of your creation [One is you, the other is your main helper] and 2 more that you can hire at specific stones that are essentially player-made characters. If that's not cool enough, the pawns actually learn about quests they are taken on, so very often you might hire a pawn who has knowledge of a quest you're trying to complete, and they will offer help with information. You also can gives presents to players whose pawns you thought went above and beyond the call of duty. Definietly a system I hope to see in more RPG games.

reviewText:
Dragon’s Dogma, Dark Arisen has sucked me in like few games before it ever
did. Admittedly, I have a short attention span. I love RPGs… I
especially love RPGs with good stories. Sometimes, an RPG can have a
great story, but if the combat is dull and not fun or challenging, I
will lose interest. Look at my profile and see the games I’ve played.
A lot of triple A RPGs in there with 20 hours or less.

Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen is a fabulous game and is very underrated.
I consider it to be the best action RPG I have ever played, by far.
Such a fantastic balance of level design, story, fun combat and
gameplay has never existed in my mind. Darksouls was great combat,
terrible story. Skyrim (and all Elder Scrolls games, really) featured
a great story but boring combat. The closest I can come to describing
this game in terms of other games would be a combination of Monster
Hunter and Skyrim. Yes… it is that awesome. Please allow me to
elaborate.

Level Design and presentation: Not the prettiest or flashiest when it
comes to modern PC games and all the bells and whistles, but the level
and character design is second to none. Some moments are breathtaking.
The immersion is astounding and very overlooked in this title. Like
once when I was standing on a castle wall and looking out over the
ocean and noticing that the banners hanging on the castle walls were
flapping in the breeze, I could actually hear them flapping as well as
the ocean waves crashing against the cliffside below. Now that is
attention to detail.

Speaking of castles, the fortresses and castles in this game are
amazing. The level layouts and designs are what I would imagine a real
castle would be like. Gran Sorensen looks, sounds and feels like a
real medieval city. Yes, some textures look muddy and under-detailed
by today’s standards, but this game absolutely makes you believe you
are really there even with the last gen graphics. And it isn’t just
the cities. With few exceptions, the “over-world”, dungeons and city
maps are all amazingly well-made.

Other than the occasional bland texture, the player characters, pawns
and enemies all look great as well. There is such a great variety in
gear that other than a few overused DLC armor set or two, you rarely
see pawns that look the same. At least, while leveling up to defeat
the game. I’m just now getting to post-game so that may change, but
I’ve been amazed by the variety in pawn looks.  More than once I
stopped running around long enough to inspect a pawn to see what that
awesome looking helmet or other piece of armor they were wearing was.

The animations are all outstanding with even the most minor of enemies
having large and varied sets of behavior and animations. I almost fell
out of my chair the first time a goblin came running over the hill,
nearly running right into me. He skidded to a stop and fell on his
rear end, just as surprised and shocked as I was. I almost felt guilty
for rapidly dispatching him before he could call for help (yes… they
do that too). I’ve seen many little touches like this that served to
immerse me like few games ever have. Visually and musically, this game
is a work of art. Even the voice acting is surprisingly good for a
localized Japanese game. And the music is fabulous, of course, but if
you’ve been reading about it, you probably already know that.

Story: I’m not sure why so many people sell the story is this game
short. It is actually a really good story with many interesting and
varied subplots. It is very easy to get lost on a sub quest and forget
that you aren’t actually getting anything done for the main quest. I
found myself caring for the plights of some of the characters and I
WANTED to help them… and not just for their rewards. I suspect a lot
of people really didn’t pay much attention and just wanted a good
action RPG.

Combat and Character Building: Another fantastic part of this game is
it’s combat systems. So many different options and ALL of them fun and
rewarding. I liked Skyrim, but without its story, it would be a very
dull game. This game is the exact opposite. Great combat that just
flows and feels right. I played this game on a console as well, but
the 60 frames per second on the PC REALLY makes a difference.  Adding
to the fluid and exciting combat system is the DEEP character building
system underneath. With 9 vocations (think classes) and hundreds of
skills and augments,  non-penalized class mixing-and-matching (though
your first 10 levels has a bigger effect on your stats than the next
90 levels will, which then have a bigger effect than the final 100
levels do for a total maximum level of 200), you really can try to
craft a character build that perfectly suits your play-style. For
example, my final assassin build uses augments from the fighter class,
the warrior class and the mage class. Assassins are a bit lacking in
magic defense, so I used just enough discipline points to invest in
the mage class to get its magic defense augment.  The Fighter and
Warrior Augments add strength and a little physical defense thrown in
for good measure. I really do love the build system here. It feels
like you really are making the character your own without the
dumbed-down system so many RPGs have these days. At the same time,
some parts were challenging but rarely felt unfair. I can think of one
instance near the beginning of the game when a group of bandits felt
extremely overpowered and out of place… like the level design team
accidently put them there, but other than that, it was a great
gameplay experience from beginning to end.

Final Verdict: If you like engrossing action RPGS, then you MUST get
this game. It is phenomenal. Any sequels will be a must-buy for me.

reviewText:
TL;DR version: God of War and Monster Hunter had a baby called Dragon's Dogma.



In depth version:
This is one of those GOTY style ports of older PS2/3 games to PC being distributed via Steam lately. That means this comes with every single DLC it originally had - no need to purchase anything. A price tag of 30 bucks might seem a hefty price tag for a port, but I can assure you it's worth it. I certainly don't regret grabbing it. Hell, I was waiting on a Steam sale for it initially but having aquired the game by other means, I picked it up the very next day when I realised what a gem it is.

Storyline-wise it's pretty basic across the board, even for the expansion area; Bitterblack Isle. It's a game that sells more off the gameplay, not the storyline - much like Dark Souls. You play an ordinary fisherman whose village gets attacked by a dragon. Upon fighting back, it effortlessly knocks you away but recognizes your bravery and retreats - but not before ripping your heart out and cursing you to become an Arisen. It's now your fate to confront the monster and kill it. As for Bitterblack Isle, the storyline is simply that a mysterious isle appeared off the coast of your hometown. You're off to explore the dark labyrinth and follow the footsteps of those other Arisen that came before you into the same trap. You're free to escape anytime of course...but do you really not want to explore the depths and unravel the mystery of the labyrinth?

So the gameplay...it's as though God of War and Monster Hunter had a baby called Dragon's Dogma which grew up playing Dark Souls but realised such a hardcore game wouldn't sell well in today's market. As a result it takes pieces of all these games and throws them together. You have your standard hack and slash styling like Monster Hunter and the monsters drop materials which may be combined into other items (potions, etc) or used in enhancing your gear. Don't worry though, Monster Hunter's carving system isn't present in this game. Neither is the massive weapon upgrade pathing that made the series unique - take that how you will, I considered it a con. Against larger monsters like chimeras, 15ft tall cyclops and the like, you can jump onto them and gouge them to death like a God of War. Or monsters like wolves might drag you to the ground and start mass mauling you as a pack, triggering quicktime events like God of War where you shake your joystick till you're free - or dead. There's a multitude of skills one can acquire (though 3 per weapon equipped is the limit - mages get 6 for their staves) ranging from counter and riposte skills to dropping meteors on the field. Some skills are class or weapon restricted for the sake of balance. Aspects of the game (Bitterblack Isle) are also highly challenging initially (emphasis on 'initially') where, like Dark Souls, one mistake can result in a oneshot. Bitterblack Isle however is completely optional and in no way impacts on the main story, allowing...*ahem* less...brave gamers to avoid it entirely.

The Pawn system in Dragon's Dogma is also something of note. Pawns are AI controlled followers that form a party of up to 4 (you and 3 pawns) or you can solo play. You have a 'main pawn' which you get to customize very early on (literally first 10 mins of play) and 2 'support pawns' which are optional. The pawns learn as the game goes on, gaining knowledge about quests, locations and monsters. Seems useless, right? That's where the online features come in. You can recruit the pawns of other players as support pawns and upload your own pawn to be hired by other players. So your pawn might come back with knowledge of a foe you haven't faced before and shout out tips in a fight accordingly. Or they might have knowledge of your quest targets and guide you to the location or give you hints in the right direction.

So in summary...
Pros:
+ Excellent gameplay, decently balanced. Gamers may challenge themselves by utilizing the basic starter weapons while max leveled as well as no armor, as made a habit by many Monster Hunter masoc-...veterans like myself who get a kick out of being oneshot from a single mistake or having two or three hour battles with a single monster. Or they may forgo this entirely while still being kept moderately challenged the entire game through.
+ No bugs. Seems they squashed the lot when porting to PC.
+ Good music. Battle vs Daimon's first and second forms in particular stand out in memory.
+ Sensible hitboxes, unlike Monster Hunter. I'm looking at you, Rathian/Rathalos tail swipes.
+ Pawn system is unique.

Cons:
- 'Blender game'. A game that took aspects out of several smash hits and threw them into one game. Lacks the major depth of those games. Can be a pro if you're a filt-...casual gamer.
- Climbing camera can annoy you very quickly, especially when the monster jiggles a lot trying to throw you off. You'll end up climbing in the wrong direction a LOT. Could've been better done (ie climb controls relative to the player character, not the camera).
- Pawns learn on a Do as I do" basis
date: not a "Do as I say" basis. So you'll see magic using pawns climbing on monsters sometimes. Can be remedied via ingame items to manipulate their AI behaviour
recommended: but gets tedious sometimes and requires rechecking of their AI or quashing of some aspects entirely.\n- Due to pawn AI system being somewhat unclear
hoursPlayed: you'll see a lot of uploaded pawns with Scather behaviour (targets strongest foes first). This would be fine
voteText: except the Scather behaviour prefers MELEE over ranged. But due to the misleading description
helpfulPercent:
you'll find a huge amount of Strider/Ranger/Mage/Sorcerer pawns with that stupid behavior. Guardian is another one (stays near the Arisen) that is common and bad as it is a passive AI (very rare attacks).
- Pawn AI system isn't the only thing with unclear descriptions. A number of augments (extra abilities you can equip - up to 6 at a time) have misleading or outright incorrect descriptions.

You decide:
-+ Minimalistic storyline. Not as minimalistic as Dark Souls
votesHelpful: but clearly designed to sell on gameplay
votesTotal: not story.\n-+ $30 price tag. Pricy for a port I suppose
votesFunny: but I consider it worth it.\n-+ Save system is a love-hate relationship. Old fashioned one save
commentsCount: checkpoint style. Good for anti save-scuming (where people would repeatedly reload to influence the RNG) to an extent (negated by Godsbaning...) but terribly annoying for those that like to mantain multiple characters. Will especially annoy people that like continuous restarting for that challenging struggle at the beginning of a game because you MUST play the bloody prologue repeatedly.\n-+ About half the game is somewhere between Monster Hunter and Dark Souls level difficulty. People looking to be a completionist but lousy at gaming may get horribly upset with Bitterblack Isle as a result. In particular

reviewText:
A very rough and unfinished gem. While it lacks in a lot of areas (story, small-ish world map, simple crafting system) it makes up for in others (character customization, pawn learning, sharing, and feedback, and diverse, responsive, fun combat).

It's definitely not for everyone, and it plays a lot like an offline MMO in terms of sidequests and story. However, the game's excellent combat and pawn systems more than make up for it. You can beat the main game in probably 6-8 hours, maybe less if you're quick, but there's a lot of hidden depth and post-game content, and the ability to start New Game+ with all your gear and stats. Some even say Bitterblack Isle is the best part of the game, and how the entire game should feel like, which I would agree, and Bitterblack is mostly for players who have finished the game and want more, which means it's purely optional content.

Dragon's Dogma is a sad example of a game who was overly ambitious in development (the outer world is half as big as what was planned, for example, and several big features and locations didn't make it to the final game) and as a result, had a lot of it's ideas and features scrapped and released in a very rushed manner due to budget issues, go look at the art books online and you'll see some examples.

Oh, and the port is nigh-on perfect. Keyboard and mouse works excelently, and I haven't heard of anyone having trouble running the game at 60FPS, whilst constant 20~ framerate and lower was a massive, common problem on the console version.

Who knows, if the game sells well, which it has so far, Capcom may be enticed into funding Dragon's Dogma 2, and this time, actually take their time and release a polished, finished game. Who wouldn't want to see that?
