reviewText:
I guess after 80 hours I can say a few things about this game...

If you didn't know, Dark Arisen is the expansion for Dragon's Dogma that came out a year after its release. I never got around to playing the extra content before my PS3 decided to die, and since I lost my save game I figured I'd just wait - and the waiting paid off with the PC release. Starting over again meant I could enjoy the core game with a graphics upgrade and then finally move on to the mysterious Bitterblack Isle that I missed a couple of years ago thanks to Sony's shoddy video card soldering.

THE CORE GAME

Dragon's Dogma starts out with an enticing premise. You face off with a Dragon on your hometown's beach front, and after barely scratching its skin the Dragon enters a sort of trance and rips your heart from your chest - magically sealing your life to his as you walk the Earth as the immortal Arisen.

Then... The game just kind of pitters around for about 20 hours.

Someone on the Gamefaqs forums once called this game Devil May Skyrim of the Colossus." That's really the best way to describe it. The director of the original Devil May Cry games took battle system concepts from that series and applied them to semi-Bethesda style open world. I say "Semi" because it's not packed with the same kind of a hundred half-written mini stories that you'd find in Skyrim. There's only one major city - two civilized settlements in total - and only a handful of dungeons. What's there is very well thought out with top notch level design
date: but the biggest draw is the combat.\n\nDragon's Dogma isn't perfect
recommended: but it's interesting. If Dark Souls is the pinnacle of RPG Combat sitting at a 10
hoursPlayed: and if Devil May Cry was put on the same list with an 8 or 9
voteText: I'd put Dragon's Dogma at a 7 or an 8. While Dark Souls is more about positioning and timing
helpfulPercent: Dragon's Dogma is about weakpoints and how to address them. One of the selling points is your ability to grapple enemies and when it comes to the giant Cyclops or the titular Dragons that means climbing all over them - Shadow of the Colossus Style. Every single enemy is different and needs to be dealt with differently - and with 3 play-styles with variances between 9 different vocations (classes) you quickly learn the game's rock paper scissors advantages and disadvantages. Add in an ingenious party system consisting of a personalized pawn and any online pawns you can hire from other players and you end up with a system far deeper than any of its individual elements.\n\nAs mentioned it isn't perfect though. There's no camera control when you're climbing on things
votesHelpful: and your greatest enemy quickly becomes the walls around you and its affect on your viewpoint. The direction you move is relative to your character's body - tank control style - making navigating the navel of the giants something akin to walking around with a mushroom on your head in Earthbound. Combat difficulty can simmer at too easy for a long time until you find an enemy capable of combo killing you in three shots. But the biggest offender I think is the potion system. The game lets you carry supplies at the expense of your own movement
votesTotal: but it's almost never bad enough that you aren't carrying around a pack full of cure-alls at any given time. Potions are accessed through the pause menu and heal you instantly - acting as a sort of "Reset" for combat gone awry. In the endgame you're even given an abundance wakestones that literally bring you back to life if you die - and you have enough carry weight that I was toting at least 5 of these everywhere I went. I often intentionally would die as a tactical decision.\n\nAt its best
votesFunny: the combat is deep and challenging
commentsCount: but even at its worst its certainly more fun than the cat-fight flailing you find in other open world RPGs.\n\nIronically though
column16: my favorite thing about this game is the story. It has a great start

reviewText:
Dragon’s Dogma: Take up arms, Arisen

Dragon’s Dogma is a weird game. Like, in the good way-- it’s definitely good weird. What makes it weird? Well, Dragon’s Dogma has excellent combat, interesting monster design, an open world, and a steep difficulty curve. But it’s also heavily Japanese. If that doesn’t mean anything to you well... It’s like Monster Hunter meets Dark Souls, with a dash of Skyrim. Two great games, and a pretty good one. Which game I am referring to, you decide.

Now, don’t get me wrong I love this game. I played it back on the Xbox 360, and recently bought it again to replay it! Capcom decided to re-release it on the Steam, and when I heard this I actually yelled in excitement. “‘BOUT TIME!”. I don’t usually do that, but in this case I was pretty stoked. Dragon’s Dogma was an exceptional game back on the Xbox, but it was hamstrung by bad performance and A LOT of screen tearing. I never really noticed screen tearing… Until I played Dragon’s Dogma… It was bad, but bearable, and worth it.

Now that Capcom has released the game on PC it has none of those limitations and it truly shines because of it. After playing about twenty or so hours of the game on PC I went back and checked it out on the XBox. The only way I could describe it-- is: Gross. It felt so sluggish. Everything about it was slow, and framey... I’m not usually a stickler about this kind of stuff… But the difference was night and day. It was not the game I remembered.

Anyway, I won’t go on about technical issues much, but suffice it to say: The game runs like a dream compared to the Xbox, and it also looks significantly better too, which is nice.

This is a great port, of a great game-- and it runs like it should. Well.

Now on to the game proper! Dragon’s Dogma game is definitely Japanese. I mean it was released by Capcom. And you can feel the Japanese-ness in every fiber of the game. Do game’s have fibers? Anyway… Dragon’s Dogma is an Eastern take on a Western open world RPG. Ala Skyrim. And it does a very respectable job! But it’s definitely niche. I won’t lie to you and tell you this game is for everyone. Because it isn’t… But I would advise you to give it a chance.

So for the game’s sake, I’ll ask you a few questions:

Do you like fighting giant monsters? Do you like challenging boss fights? Do you like Shadow of the Colossus? Do you like having to fight tooth and nail to succeed? Seemingly accurate medieval dialog? Dragons? Magic? Monster Hunter? Fake British accents? Kimyōna Nihon no mono?

If you said hai to three of those questions-- well, then do I (probably) have the game for you!

Let’s talk about the combat first, because that’s definitely the main draw of this game-- unless you’re really into the weird romance side of things… Anyway… The combat is great, but it’s definitely different. You have a standard light and a heavy attack, as well as up to six different skills for each of the game’s nine classes. Yes nine.

The combat is rather simple with only a few different combos, but the variety of skills and multitude of ways to use them comes together in a very pleasant and rewarding way. Also the magic system is one of the coolest I’ve seen in a video game. Right up there with Magicka. I’ve been mentioning Magicka a lot… Maybe I should play it again.

Now it might sound intimidating that Dragon’s Dogma sports nine different classes, but it’s actually handled quite well. The game splits it’s classes, called vocations, into three types: Basic, Advanced, and Hybrid. And they sound exactly like what you would expect.

Basic vocations are your standard RPG fare: sword and board Fighter, bow and dagger Strider, and the hurt or heal Mage. Advanced Vocations are specialized versions of their basic cousins: Warrior, Ranger, Sorcerer. And of course the Hybrid vocations are… well-- Hybrids. Featuring the Assassin, Magic Archer, and the Mystic Knight.

Although there is some overlap, each vocation has a large amount of unique abilities which is where they really flesh out from each other and feel different. On top of that each vocation also has a variety of class independent ‘Augments’ which provide various boons, and are unlocked as you rank up in each vocation. So play around with the vocations and see which ones you like! I really enjoy the Ranger and Mystic Knight. This game has a huge potential for Min/Maxing as well.


In addition to yourself-- The Arisen, you also get a companion called a pawn. And you can also hire two additional pawns to create a party of four. And trust me party composition is quite important. If you don’t have a healer/buffer… You’re Chimera food...

Speaking of Chimeras, you face some truly difficult and abhorrent creatures in the world of Gransys. You will encounter, Cyclopes, Hydras, Wights, Wargs, Gryphons, Cockatrices, and of course Dragons! And plenty of others too!

The encounters with these creatures are almost always memorable. Without fail something unexpected will happen and it will leave an impression on you-- or a deep emotional scar that will may never heal... I still remember the time my entire party was stricken with petrification and we slowly turned to stone with no hope of escape. Watching you and your party slowly harden into twisted statues and then crumble into dust is hard to forget. Trust me the monster encounters are super cool, and almost always heart pounding.

Also the fight with the Dragon is one of the coolest boss fights I have experienced in gaming. It does everything right. And despite really wanting to tell you about it, I would suggest you go in blind.

It’s so badass, though. Like if you don’t have any interest in this game atleast check it out on YouTube.

Like this review? Check out more on 100HourSave.com

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is just a gem of a game.  While it's not particularly ambitious (it doesn't have a grand arcing story, it's not a *huge* open world, and it isn't tremendously complex visually), the game just does what it does very well.  Combat is smooth, varied, and very visceral sounding and feeling.  The mechanics for moving around in the world are very responsive, and the character leveling system is forgiving of mistakes, easy to get into, and impressively versatile.

In addition, the PC port is gorgeous looking (obviously still somewhat limited by it's overall graphical limits) and runs liquid smooth.

The primary plot is fairly straightforward, and role-playing aspects are extremely limited.  The dialogue and voice-acting are not particularly imaginative, but competent.  But overall, the game is just a joy to play.  I love moving around in the world, the world looks...interesting in most of the places, the sound design provides excellent atmosphere, the fight mechanics are fun and active and diverse...

I recommend this game to everyone that enjoys fantasy exploration and combat, and especially the PC port.

reviewText:
The story is non-existent. The dialogue is horrible. The music is horrible. The cutscenes are especially horrible. The UI isn't changed from the console release (read: horrible).

But the combat is rather fun. There's just one big problem I've found with the early game, or perhaps it's just with the storyline in general. It's that there's so much slogging through boring content to get to the good parts. Fighting big monsters is really fun, but doing quests and killing bandits and goblins and other small critters is completely boring.

Often you'll find yourself running through large expanses of land to get to a quest objective, and there's nothing along the way but bandits barely worth killing. This is pretty much what questing is like. 15 minutes of running to get to 5 minutes of actual fun.

This is an RPG only in the sense that you're given the mechanics and tools to role-play, but you have to completely make up your own canon. There's practically no story to facilitate role-playing. If you're looking for an RPG, this probably isn't a good choice. On the other hand, if you're just about the action, then perhaps you'll find value in Dragon's Dogma. Just be prepared to slog through the first bit to get to the good parts.

There are really awkward keybindings, such as backspace to confirm changes (really?). The menus have a lot of unnecessary pauses, such has a 2 second modal dialogue saying Game is saved". Saving options takes nearly 10 seconds (how?). The game syncs with a server whenever you sleep at an inn
date: and it takes another 10 seconds. The menus are extremely console-ish with its giant fonts
hoursPlayed: and lists containing only three elements at a time. Performance is great however
voteText: as it should be for a game of such fidelity.\n\nGenerally I'm having fun with it though. I'd recommend it

reviewText:
I need to say this: I love this game. I love this game to the point of putting countless hours on it on my 360 and still pre-ordering it here.
However... Okay, look, this game can be obtuse as ♥♥♥♥ at times. Its difficulty curve is weird, the controls are sometimes wonky and the game mechanics and design decisions are often questionable.
It also really doesn't like to tell you anything - that may be a plus for some.
Although, it does have:
- Really sweet action oriented combat system
- A bunch of classes that feel truly different from each other while still being fun in their own way
- A nice npc slav- erm, i mean, lending system  where other people rent characters you created in return for cool stuff and monies
- Climbing on big beasts Shadow of the Colossus style and then stabbing them in the privates
- An end-game area that feels reminiscent of the Souls games in both difficulty and general ambiance
- Pretty good world presented in a less than stellar way
- ♥♥♥♥ing insane (and awesome) ending which is even awesome-er when you see it for the 2nd+ times
If any of that sounds appealing, try it out. Just... keep an open mind, it has flaws and I cry a bit every time I see a This game f*cking sucks" post somewhere
date: complaining about stuff that for many is even part of the game's charm."

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma was very high on the list of games from the PS3/360 that I really wanted to be released on PC.
It didn't look likely to happen, but then Capcom did the right thing. Better late than never.

Now that the game has been freed from the confines of old consoles it is great to finally be able to enjoy the gameplay at a stable 60+ fps, instead of the terrible framerate I played with on the PS3.

The game was never a looker, but the overall world aesthetic is cohesive and pleasing. Monsters look great and everything is very well animated. I am thoroughly enjoying battling huge monsters all over again.

The port is barebones with no real enhancements to speak of but it's stable and offers seamless switching between mouse/keyboard and controller. Even with no additional enhancements the port does tick the boxes for a good PC port in terms of controls, resolutions and framerates up to 150 fps.

The meat of the game is the combat and the unique pawn rental system. The story is slow to begin with and perhaps not to everyone's liking, but I think it goes interesting places in the end. The real Dragon's Dogma starts with the post-game anyway. I'm not spoiling it here, but the end of the story is really just the beginning of the best part of the game - and then there's the high level Dark Arisen content with hours and hours of the best gameplay Dragon's Dogma has to offer.

This is easily one of the very best action RPGs ever created.

reviewText:
Right lads, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a pretty fun game. Quite a number of points to cover now so it might be a wee bit of a read. I'll start with the character creation.

Character Creation is a right bit impressive, your character (The Arisen) and your main Pawn (Your perma companion/slave/meat sheild/whatever) can be created up and customised when you get to do so. You can choose a good number of hairstyles and other cosmetics, however you'll need to notice the Height and Weight options that change during creation as they can impact gameplay, I havn't looked too much into this but I would imagine that lighter, smaller characters can sprint longer and quicker then bigger characters, but would likely not be able to carry as much.

Gameplay is like your hack n' slash if you go melee on the enemies (more on enemies later) and mage characteres have quite the magic system. I'm not playing as a mage myself but from what I've seen from my main pawn (Aimee) she has quite the magic power. You can also climb bigger enemies and hack away at their body parts if you want to butcher them for the banter. Want to cut the snake part off a Chimera? Go for it! You can throw your pawns and enemies off cliffs aswell if you want for easy kills, so if you want to create a pawn that looks like that annoying kid named Samuel Edmund that barely anyone likes for the sole purpose of throwing him off a cliff, go for it!

There is indeed online funcionality, however (I might be wrong, only got to the main city at the time of writing this) there isn't any PvP. You CAN however hire other player's pawns to fight for you. They'll use their abilities and destroy stuff if you need 'em to. If you want, you can find my pawn Aimee and hire her to fight for you if you want. I'll try getting that sorted.

The game has a good number of enemies. It has your standard RPG blokes like the goblins and zombies, but it has bigger enemies such as ogres and hydra enemies for a bigger challenge. Each type of enemy has weaknesses and such, so be sure to prepare quite well if you want to fight 'em.

The actual in-game enviroment is pretty big. Mind you, I'm only currently at the big city place but I imagine there is a whole lot more other places to explore, including caves, mines and other locations. Top looting kek.

I would highly recommend this game for the RPG fans and if you fancy throwing people of cliffs. I'll give it a solid 9/10.
The price SHOULD be affordable enough for the amount of fun and gameplay that it offers, but if you don't have the money or still not sure about the game, you could wait for a sale or something.

reviewText: If you've played the console version and liked that, then for sure get the port as it is definitively superior. If you have not played it before however, you should know what you're getting into. Dragons Dogma is an open world RPG, where you get to explore many fairly similar yet minutely distinct environments. The combat is very varied between the 9 vocations available, the games version of classes, which are almost freely switchable between, Whether you're melee or ranged, you have both physical and magical options which are both mechanically and visually distinct, with magic oft being the more visually spectacular, but not necesarilly satisfying option. The world itself has a lot of lore built into it, though it is hardly something pressed to the forefront; in general plot points beyond the major ones are kept relatively quiet. That said, the game does give a lot more if one explores at the right times, the right times being before a quest expires, as the game does make a fair few side quests, and even a few main ones, missable. These are however of course doable in NG+, something most people are like to partake in.

reviewText:
Extremely fun game.  Brings a console feeling to the PC even though I used kb+m.

Combat is entertaining.  Pawn system is awesome (3 followers who give you tips and hints) who you get to pick and choose who goes with you.

Story is a bit meh, but otherwise still good.

I beat the game in about 20 hours, which for $30 that's decent value, but there is still alot more content to go through than what I expereinced.  I am now doing post-story quests/exploration which I have not even touched even 10% of it.  Probably another good 20-40 hours left in the game to finish it completely, and then there's NewGame+ where you can do it all over again on a harder difficulty if you want to.

Overall an entertaining and fun solo game, which is the only downside to it as I prefer co-op.

reviewText: Dragons Dogma has A LOT to offer, this game is truly something special doesnt need a pre-alpha,  no half ♥♥♥ job. this game blew me away. its challanging in quite a few aspects. not your typical RPG. it reminds me of dragon age a bit. but something about dragons dogma really stands out to me. it has its own spice to it, and seems to amaze me everytime i play. i love the parkour feel, as well as being able to change to any class at any time. the graphics could be better, but with a game this good, it could have minesweeper graphics and would be just fine. many Pros, little cons. MUST NEED GAME

reviewText:
If you've played Dragon's Dogma on console, you should know what to expect. It's without a doubt a surprisingly fantastic RPG. For the sake of keeping things short, Dark Arisen 2016 is everything you've probably already played, only better. It's a great port, and at this price you have absolutely no excuse not to buy it right now.

For those who want a more detailed review, read on.

PROS:
-Say goodbye to silky smooth console 24fps.
The game runs at a constant (or variable, if you want) 60fps. If you are like me and often wished the console version ran at a higher frame rate, it's here, and it's wonderful.

-At 1080p this game still looks good, and given the fact that it's a port of a 4 year old game I'm impressed. Some standard features like FOV adjustments and other graphical features can all be tinkered with as well.

-You can play with Mouse and Key, and controller support is there as expected. My XB1 controller works fine.

-Gameplay is just as fun as always. Monster Hunter with a dash of Dark Souls is how I usually describe it.

-Explore, explore, explore. You never know what you're going to find.

-Boss" battles really do have a (again) Monster Hunter feel to them.
Climb up the back
date: slash at the legs to topple it
recommended: it's up to you. It's not crushingly difficult
hoursPlayed: but you'll be in for a challenge.\n\n-The pawn system allows you to recruit other players pawns to join you on your quest. I personally love this feature as it allows me to hire higher level pawns
voteText: making my life that much easier.\n\n-A pleasant soundtrack
helpfulPercent:
albeit a little repetitive over time.

MIXED:
-The story starts off half decent
votesHelpful: slows down midway and then gets good near the end.\nNow for some the story won't really impact the level of enjoyment they get out of this game
votesTotal: while others might be slightly disapointed. It's not fantastic
votesFunny:
but it's not bad either.


NEGS:
-MASTERWORKS ALL YOU CAN'T GO WRONG (repetitive NPC lines become a little annoying after a while
commentsCount: especially with pawns). Thankfully you can turn off your Pawns chatter completely. Shame the same can't be said for a certain shop owner.\n\n-Voice acting is a mixed bag. While I liked some characters
column16: others were done poorly. Worse is that they've recycled the same VA for the pawns and raised or lowered their voices to give a half-baked impression that they're entirely different. I know it's due to budget/time/game restraints
column17: but still.\n\n-Pawn AI seems to do alright half the time
column18: other times they become a nuisance. For example
column19: in one of the early quests you're forced to make a run for the exit. You make a break for the stairs and instead of following
column20: the AI decides it's going to fight every single enemy AI on the way up. You have to either nanny them all the way (at the risk of your own life) or let them "die"
column21: hopefully reviving them at the next area.\n\n-A very minor gripe
column22: but sometimes the game can become a touch grindy and it'll become clear to you that some bosses simply require a higher level character to take on. While it's hardly the end of the world
column23: it might become frustrating when your quests end up stonewalling you and no amount of gitgud will save you.\n\n-No Berserk armour sets available to us dirty western piggus. Guts is finally off the boat and yet I still can't play as him."

reviewText: A true Masterwork, you can't go wrong!  The prologue is freakin' amazing, and gives players a heady taste of what's to come if you're willing to give the game a chance.  This is a brilliant, deep RPG with one of the best battle systems I've ever encountered before.  After playing 100+ hours of this game on the consoles, I can't believe how eager I am to start from scratch all over again.\n\nThe only downside to this port is that there is no Japanese language setting as there was on the 360/PS3 versions.

reviewText:
My first time playing, games runs great, combat is interesting, story is interesting, just made my pawn. Haven't tried 4k on my TV, but will soon. From what I can tell no online co op. If they add multiplayer I will buy more copies of the game so they're is an instenive for adding multiplayer. Very happy with my purchase.

Update, 4k 60 FPS on GTX 970, cpu usage around 50%, GPU sits around 70-80%, but jumps up to 99%. I bit more taxing then Dark Souls 2. VRAM uses well under 3 GB at 4k. Biggest isse is the game seems to suffer from texture popping. The only hardware that could be causing this is my hard drive, 7200 RPM. I could try installing on my SSD to see if that fixes the issue. Otherwise it's just the game. Don't really use SSD for games.

The game itself just keeps getting better and better. It's basically Skyrim meets Dark Souls. Skyrim still has more detail and Dark Souls still has more precise combat. But the combat has a really enjoyable organic feel to it. The large bosses and the ability to climb on to them is fantastic. From what I can tell the map to this game is smaller then say Skyrim and The Witcher 3, but somehow it feels larger. This has a mix to do with the difficulty of combat, the fast travel system and day and night cycle. Combat is challenging, but not Dark Souls challenging. Leveing up, gearing up will cushion the challenge.

You can use an item you get from your Gran Soren depository to fast travel to a few major hubs and you must find each individually before fast travel options becomes available. This fast travel system will force you into having to travel through the same area's over and over, but in a quality way.  Basically fast travel is for returning to town, sell, gear up and then had back out. This makes fast travel not feel cheap and over used like in Skyrim, nor tedious like the original Dark Souls before completing Anor Londo.

Day and Night is amazing, about 48 minutes total. Sun rises and sets at a very slow and realistic pace. Night is amazing, without Lantern areas can become pitch black. The Lantern is perfect, Dark Souls take note. You stick Lantern on your hip, has no impact on combat and use oil found around the game to fill it up. The environment is harsher and filled with more monsters at night. At night the game really starts to feel like my favorite manga Berserk. You feel very much like Guts being marked as sacrifice and that all ceatures of darkness are attracted to you.

The game features a Guts like class and Large swords. Of course many other options, basics are fighter, rogue, mage.  Biggest issue with combat is they're is no lock-on like Dark Souls, but I here Bow and Magic have lock-on, I wouldn't know. I really like the character editor, not overally detailed or simplistic. You can make migget or gaint, skinny or fat, muscular or not.

Few last minutes note's, game features a pawn system, companions that travel with you. This is the online feature in the game. It allows us to all share are pawns with each other. Not much to say about it, works good and you can see for yourself what it's like.  Has plenty of Berserk references, earily on you meet a female commander much like Casca, later on you come to a witch house much like the one in Berserk. The game is fully voiced, but can't ride horses. Lastly I'm 80% sure this will be one of favorite games of all-time. Which makes me a little depressed by thinking to myself that I maybe missing out on great titles from Playstation and Nintendo consoles, but the Japanese seem to be catching on to the future of gaming which is to game one whatever the hell you want.

reviewText:
I played the ♥♥♥♥ out of this on PS3.

It has its flaws but it's a great game overall. Great character customization in terms of character creation, equipment variety, the ability to switch between classes freely, and choosing skills and augments. Combat is solid and the grab mechanic is great, but the game could use more variation in monster types to populate its large map. Quicktravel exists and I like that you have to work for it, and that you can place quicktravel points where you want them. The main story is simple and honestly kind of weak, but I absolutely love the subtle worldbuilding behind it all. The highlight is the battle with Grigori, where the game's story really unfolds, and it's probably my favorite dragon fight in any game.

Also the npc affinity system is a nice touch, especially since you can romance just about any npc however insignificant they may be (even on accident), but it would've been nice to see your partner do more than chill at your house. Same goes for the other character that goes to your house after completing her quest.


10/10, would play a more polished sequel, on PC and/or PS4.

reviewText:
YES YES YES! It's finnaly here! I put SO MUCH time into this game on PS3, it is one of my absolute favorite games of last gen, it's so freaking good! Even playing on my crappy laptop (not my main PC) it still runs at double the framerate as on console, so I'd say it's optimized pretty well! What can I say....
-The story is awesome and stays interesting playthrough after playthrough
-Endgame content is TOTALLY worthwhile and super fun to face harder challenges
-The graphics, though obviously aged, still hold up really well (especially with maxed settings)
-The leveling is FUN, you can level up an insane amount and it never feels grindy
-The combat.... Ooohhh the combat.......... Simply put, it's probably my favorite combat in an RPG (only after Kingdom Hearts) It's deep, there's tons of different moves to learn, you can latch onto giant creatures ala Monster Hunter. It takes the best elements of MH, Dark Souls, and arcade hack n slash and just.... It's so fun..
-Upgrade system and class system are very easy to switch, you can be anything you want to be anytime
-Tons of customization for your character and pawn, loads of outfits/armors, once you start delving far into the game you can get black market items too, eventually when you level super high too (maybe this is a con for the diehards?) you don't even need to worry about what armor is best" and can run around naked if you like (at least that's what I did when fighting UR dragon lol)
-Bosses
hoursPlayed: lots of explorable treasures and awesome things/people/places to find\n\nTrust me

reviewText:
An amazing game with brillant graphics and gameplay. This game is best described as a mix between the Elderscrolls, Shadow of the Colossus, Dark Souls and Monster Hunter. The pawn system is remarkable and allows you to customise your own personal, permanent companion. The customisation options for creating your character are rather thorough.

In battle you can climb big bosses and hack at their weak spots. It has a day and night cycle system; in which the atmosphere in the game changes to a more survival horror vibe. The game has immense replay value as the are multiple side quests and the DLC to complete.
When the game first released on consoles, I logged approximately 90 hours.

If you have not purchased or played the game before, this game is undoubtedly worth the full price. The game comes with DLC.

This game is highly recommended.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Don't take my lack of logged hours as inexperience with this game, I played this game for well over 100 hours on my 360, this game and Red Dead Redemption remained more or less the only reason why my 360 isn't in the trash.

This is a damn fine PC port, the textures anmd draw distance still scream 2012, but the PC definitely looks better than the console version thanks to 1080p, and the lighting seems to be a little better too. The framerate isn't capped, or tied to the physics in any way - so you can play this game at over 60FPS and not suffer for it, and you'll more than likely be playing this game at over 60FPS thanks to the modest system requirements. An entry/mid range GPU will easily be able to hang with the higher settings.

So onto some pros and cons:

+ Amazing combat, thnk Dark Souls meets Final Fantasy XII meets God of War meets Shadow of the Colossus, the big boss battles are truly memorable. The first time you tackle a Griffin or a Troll, you won't forget it. This game handles big monsters superbly, you don't just find yourself slashing at their shins a la Skyrim
+ Big open world to explore with very few loading screens, and the ones that are there are very fast
+ Robust character creation system and layered armour means you can create a truly unique character, a big plus for me in an RPG
+ Pawn system is great and allows for some very unique party lineups, and sharing your pawns online and rating other people's is a lot of fun and adds a real sense of community in an otherwise single player game. Their AI is cgreat too, you only need to issue a few imple commands like 'help' and 'come' and they'll handle the rest.
+ Not as many quests or dungeons as Skyrim or Dragon Age, but this is a game that values quality over quantity
+ Open ended class sytem with lots of customization, and being able to switch between classes at the Gran Soren inn means you don't have to reroll another character in order to try something new.
+ The Bitterblack Isle DLC which is included in Dark Arisen is a very fun and challening expansion that adds many more hours of looting, dungeons crawling and monster slaying

- Big though the world is, the environment is very same old same old, steep crags, rivers, rolling hills, dried out shrubland and woods, that's more or less it.
- Pawn chatter is annoying, luckily the PC port includes an option to disable it
- The main story is very cliche, Dragon threatening the world, you are the chosen one, we've seen it all before. I never cared much for this game's story, but narrative isn't what drives this game, gameplay is.


I give Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen an 8.5/10, arguably one of the best games to hit last gen consoles during the end of their tenure, now finally on the platform it deserved to be on in the first place.

reviewText:
The game is solid. After playing Dark Souls 2 for the last month and wanting to play Dark Souls 1 without terrible jittering and bad overall port performance, seeing a japanese developer do a PC port right is truly a breath of fresh air.

The textures are not beautiful. In fact, some of them seem damn atrocious. For example, in the subtitles, you can see the discoloration of pixels around lettering... But the game flows well. The higher framerate really helps make up for lesser textures by making the game feel responsive and smooth as far as game experiences go.

This game also does something that I've long desired in games. Too often game developers fall back on cinematics to do the big awesome stuff. You'll get into a fight of some sort, and when it is over it cuts to a neat scene of the character jumping up and doing some fantastic gymnastics to kill the enemy... In Dragon's Dogma though, it is a lot more like Shadow of the Colossus. There are mechanics for -you- to climb up on the enemy, to get up to his head and attack him from there. It isn't just you watching a cinematic of that being done, -you- do it. In that way, this game is already leagues ahead of so many action games that rely upon cinematics or QTEs for awesome character actions.

All around, this is a good game. I recommend it. My only true issue is just how many tutorials there are. I'm 2 hours in, and still getting assaulted with pop ups telling me about how to do different things. However, to be fair it is possible to turn those off... It just seems like by 2 hours in, I should be past the tutorial" stage in the game.

Get it. It is an excellent deal at $30."

reviewText:
Dragon’s Dogma: Take up arms, Arisen

Dragon’s Dogma is a weird game. Like, in the good way-- it’s definitely good weird. What makes it weird? Well, Dragon’s Dogma has excellent combat, interesting monster design, an open world, and a steep difficulty curve. But it’s also heavily Japanese. If that doesn’t mean anything to you well... It’s like Monster Hunter meets Dark Souls, with a dash of Skyrim. Two great games, and a pretty good one. Which game I am referring to, you decide.

Now, don’t get me wrong I love this game. I played it back on the Xbox 360, and recently bought it again to replay it! Capcom decided to re-release it on the Steam, and when I heard this I actually yelled in excitement. “‘BOUT TIME!”. I don’t usually do that, but in this case I was pretty stoked. Dragon’s Dogma was an exceptional game back on the Xbox, but it was hamstrung by bad performance and A LOT of screen tearing. I never really noticed screen tearing… Until I played Dragon’s Dogma… It was bad, but bearable, and worth it.

Now that Capcom has released the game on PC it has none of those limitations and it truly shines because of it. After playing about twenty or so hours of the game on PC I went back and checked it out on the XBox. The only way I could describe it-- is: Gross. It felt so sluggish. Everything about it was slow, and framey... I’m not usually a stickler about this kind of stuff… But the difference was night and day. It was not the game I remembered.

Anyway, I won’t go on about technical issues much, but suffice it to say: The game runs like a dream compared to the Xbox, and it also looks significantly better too, which is nice.

This is a great port, of a great game-- and it runs like it should. Well.

Now on to the game proper! Dragon’s Dogma game is definitely Japanese. I mean it was released by Capcom. And you can feel the Japanese-ness in every fiber of the game. Do game’s have fibers? Anyway… Dragon’s Dogma is an Eastern take on a Western open world RPG. Ala Skyrim. And it does a very respectable job! But it’s definitely niche. I won’t lie to you and tell you this game is for everyone. Because it isn’t… But I would advise you to give it a chance.

So for the game’s sake, I’ll ask you a few questions:

Do you like fighting giant monsters? Do you like challenging boss fights? Do you like Shadow of the Colossus? Do you like having to fight tooth and nail to succeed? Seemingly accurate medieval dialog? Dragons? Magic? Monster Hunter? Fake British accents? Kimyōna Nihon no mono?

If you said hai to three of those questions-- well, then do I (probably) have the game for you!

Let’s talk about the combat first, because that’s definitely the main draw of this game-- unless you’re really into the weird romance side of things… Anyway… The combat is great, but it’s definitely different. You have a standard light and a heavy attack, as well as up to six different skills for each of the game’s nine classes. Yes nine.

The combat is rather simple with only a few different combos, but the variety of skills and multitude of ways to use them comes together in a very pleasant and rewarding way. Also the magic system is one of the coolest I’ve seen in a video game. Right up there with Magicka. I’ve been mentioning Magicka a lot… Maybe I should play it again.

Now it might sound intimidating that Dragon’s Dogma sports nine different classes, but it’s actually handled quite well. The game splits it’s classes, called vocations, into three types: Basic, Advanced, and Hybrid. And they sound exactly like what you would expect.

Basic vocations are your standard RPG fare: sword and board Fighter, bow and dagger Strider, and the hurt or heal Mage. Advanced Vocations are specialized versions of their basic cousins: Warrior, Ranger, Sorcerer. And of course the Hybrid vocations are… well-- Hybrids. Featuring the Assassin, Magic Archer, and the Mystic Knight.

Although there is some overlap, each vocation has a large amount of unique abilities which is where they really flesh out from each other and feel different. On top of that each vocation also has a variety of class independent ‘Augments’ which provide various boons, and are unlocked as you rank up in each vocation. So play around with the vocations and see which ones you like! I really enjoy the Ranger and Mystic Knight. This game has a huge potential for Min/Maxing as well.


In addition to yourself-- The Arisen, you also get a companion called a pawn. And you can also hire two additional pawns to create a party of four. And trust me party composition is quite important. If you don’t have a healer/buffer… You’re Chimera food...

Speaking of Chimeras, you face some truly difficult and abhorrent creatures in the world of Gransys. You will encounter, Cyclopes, Hydras, Wights, Wargs, Gryphons, Cockatrices, and of course Dragons! And plenty of others too!

The encounters with these creatures are almost always memorable. Without fail something unexpected will happen and it will leave an impression on you-- or a deep emotional scar that will may never heal... I still remember the time my entire party was stricken with petrification and we slowly turned to stone with no hope of escape. Watching you and your party slowly harden into twisted statues and then crumble into dust is hard to forget. Trust me the monster encounters are super cool, and almost always heart pounding.

Also the fight with the Dragon is one of the coolest boss fights I have experienced in gaming. It does everything right. And despite really wanting to tell you about it, I would suggest you go in blind.

It’s so badass, though. Like if you don’t have any interest in this game atleast check it out on YouTube.

Like this review? Check out more on 100HourSave.com

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is just a gem of a game.  While it's not particularly ambitious (it doesn't have a grand arcing story, it's not a *huge* open world, and it isn't tremendously complex visually), the game just does what it does very well.  Combat is smooth, varied, and very visceral sounding and feeling.  The mechanics for moving around in the world are very responsive, and the character leveling system is forgiving of mistakes, easy to get into, and impressively versatile.

In addition, the PC port is gorgeous looking (obviously still somewhat limited by it's overall graphical limits) and runs liquid smooth.

The primary plot is fairly straightforward, and role-playing aspects are extremely limited.  The dialogue and voice-acting are not particularly imaginative, but competent.  But overall, the game is just a joy to play.  I love moving around in the world, the world looks...interesting in most of the places, the sound design provides excellent atmosphere, the fight mechanics are fun and active and diverse...

I recommend this game to everyone that enjoys fantasy exploration and combat, and especially the PC port.

reviewText:
A very rough and unfinished gem. While it lacks in a lot of areas (story, small-ish world map, simple crafting system) it makes up for in others (character customization, pawn learning, sharing, and feedback, and diverse, responsive, fun combat).

It's definitely not for everyone, and it plays a lot like an offline MMO in terms of sidequests and story. However, the game's excellent combat and pawn systems more than make up for it. You can beat the main game in probably 6-8 hours, maybe less if you're quick, but there's a lot of hidden depth and post-game content, and the ability to start New Game+ with all your gear and stats. Some even say Bitterblack Isle is the best part of the game, and how the entire game should feel like, which I would agree, and Bitterblack is mostly for players who have finished the game and want more, which means it's purely optional content.

Dragon's Dogma is a sad example of a game who was overly ambitious in development (the outer world is half as big as what was planned, for example, and several big features and locations didn't make it to the final game) and as a result, had a lot of it's ideas and features scrapped and released in a very rushed manner due to budget issues, go look at the art books online and you'll see some examples.

Oh, and the port is nigh-on perfect. Keyboard and mouse works excelently, and I haven't heard of anyone having trouble running the game at 60FPS, whilst constant 20~ framerate and lower was a massive, common problem on the console version.

Who knows, if the game sells well, which it has so far, Capcom may be enticed into funding Dragon's Dogma 2, and this time, actually take their time and release a polished, finished game. Who wouldn't want to see that?

reviewText:
I guess after 80 hours I can say a few things about this game...

If you didn't know, Dark Arisen is the expansion for Dragon's Dogma that came out a year after its release. I never got around to playing the extra content before my PS3 decided to die, and since I lost my save game I figured I'd just wait - and the waiting paid off with the PC release. Starting over again meant I could enjoy the core game with a graphics upgrade and then finally move on to the mysterious Bitterblack Isle that I missed a couple of years ago thanks to Sony's shoddy video card soldering.

THE CORE GAME

Dragon's Dogma starts out with an enticing premise. You face off with a Dragon on your hometown's beach front, and after barely scratching its skin the Dragon enters a sort of trance and rips your heart from your chest - magically sealing your life to his as you walk the Earth as the immortal Arisen.

Then... The game just kind of pitters around for about 20 hours.

Someone on the Gamefaqs forums once called this game Devil May Skyrim of the Colossus." That's really the best way to describe it. The director of the original Devil May Cry games took battle system concepts from that series and applied them to semi-Bethesda style open world. I say "Semi" because it's not packed with the same kind of a hundred half-written mini stories that you'd find in Skyrim. There's only one major city - two civilized settlements in total - and only a handful of dungeons. What's there is very well thought out with top notch level design
date: but the biggest draw is the combat.\n\nDragon's Dogma isn't perfect
recommended: but it's interesting. If Dark Souls is the pinnacle of RPG Combat sitting at a 10
hoursPlayed: and if Devil May Cry was put on the same list with an 8 or 9
voteText: I'd put Dragon's Dogma at a 7 or an 8. While Dark Souls is more about positioning and timing
helpfulPercent: Dragon's Dogma is about weakpoints and how to address them. One of the selling points is your ability to grapple enemies and when it comes to the giant Cyclops or the titular Dragons that means climbing all over them - Shadow of the Colossus Style. Every single enemy is different and needs to be dealt with differently - and with 3 play-styles with variances between 9 different vocations (classes) you quickly learn the game's rock paper scissors advantages and disadvantages. Add in an ingenious party system consisting of a personalized pawn and any online pawns you can hire from other players and you end up with a system far deeper than any of its individual elements.\n\nAs mentioned it isn't perfect though. There's no camera control when you're climbing on things
votesHelpful: and your greatest enemy quickly becomes the walls around you and its affect on your viewpoint. The direction you move is relative to your character's body - tank control style - making navigating the navel of the giants something akin to walking around with a mushroom on your head in Earthbound. Combat difficulty can simmer at too easy for a long time until you find an enemy capable of combo killing you in three shots. But the biggest offender I think is the potion system. The game lets you carry supplies at the expense of your own movement
votesTotal: but it's almost never bad enough that you aren't carrying around a pack full of cure-alls at any given time. Potions are accessed through the pause menu and heal you instantly - acting as a sort of "Reset" for combat gone awry. In the endgame you're even given an abundance wakestones that literally bring you back to life if you die - and you have enough carry weight that I was toting at least 5 of these everywhere I went. I often intentionally would die as a tactical decision.\n\nAt its best
votesFunny: the combat is deep and challenging
commentsCount: but even at its worst its certainly more fun than the cat-fight flailing you find in other open world RPGs.\n\nIronically though

reviewText:
This game is hands down my favorite ARPG.  JARPG.  Whatever.  Point is, I bought the base version on the PS3 when it came out.  Then I bought the expansion.  Then I told my friends I'd buy it again if it came out on PC.  Years later, it came out on PC.  Bought ii again like I said I would.  Played the game multiple times through, again.  Very few games keep my attention long enough to play it multiple times, even with NG+ like this game has.

There's no RPG I would rather have.   Here's hoping we here in the west get either Dragon's Dogma Online, or Dragon's Dogma 2.  Both, preferably.  I'll buy it all.

This game has many flaws, but DD:DA does so many things right that I'm not even bothered by it.

I feel like I should elaborate, but many other reviews have already done that for me.  The most important things the game has, in my opinion, is the character freedom, the replayability, and the combat.

By character freedom, I mean that the character customization is pretty good.  It's not Black Desert good, but this game lets you do things for characters that not even BDO will let you do.  Character height and weight has an impact on certain stats, though they're not really game-changing.  There's an item you can buy that lets you change (Entirely, even gender) your character and your main pawn from the main menu.  Later on you can buy one that's permanent.  This is extremely important for me.  Also, you can change your class and equipment at any time in town.  This is also very significant.

Replayability is pretty self explanatory.  The game has some things that you might miss out on in your first playthrough, and NG+ is actually lore-friendly in this game.  I won't spoil it, but after you beat the game, it'll all make sense.  There are multiple endings, but only one lets you continue on with NG+, the 'true' ending, whatever that means.

Combat.  The only thing I'll say about combat is, if it isn't fun, I wouldn't play a game through 7 times.  Being able to change classes in town is also a huge part of this.  You can literally switch your whole playstyle (including your party synergy) with a visit to a town.

tl;dr - This game is worth the money.  I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
If you’re looking or considering something that will last you in terms of game play, and be value for money, then this game plus the expansion is a great place to start.

With no required expensive dlcs or season passes, the amount of content you will receive alone is worth the entrance fee.

People will argue there are better games out there, I would argue for the quality of content and time verse money ratio, there aren’t many.

I found this an easy game to pick up, but a hard game to put down.

If you get this on sale, it’s a steal.

reviewText:
I'll start this review by saying that I never played the console version of this game, so I have no idea what, if anything, has changed between the console release and this one.

First of all, the quality of this port is fairly high, very good optimisation, a decent selection of graphics options and on-screen prompts for keyboard+mouse and controller depending on what control system is in use.

The gameplay itself is really good, in the 12 hours (as of this review) there hasn't been a dull moment between killing monsters and doing quests. The combat is fun and there's a lot of variety in weapon choice.

There is a few issues I have with the game, the first being that it takes a long time to travel around the map. Fast travel items are somewhat rare (at least near the start of the game) which leaves you with running around the game world. The other issue I have is that the auto-save system is a bit infrequent compared to other games and can take some getting used to at first, so manual saving often is recommended to avoid losing progress.

Overall, I think this game is great and it made me, for the first time in a long time, spend an entire day with one game

reviewText: This review is less about the game as it is about the quality of the port. I played over 100 hours of this on PS3 and the one thing that I always felt held the game back was the hardware it was running on... it was too much for that old system to handle. I'm happy to say this port is AMAZING. Capcom did an incredible job with it. Runs like LIQUID with everything maxed. Plenty of PC-specific options including an FOV slider. I really feel like I'm seeing this game for the first time seeing it in 1080/60. This game is truly a gem and now that it's on PC, it's a true masterpiece.

reviewText:
It's a masterpiece.

My favorite Xbox 360 game of all time and after already investing 200+ hours on console this game was a MUST BUY on PC.

A huge open world, 9 Vocations ( classes ), towering enemies you can climb, already punishing gameplay on normal difficulty, hundreds of hours of quests, NG+... This game is pretty much the inofficial lovechild of Skyrim and Dark Souls.

Better graphics, silky smooth 144fps, awesome keyboard+mouse controls, OFFLINE MODE ( lookin at you Square ) and for ONLY 30€ including the DLC....

It's pretty much a MUST BUY ON PC if you love good ARPGs.

reviewText:
The game is solid. After playing Dark Souls 2 for the last month and wanting to play Dark Souls 1 without terrible jittering and bad overall port performance, seeing a japanese developer do a PC port right is truly a breath of fresh air.

The textures are not beautiful. In fact, some of them seem damn atrocious. For example, in the subtitles, you can see the discoloration of pixels around lettering... But the game flows well. The higher framerate really helps make up for lesser textures by making the game feel responsive and smooth as far as game experiences go.

This game also does something that I've long desired in games. Too often game developers fall back on cinematics to do the big awesome stuff. You'll get into a fight of some sort, and when it is over it cuts to a neat scene of the character jumping up and doing some fantastic gymnastics to kill the enemy... In Dragon's Dogma though, it is a lot more like Shadow of the Colossus. There are mechanics for -you- to climb up on the enemy, to get up to his head and attack him from there. It isn't just you watching a cinematic of that being done, -you- do it. In that way, this game is already leagues ahead of so many action games that rely upon cinematics or QTEs for awesome character actions.

All around, this is a good game. I recommend it. My only true issue is just how many tutorials there are. I'm 2 hours in, and still getting assaulted with pop ups telling me about how to do different things. However, to be fair it is possible to turn those off... It just seems like by 2 hours in, I should be past the tutorial" stage in the game.

Get it. It is an excellent deal at $30."

reviewText:
Buy this game. Hopefully Capcom will release Deep Down on PC fast after the PS2, or, even better, make a proper Dragon's Dogma sequel. OK, I'm getting ahead of myself...

Dragon's Dogma is, in short, the prototype for The Witcher 3. At least in some aspects. That's how you'll feel the first time you slide down a hill, or stand in front of a message board. It doesn't have the polish of TW3, but it sports its own unique charms and mechanics, and the combat is solid and visceral.

Visually the game holds up nicely, despite being a console title from a few years back. And knowing what a dedicated following it has, more and more advanced visual mods will be popping up for it.

The best part of the move to PC is how smooth the game runs. It's almost a completely different experience than the 20-30 frames it was getting on the consoles and plays damn smooth.

So, should you get it? An easy YES, if you're interested in any or all of the following:
- climbing massive monsters and repeatedly stabbing them in the sensitive areas whilst hanging for dear life
- spending hours in the character creator in order to get your and your pawn's facial features just right
- did I only now mention the pawns"?.. no other game offers sharing your fallower with other players like that
- conducting crazy fashion experiments with your gear
- some of the best combat in any action RPG
"

reviewText:
I don't often gush about my favorite games, mostly because I haven't had a whole lot of time to play games in the past decade or so. However, I was so excited for this game to come out that I'm going to act like a sellout fanboy for a second so as to explain its greatness.

(As an aside: myself and the DD:DA community would like to see a sequel, and a PC port 4 years after initial release makes us very hopeful.)

Including the PC version, I have purchased this game three times now, plus owning the art book. The original on PS3 in 2012, the PS3 GOTY edition just before my daughter was born, and now the PC edition which is has all the previous content and then some.

The best way I can describe the gameplay is to say Dark Souls + Monster Hunter. From Software's Dark Souls is my favorite game of the last decade (100% PS3 and PC, approx. 400 hours of gameplay), and though I've never gotten into Monster Hunter, there are some JRPG/MMO mechanics that are straight from that franchise (also, it's Capcom, so that makes sense).

The best way I can describe the world and feel" of the game? D&D. This is the best analogue to Western-Fantasy role playing that I've ever encountered (heh

reviewText:
Dragons, harpies, cyclops and a plethora more of dangerous creatures litter the world of Dragon's Dogma. You start
the game with a short intro showing the end of the life of the arisen before your arisen's era. You then proceed to
creating your own character. You're given plenty of options to create a large variety of different options to create
a character unique to yourself.

After the intro segment and creating your own character, you will choose between 3 archetypes, which can later split
off into even more archetype varieties later on into the game. When you're released into the world of Dragon's Dogma,
there is nothing short of tons to explore and see. You're not restricted to staying in a very small area at the start,
but you're actually only limited by your own power. If you chose, you could run off into lands filled with extremely
dangerous creatures from the get go, however, it's unadvisable. Not only do the normal creatures grant you lots to fear
and respect, but the day/night cycle will leave you to fighting for your life if you're caught in the dark. Once night
falls, a whole new group of enemies can be found and they are no push over. All of your journeys need to be planned to
avoid the night at much as possible.

The gameplay is centered around a really nice action RPG system where you can customize your attacks, weapons, armor,
spells and even all of your pawn's as well. Your pawn is a tag along buddy you gain access to very early in the game.
You're not only able to customize thier appearance, but you also choose thier archetype, spells and equipment. The pawn
is used in the game's online mechanic where people can hire your pawn based on thier level, class, spells, equipment and
even quest knowledge, which they will learn as they are used in each quest. After they served thier purpose in the world
of the player who hired them, they can be sent back to you with new knowledge and even items the player chooses to send
them back with.

Regretably, that is the only bit of online experience to speak of. This game could have gained a ton from a proper co-op
online mode.

::Pros::
-character customization
-action combat that goes beyond mashing a button over and over
-many hours worth of gameplay to really give you your money's worth
-replayability
-interesting spells and abilities

::Cons::
-graphics feel a little dated
-no proper online mode
-items are set in places instead of randomized from drops
-crafting system feels limited
-night cycles can become a hassel to deal with when you want to just explore

All in all, I have to say the game is a definite buy. There are a ton of hours to be dumped into the game. This game
should be pretty accessable to pretty much anyone, so there isn't any level of skill needed, so if you're a pro gamer
or a person who only plays a few hours a week, you're good to go with this title.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Dragon's Dogma experience is essentially this: Do you like giant mythical monsters? Do you like the idea of climbing on said monsters and knocking the sense out of them? Do you like capes? Do you like the idea of killing things while looking fabulous in many capes? If yes, to any of these, buy this.

This game is a combination of Dark Souls inspired (albeit NOT near as punishing) + Monster Hunter, with a flat, lackluster story. Fortunately, the latter is easily overlooked by the sheer amount of quality content/gameplay the game is stuffed to the brim with. In-depth character customization and plenty of variation in gameplay, as there are 9 classes to pick and/or switch between.  Not to mention the unique Pawn system, which gives you more incentive to play and make your Main Pawn the most badass creature killer possible. I put well over 100 hours into the PS3 version back in the day, so this was an instant purchase when I heard it was spontaneously heading to PC (years after release).

Since writing this, Capcom have already patched the game twice, so it is clear they are showing some support to the PC crowd. A lot of love and time went into developing this port, so I hope the success of this game on PC earns it the long, overdue, sequel it deserves.

reviewText: Dragon's Dogma is a confusing beast. On one hand it feels unpolished, featuring a boring overworld with very few actual locations of interest, a stupid stamina system that makes traversing annoying and some unfortunate mechanics that make you question why they even bothered implementing them (the romance" system being the chief offender). On the other hand
date: the aspects of this game that work feel so good that the faults seem almost trivial. The game feels like a perfect mix between western fantasy and Japanese game sensibility
recommended: a classic tale of knights and dragons with a twist rooted in an interesting meta-narrative. Do you want to be a mighty sorcerer conjuring tornadoes and summoning meteors? You can do that. Do you want to be the sneaky ranged who climbs beasts with their daggers and shoot down flying fiends with their bow? You can do that. Do you want to be Guts from Berserk? You can do that.\n\nUltimately
hoursPlayed: Dragon's Dogma is a game that requires some patience to not only get into
voteText: but also to persevere through
helpfulPercent: but if you are a fan of a varied action RPG with the feel of DnD roleplaying and a very interesting AI companion system you should probably buy this."

column23: especially in comparison to the Witcher III or... Skyrim... but its combat system is miles beyond any other open-world RPG I've played yet. If you're not a fan of the Witcher-patented "roll and spam X" or the Batman-patented "dodge and spam Y
column24:
then you might just adore the change in pace Dragon's Dogma offers. You may choose from nine different classes: three basic, three advanced, and three hybrid, each with their own unique moveset. Your three pawns will also fulfill these classes (though they cannot be the hybrid ones), so it's always a good idea to have a healer on the squad.
Where the game truly shines is in the boss battles. The sparse nature of the plot isn't for everyone, but I'll be damned if the boss battles aren't. In endgame, dragons aren't bosses, they're regular enemies. The epicness of every fight against a true monster cannot be understated, and it puts everything in the games listed prior to shame. You will feel a true sense of camaraderie with your pawns when, as a Fighter, you're clinging on to a Griffin for dear life as it begins to take off, soaring quickly above the heights from which you can safely fall, when, with a flaming storm of arrows, your Ranger companion will bring it down swiftly to the ground, allowing you to safetly jump off and regain your stamina. The music swells, your adrenaline builds, and you keep on fighting.
I cannot recommend this game enough. Please consider buying it so that Capcom will see the want for a sequel, or, at the very least, to port the MMO over to the West. If you enjoy the pure fighting spirit of TENGEN TOPPA GURREN LAGA- I mean, Dark Souls, then you should pick it up.
WHERE'S MY GRIFFITH AND GATTSU ARMOR, CAPCOM?

reviewText: A very good PC port, in my opinion. This game is very much open world and has excellent character creation.  You can spend hours playing this game and still find new things.  The New Game + option is also great and you keep all previous levels, abilities, items, etc.  The game does, however, get harder.  The Bitterblack Black Isle map is fairly challenging and might make you rage a fair bit.  You can also pick people up (including children) and throw them off cliffs so if that's a thing you enjoy, this is the right game for you.\n\nOne of the weaker points of Dragon's Dogma is, to some extent, the story. Some of the quests can be fairly repetitive (not as bad as saving settlements in Fallout 4).  One thing also missing from this port is the lack of Japanese voices (hearing Wolves hunt in packs
date: Arisen" gets more annoying in English than it does in Japanese) but there is a mod out there for that
recommended: as well as a variety of other things.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: if you're a fan of action role playing games that you can spend hours in

reviewText:
This game was developed by Capcom staff members that had previously worked on Breath of Fire, Devil May Cry and Resident Evil.

What does make this game amazing?
+ First of all, the gameplay
+ Interesting story
+ Interesting quests
+ Interesting dungeons
+ Beautiful soundtrack
+ Giant monsters
+ Vocation system. Even you can go for hybrid vocations e.g. Magic Archer
+ Pawn system. You make your own pawn, people rent, you can rent others' pawns as well
+ 4k support while the console version was 1280x608p
+ 60fps while the console version was between 15-30fps

I highly recommend this game for every RPG fan!

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is an educational point and click adventure set in the world of Middle Earth. Perfect game for a 9 year old like me :))))

Useful things I learned :OOO
1. Goblins are weak to fire.
2. Goblins are weak to ice.
3. Goblins are weak to both ice and fire.
4. Fire sets a harpy's wings ablaze.
5. Hydras have multiple heads.
6. Ogre's get excited over women.
7. Falling from too great a height can kill you.
8. Many have lost their lives from falling too great a height.
9. The animals of the field are a good source of meat.
10. Pawns ♥♥♥♥ing suck.

Things I liked :)))))))
+The soundtrack is great. Masterworks all, you can't go wrong.
+Great animations for the monsters and the attacks. Some of the spells are completely devestating and badass.
+Great combat. A mix of Dark Souls and Shadow of the Colossus. You get to climb the monsters.
+Good variety of vocations" (classes). Helps the game's replay value and adds more interesting variation to combat and strategy
date: \n+New Game+ means you can start a new game with your old character
recommended:
keeping the levels and equipment from your last playthrough.
+Map is pretty big. Lot's to explore and the loot can be great.
+Character customization is great. Characters are fully customizable.
+Dragons aren't a joke unlike the ones in Skyrim. Battles can last up to an hour depending on the difficulty and how strong you are. Killing a dragon can be very rewarding.
+Modding community seems fairly active

Things I didn't like :(((((
-No online. Would love to play with friends rather than some faggy pawns.
-Pawns are ♥♥♥♥ing annoying. You can mute them but they're still useless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. At least the mages can heal you and the warriors can distract the monster for you but they die constantly and do the dumbest things. It is painful to see my idiot pawn hacking at the feet of a dragon or standing behind a drake's tail. Fun to throw them off cliffs though.
-Voice acting is mediocre. It does add a humorous charm however
hoursPlayed: especially with your pawns repeating the same thing over and over and stating the obvious. Grigori has a badass voice though.\n-Travelling can be tedious. You need to run around the map to get to places and it's pretty big
voteText: after a while the same enemies will spawn in the same place. You need port crystals to choose where you want to fast travel but you need to travel to that location first and then place the crystal there. Port crystals are also fairly rare. The Eternal Ferrystone is what you use fast travel. It's useful but you'll still need to travel around by foot. I suggest getting a mod so you don't consume stamina while running otherwise you'll be running out of breath alot.\n-The main story is fairly weak. It starts to get better once you first meet Grigori but that's quite close to the end game.\n-Characters aren't very interesting. Pawns are boring. Other than a few characters like Ser Mercedes
helpfulPercent: Grigori or that Jester
votesHelpful: everyone is either completely lifeless and dull or they're just annoying.\n-Ogres don't look like Shrek. This is completely unforgivable and it gives these onion lovers a bad image
votesTotal: they are portrayed as giant dumb gorillas. Very disrespectful and very inaccurate. I hope someone out there completely re-models the Ogres to look like Shrek.\n\nOverall despite the flaws
votesFunny: I enjoyed the game and I now know that falling off cliffs can kill you.\nI think it deserves 7.5 horny Ogres out of 10.\nRemember

reviewText: Love it. I seriously love this game so much. I hope the online version gets an English patch soon. I had never played Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen and only found out about it a few weeks before it came to PC. Now I play it 24/7 like I'm going to die if I don't. One thing about it though.. the only problem that I have run into was at the final battle(no spoilers) when I didn't pack enough supplies. I ended up rage quitting hard mode to try normal. Then I realized that Normal isn't much easier, so I just lost out on the bonuses of Hard Mode for no reason and all because you can't set it back to hard mode but instead have to start hard mode all over from the beginning of the whole game.  So that's what I have to do... If I had multiple save files, I could have just gone to one of them and saved my hard mode. To be honest, I don't even know if I would change that, though. That feeling of loss I experienced was awe inspiring. When first I was learning how to play, the difficulty was the best part, and that just amplified it. It has driven me to madness. I am soaked in willpower to finish what I started and I imagine my failure has folded me through dimensions to start over again. Great game 10/10 would rage quit and start over again.

reviewText:
I'm redoing this review as my original was something I posted quickly to say I recommended it I needed to play the PC port more first.

So, the game is a wonderful RPG type game. It has many enticing features of the combat and pawn system. You can have a multitude of combat possibilties based on your chose of class and how your pawns behave in combat which is very rewarding for me. Early on when you're consistently changing pawns because only your main pawn levels with you the other 2 pawns you have to hire things are always changing up because even if you hire the same class the new pawn will behave differently in the world from small mannerisms to combat roles. Some end up sucking and you have to return as fast as possible and some you wish you could keep.

The story isn't The Wicther 3, but it still very good in itself. The world is set-up very well in my opinion to optimize exploration and feeling freedom but not having too much land to traverse for quests.

The graphics are dated given it is from 2012 but modders are already working on that.

Modding anything beyond the visuals is not recommended because anything that messes with the pawns(unless you play offline)can corrupt them and mess with someone elses game if they rent your pawn.

The game did very well on consoles back in 2012 and I remember spending a whole summer on it. This PC port is running very well and perfroms better than the console versions did.

It has some small quirks about it some people may not enjoy and don't, but it is well worth anyone's time to try out in my opinion!
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: When I saw the preorder for this game, I made a sound I am not proud of. Then I worried it wold be a bad port and spent a month worrying. It was finally released, and I sang and danced. For several hours while my pathetic internet downloaded this game. Again, something I am not proud of.\nThis game is probably one of my favorite games of all time, and that is saying something. I had hundreds of hours on the Xbox version of the base game, and then sold it to get the Dark Arisen also on the Xbox, promptly beating it again. Now it is for the PC and I rejoice. I wish they made more games like this.\nHow many other games can you latch on to the side of a cyclops, and make it stagger off a cliff by stabbing it in the face, then use it as a meat shield to protect from the 100 foot fall? It is epic. I cannot recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
Note: Although my play time is not much at the moment, I played the game back in the Xbox 360 years ago.

What happens when you combine the open world design of TES games with the gameplay and creature design from Monster Hunter? Dragon's Dogma is what happens. One of the best games from last gen gets a makeover and technical improvements, while adding all the dlc and expansion content all into one excellent game. The result is a game chock full of content and excellent hack and slash" gameplay.

Dragon's Dogma's basic gameplay and questing is more or less like your standard open world rpg. You visit towns
hoursPlayed: kill giant monsters
voteText: etc. What sets it apart
helpfulPercent: however
votesHelpful: it's the pawn system. The Arisen (Player character) has the power to invoke pawns
votesTotal: which are much like your traditional party members. You can fully customize your own pawn and they "grow" as you play the game. You can also take on the pawns from other players online. It's a mechanic that seems to incorporate some ideas from Pokemon/Tamagotchi into developing a character. It's a very unique feature that should be used in more games.\n\nThe game is not without its faults. Despite getting texture and framerate improvements
votesFunny: the game's age is notable. Not only in the visual aspects but the mechanics as well. The menu system is somewhat archaic
commentsCount: players used to the latest games might find it a bit hard to get used to. That said
column16: the gameplay is still amazing. Like I mentioned before
column17: this game more or less combines the best elements of a TES game with the best elements of a MH game
column18: the result is a very satisfying combat. Few games give you thrills like climbing onto a dragon to hack its head.\n\nAll in all
column19: Dragon's Dogma is a gem. It's not for everybody
column20: but for the audience that it's aimed
column21: it's definitely a must buy."

reviewText:
Back when this game was first released in 2013 or so for the last-gen consoles, I basically wore myself out on let's plays of the game, seeing as I hadn't really thought it would be a very good game. Needless to say, I was incorrect. It seemed like a really amazing game, and I was rather upset it was never ported to PC.

Fast forward to like 3 days ago, when i see this game for sale, and having forgotten it existed, I was rather confused. I knew I had heard the name before, but was it a good game?

WAIT, I KNOW THAT GAME.

I instantly sprung to the purchase button and preloaded it, awaiting the release day. And now that I've finally gotten my hands on the game for myself, I am SO, SOO glad it was ported over. It's an amazing game, and needless to say, my recommendation may not be in-depth, but hopefully my little story has won you over.

TL;DR: Is gud.

reviewText:
Played this back on PS3 when the awefull frame drops would get you killed in a fashionable manner, and the load times gave you time to walk the dogg, groom the dogg, train the dogg, see it succumb to old age.
It was an awesome game.

And now we have an awesome pc port wich runs buttersmooth and it can be pushed to look somewhat better then the PS3 version, specially by forcing your gpu driver to top things off like better AA etc.
Sure theres ''pop in'' but onhoustly i couldnt care less myself.

And fighting bosses doesnt require you to poke their feet till they die, just climb them and poke their eyes out.
I love the dragon age series and the witcher but dragons dogma just has something going for it.
So one of the best fantasy RPGs ive ever played.
