reviewText: So i dont write reviews very often but this game is a gem to me...back when i still had my X360 i wished for this game so hard and when i finally saved some money and bought it i was just amazed. For a japan game it has wonderfull and at places even dark atmosphere especialy once you get to bitterblack island when you will get your ♥♥♥ handed to you on silver plate. I played this game after nearly beating Dark Souls and sinking nearly 300 hours into it with multiple characters and i gotta say this game is similar in many ways...the combat especialy in later stages doesnt hold your hands (fak the dragons -_-) and when you venture out at night bring your brown pants with you...and god that Post End game event...it gives the game whole new and dark feel. There is just not a lot that i didnt love about this game back then and even after all that time when it was polished a bit my love for this game is as passionate as it used to be. Also the quality of the port is stunning for such an old and japanese game...you can even rebind frikkin controller if you have direct input one O.O i was like whaaaaaat when i saw it...the framerate never goes down on me so far and my computer is not a total beast...and i know it should be sure thing with an older game but i have seen many butchered ports so i am happy to say that this one doesnt belong among them. For me this is totally a 10/10 - whoever liked the original game...GET THIS THING NOW...whoever wants to be a badass archer who is climbing on a frikkin chimmera and cutting its goat head of...GET IT TOO...And last thing...this game has like the longest final" boss fight from all the games i ever played...god my ballz were drippin with sweat during that ♥♥♥♥ o.o"

What happens when you combine the open world design of TES games with the gameplay and creature design from Monster Hunter? Dragon's Dogma is what happens. One of the best games from last gen gets a makeover and technical improvements, while adding all the dlc and expansion content all into one excellent game. The result is a game chock full of content and excellent hack and slash" gameplay.

Dragon's Dogma's basic gameplay and questing is more or less like your standard open world rpg. You visit towns
hoursPlayed: kill giant monsters
voteText: etc. What sets it apart
helpfulPercent: however
votesHelpful: it's the pawn system. The Arisen (Player character) has the power to invoke pawns
votesTotal: which are much like your traditional party members. You can fully customize your own pawn and they "grow" as you play the game. You can also take on the pawns from other players online. It's a mechanic that seems to incorporate some ideas from Pokemon/Tamagotchi into developing a character. It's a very unique feature that should be used in more games.\n\nThe game is not without its faults. Despite getting texture and framerate improvements
votesFunny: the game's age is notable. Not only in the visual aspects but the mechanics as well. The menu system is somewhat archaic
commentsCount: players used to the latest games might find it a bit hard to get used to. That said
column16: the gameplay is still amazing. Like I mentioned before
column17: this game more or less combines the best elements of a TES game with the best elements of a MH game
column18: the result is a very satisfying combat. Few games give you thrills like climbing onto a dragon to hack its head.\n\nAll in all
column19: Dragon's Dogma is a gem. It's not for everybody
column20: but for the audience that it's aimed
column21: it's definitely a must buy."

reviewText:
I've gotta say I've never played this game till now, and im kicking myself for it to. this game has got to be one of the best RPG's ive ever played. the combat system is so amazing! it's like a mix of Shadow of the Colossus meets Skyrim.

although there is no Co-Op the Pawn system is unique in its own and having other NPC's to help out is a great way to make progress in the game. having a constant feedback from the party members can be helpfull and annoying at the same time.

I really hope the modding community comes together some day to make this game Co-Op just like they are doing with Skyrim. but dispite the lack of, this is a great RPG one that i feel needs to be played.

Great game Capcom.

column29: extremely annoying
column30: or both.\n\nLet me take a little bit to explain "extremely annoying." There's a vertical room with broken stairs you climb by bridges going across the middle of the tower. You know what's the best kind of enemy to randomly spawn here? A dragon. Yep
column31: a dragon. Something that flies and crashes to the ground if you hit hard enough. That wasn't enough for ya? How about an enemy that is literally immune to damage unless you attack its weak spot which is almost never vulnerable while it debuffs you with blindness (your entire screen is a black fog
column32: and you cannot see anything except yourself) and slowness (effects walking
column33: attacking

column35: and jumping). This enemy is unavoidable and in another vertical room where you are required to be on the ground level to take advantage of its "big opening" attack just for it to then spew poison fog through the lower chamber meaning you must go back up the stairs. This fight easily took longer than the final boss of Dragon's Dogma and was mostly me running up and down the stairs just to get like 5 seconds of attacking its weak spot for a bit of damage.\n\nIf the above paragraph was not enough for you

column37: you can cancel casting but not animations once you finish the cast).\n\nIf I haven't thoroughly convinced you that Dark Arisen is at the very least frustrating
column38: the equipment you acquire during the DLC is randomly generated. You can buy strong gear in Dragon's Dogma from the vendor or will be given some periodically (or you'll find some in chests). The gear in Dark Arisen is not useable until you pay an NPC special DLC currency to "purify" for you. Once you've done that it will assign you a piece of equipment based on your vocation (class) and your main pawn's vocation. You wouldn't even KNOW that if you didn't look it up on the wiki first. If you don't like what it gives you
column39: you can kill yourself and retry for a different item.. but only if you also switch vocations. If you want a melee weapon

reviewText: Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is an RPG set in a fantasy world filled with dragons, goblins and other mythical creatures. For those who have played the original PS3 release and have dealt with the inconsistent 20 fps, you will be blown away with the smoothness and stability of the PC version. Running at a constant 60 fps and above with no frame drops even when playing a mage. I would definitely recommend this game for anyone that has a interested in RPG's or is a fan of the original release of the game.

reviewText: Now that it's at a playable framerate it feels like a different game from the original PS3 release.\nIt has very satisfying combat albeit a bit old school with its damage/defense calculation, high emphasis on knowing what you fight and exploiting its weaknesses using many many ways. It has a fun scaling system where you can climb up any big creature and attack it. Lots of exploration and fun, and i recommend it.

reviewText:
UPDATE: Soundtrack has been reviewed! Please give it a read if you would like to know about all 3 releases!

This game surprised me so much, that it's probably my favorite game ever. It's literally everything I want in a game: Action, exploration, good combat, excellent soundtrack, amazing boss fights, and all around fun. I was sold on the game the moment I latched onto a hydra's head.

Allow me to start off with a port report: This is an extremely optimzed game that puts all other Japanese ported games to shame (Aside from MGSV I love you Kojima). The textures may look dated, but realize that this game out in 2012. But don't take that in a negative light, it's by no means a bad looking game. The best way I can describe the look of this game is like a remastered PS2 game with excellent lighting. It may not look nextgen, but it looks clean and very good all around. If it helps, I'm a using a 750ti and can run the game at high settings at 60fps at 1050p. And if you have the horsepower, you can run it at 4K or 144hz with ease! Optimization at its finest!

A minor heads up for anyone using not using a 16:9 monitor: You will no doubt have black bars on something like a 16:10 monitor. There's no fix as far as I am aware sadly, but it's not as bad as the console versions. Everything looks sharp still, just with half inch borders on top and bottom.

Now, onto the story! It's pretty simple: A dragon steals your heart, and you must get it back. That's really it. You do go to the main city called Gran Soren for some quests but it feels like filler honestly. There are sidequests, but they're mostly for the money and experience. But it does get interesting at the end. Those who have experienced it know what I mean. Just trust me, the less you know the better. I'll leave the story for you to experience yourself.

Now onto the meat of the game: Gameplay. This is without a doubt the main selling point of tghe game. Seriously, all action RPGs must look at this for reference, it's that good. Best way I describe it is an excellent 3rd person action game's combat, Shadow of the Colossus boss fights, and the exploration of Elder Scrolls. With a pinch of the Souls challenge early on.

There are many types of enemies as well, each requiring a different strategy. Goblins throw rocks! Wolves hunt in packs!  Bandits gang up on you! A Drake (Dragon) will chokeslam you if you encounter one under level 20!  So what can you do to combat these? Let us discuss vocations/classes! Before that however, here's an important tip if you find enemies overpowering you:

Tis' not defeat to flee from battle
date: Master. Tis' Survival."\n\nTake that quote seriously
recommended:
you can get your revenge later.

There are 3 basic ones to start off with:

Fighter - A good tank class to defend others and yourself. Your sword can deal good damage and your shield can block pretty much anything. Not the fastest
hoursPlayed: not the slowest either. You can climb onto monsters
voteText: albeit slowly. Use this if you like to be the main offense of the party.\n\nStrider - A glass cannon
helpfulPercent: but very fast and specializes in the climbing mechanic. If you go into this game expecting Shadow of the Colossus like I did
votesHelpful: this is the class for you. You're extremely agile
votesTotal: so make use of that ability as you have next to no defense.\n\nMage - The supporter of the group. Do not underestimate this class

Accidentally hit the "Climb up really big monsters button" and pick the thief up to throw him over my shoulder.
Spend the next two hours abusing this new discovery as I try pick up EVERYONE in the village and cram them down a well or throw them into the ocean trying to feed the Brine.

Best two hours ever spent.

Oh and it also has mentally damaged sub human slaves you can ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ =D"

reviewText:
I played Dragon's Dogma before on the Xbox. I didn't like it too much. I bought it on PC to see if I could enjoy it more (after all, I *hated* Dragon Age Origins the first time I played it) and guess what? I'm not enjoying it too much on PC either.

Dragon's Dogma starts with a dragon eating your beating heart, which I consider a plus. You're alive after the attack though, and some dude appears in front of you and another dude tells you it's a Pawn, and from there you're left to your devices mostly. Pawns are not-human-but-almost drones that you can recruit for your adventures, up to four. While you'll have direct control of one of your Pawns' leveling and attributes, the other two you'll have to rehire a bunch of times. Nothing else merits much more explanation, you just go out there and kill goblins.

THE PROS:

- You can change between classes at any time and purchase new enchantments as you progress on a class, besides getting passive bonus that carry over should you decide to choose another. Same applies to your Pawn.
- Combat is pretty fun, and despite being a party based RPG, the classic triad" conventions can be broken pretty easily without much detriment.
- It's pretty. In-game cutscenes especially.
- Big enemies can be climbed in combat
date: which is fun. Some moves are geared towards working in tandem to reach higher
recommended: which is also fun.\n- Pawns comment on things
hoursPlayed:
there's a *lot* of voicework.
- Pawns will harvest for you.
- Nights are unnerving. Lanterns are cool. Detailed and gameplay-relevant character customization.

THE CONS:

- No enemy locking
voteText: meaning no strafing
helpfulPercent: meaning no manual dodging

votesFunny: can't give orders outside "go" "here" and "help".\n- AI does weird things
commentsCount:
especially running around without attacking.
- No conveyance at all when it comes to quests. Players are expected to run around and talk to a gajillion people to either get quests or advance on said quests. That translates to a lot of time running around for eventually little to no payoff.
- No control over hired Pawns eventually translates on running around some more trying to find a satisfying party setup.
- No conveyance cont'd: player is given quests without even a general direction of the mission area
column16: prompting them to either run headlong into an area that will certainly kill them
column17: rely on Pawns for quest information

reviewText:
I played this game  a lot on my Xbox 360~... I'm already Level 200 and still not bored at all <3
I have to say; It's my very favourite game!
Dragon's Dogma was a reason for me playing another  RPG's but I had to face it... There are just a few good RPG's in my opinion. But there wasn't one I enjoyed so much like Dragons Dogma!

I love the story, the character-customization, the animations. the fight-system, the graphics...
Also you're not forced to do the story all time! You're free in Gran Soren.
And well... If you played the story like 20 times you need this freedom!

To be honest, I never understood why Dragons Dogma is so underrated.

I also think it's better than Skyrim,
because Skyrim's animations are floppy, story is meh, character customization hurts in the eyes and battles are super boring! Also I'm not a graphic-♥♥♥♥♥ but let's face it: Skyrim is NOT a pretty game...
Of course there're a lot cool mods! But Dragon's Dogma is able to be much cooler without mods.

(I also can imagine the mods that'd be possible for the Dragon's Dogma PC Version! That'd be sooo awesome!)

You literally can feel all the love they put into a game!
You can find a lot of enemies of the Greek mythology, which I think is pretty cool! c:
The synchronization is pretty good even if you have to hear some quotes pretty often...
I think... that could be pretty annoying for some kind of people, but hey; You can deactivate 'em!

The only negative thing I could find was:
If you're used to huge maps like GTA V, Skyrim, Witcher and Fallout 4... then you might be dissapointed!
For people like me it's more comfortable! I love open world but I always want to know where I am!
I want my environment... comfortable and familiar and not huge and lost!

But that's just my opinion! <3

reviewText:
Weird review/opinion here, since I refunded this game but still recommend it.

The game itself seems good, the combat mechanics are good, the world seems well designed so far and the voice acting for NPCs (NOT the helpers... we'll get into that) is good. I just cannot get away from the 'Pawn' system... it seems lazy, it's sometimes annoying and just feels like a loose end even though I'm sure it will have some impact on the story later on at some point. The way the game saves and re-loads after a defeat is kind of annoying and all of these little niggles seem to add up to overshadow all of the positives I found with the game. The fights are cool, you can grab enemies or attack ones that your helpers grab, buff characters with elements to do extra damage etc, but it just seems to fall flat for me.

Recommended for general RPG fans who aren't as bothered by such details and design choices, but not so much if you've played Dragon Age Inquisition before, as I feel that game was, in general, stronger overall and seems quite similar.

reviewText:
A very well rounded port that improves vastly on the original XBOX360 and PS3 versions of the game.

Graphically, it has been unaltered, all textures and effects are as they were - this is NOT a HD remaster. The upshot is, the letterboxing found on the console version is gone, and the framerate has been uncapped, allowing for much smoother gameplay. High density particle effects no longer slow the game down to a crawl, and a surprising amount of graphical customization, often not found at all in PC ports, allows you to tweak the game to your own performance.

Gameplay wise, Dragon's Dogma hasn't changed a bit. It's still the epic monster slaying adventure it always was. Camera problems still persist throughout, unfortunately - especially when climbing larger monsters. All downloadable content for the console versions is present in the Steam release, providing further challenges and extended replayability with the Dark Arisen dungeon.

If you want an action oriented RPG that doesn't hold your hand too much, this may be the game for you.

reviewText:
The game in a whole is well ported.

The 60 FPS makes this feel like a brand new game for returning players from the last generation consoles. The graphics don't give much to look at (not a remastering). The combat is fun and evolves throughout the game which keeps fights interesting. If you're looking for an RPG that doesn't hold your hand every quest; a game that gives you the opportunity to wonder and discover for your own then this game is one you should put more research into buying.

The negatives that I found were pop in issues, and rare glitches that would cause me to stop moving. This being an old game I believe it gets a pass on these minor bugs.

reviewText:
One of my favourite PS3 games of all time~
Time to spend another few hundred hours here on PC~ >:D
Good bye real life~ XI

Review~

Music in the game is still awesome as always, really loved the sound track~
Would listen to it often, cause it feels so darn epic~

The gameplay is fantastic, though the climbing may be a little wonky; its still pretty awesome a concept and fresh for what it is even now~ ( I might say that but i am a skull splitting strider, climbing exp. not needed~ :P )

Overall, this game is still a 10/10 for me~
It entertained me once 3-4 years back and it still managed to do the same now, that in itself stands for something~

So if you haven't already bought the game, do it~
I didn't regret it and in fact was glad i pre-purchased it~
So you shan't regret this decision either, have fun~ ;D

reviewText:
Okay welcome to Dragon's Dogma the game that doesn't hold your hand like Skyrim.

The game starts you chasing through an area with tutorial where you play as a fighter.
You explore the surroundings and so on. Eventually fighting a boss" monster that i am not going to spoil.

After that you get this epic cinematic of a dragon falling through the sky. reaching your town...
Then you get to create your character who is a local fisherman in that town.
You then lose your heart to the dragon and get sent off on a magical quest to level up to reach the dragon.
Who is later your target in the future part of the game.

Not spoiling anything else about that part.

Also you get to get a "pawn" who is your servant that fights for you. An AI that learns within battle to beat your enemies. The only problem is that this "pawn" will never shut up. You can also recruit 2 other pawns (these are helpful and annoying).

At first i was playing the game without knowing that i had "skills" to do more damage. So i was fighting everything using the basic and heavy attacks... (About 2 hours in i notice RB and LB have the ability to use skills)
After i figured out that... It made every battle trivial...
Also Remember to save often as if you die... you can't respawn unless you have a "wakestone".

After fighting another 2 bosses...

You get the most annoying escort quest... It's annoying.

Once you do a series of main quests. You will unlock the best battle in the game...
THE DRAGON... He was easy to kill but falling was my downfall on several occasions...

Once you defeat him. The world changes... to become alot harder...
No spoiling anything else.

This game was enjoyable. The world felt more alive than skyrim. Even on a lower budget."

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is a decent open world rpg, it has one huge difference with other recent rpg and that is this game doesn't have fast travel. Which is very troublesome as it makes you do a lot of back tracking. Besides, a lot of npc in this game have dull speech line and same generic voice over. There are many weapon variety in DD but most of them only can be used by specific classses which is anoying. The huge space gap in the open world with nothing exciting to fill it also makes me want to quit sometimes. The world in DD is just too boring at times, most enemies are also reused mostly. The locations of each dungeons and enemy camp are all look alike. The most frustrating fact is the weight of most item as you will quickly find that you are overencumbered if you don't store your item frequently. The pawns or any other moving npc are f** stupid as well cause they will keep walking away from you whenever you want to speak to them and the pawns will always act way too ahead of you like taking all the drops and items and also runs ahead to fight enemy before you can explore the place.

Of course there are good things in this game as well like tons of character customization (as expected of most japanese rpg). Great character model and monster design. Beatiful environment even if graphics are mediocre, lots of different fighting styles and ways of aproaching things. Good combat and great ai response in combat from both your team and the enemy. The menu and HUD in this game is comfortable for players IMO, great character introduction (most of them). And the best part in this game is the story is decent and very generic but it is the old school slay the dragon type which i like a lot so good job on that. The armors and sets of clothes in this game is well design but the downside is that  the stats are very weird like my very 1st armor from my item storage ( vagabond armor and lion's spine) remains better than most of the armor i found or bought. (as of 30+ hour of play time)

All in all this game has a bit difference than most open world rpg you find these days, some of the changes are not great but some works fantaticaly. So i give this a 7/10.

reviewText:
I can't stand this game. I hate it. It's horrible. I haven't had a good night's sleep in DAYS since I bought it. On days off work, I get up, I try to resist, but it calls to me and I can't break free! I've been engulfed by the perdition that is Dragon's Dogma and good lord am I ever obsessed with it.

Honestly, I haven't been this IN to a game since 2001. And that's saying one hell of a lot. In my time waiting for a game that tickles my fancy, I've played things like Skyrim, Dark Souls, Dragon Age: Inquisition and the Witcher series-- all of them good, but none of them getting me worked up this much. Why am I so wild-eyed over Dragon's Dogma? What on EARTH could it be that makes it stand out from the rest?

The graphics aren't the absolute best. But they're not bad either. It's a good medium that focuses namely on monster animations and humbling views of the horizon. The only thing that I would say is inherently 'bad' in the graphics department is the mouth-flapping, and that can easily be ignored. I'm a child of the 90's, and I prefer blocky low-poly meshes over pre-rendered backgrounds (*winks at the PSX-era Final Fantasy classics*) over HD ultra-realistic mumbo-jumbo any day-- so it's easy for me to accept the clunky bits. It still portrays the imagery well, and in an unpretentious manner unlike SOME AAA games. But take it or leave it, while graphics do help, the GAMEPLAY tends to help more.

The gameplay being one of the main staples, of course. It really does lend itself to a more hands-on, tactile feel, and I really CAN'T get enough of it. Grappling onto enemies and stabbing 'em like in Shadow of the Colossus is just the tip of the ice berg. You have your Pawns to help you out in battle, and they really do MATTER. Not only on a tactical standpoint, but I end up caring about them, despite how annoying their banter can get-- even if I'd only JUST hired two of them. If the banter gets too much, of course, you can just turn it off. (I heard the original version of DD didn't have that option. This must mean Capcom has been listening to the complaints and wishes of players, which is AWESOME.)

But regardless of what you think about the Pawns, their AI is far more intuitive than the followers of Skyrim, or anything else I mentioned for that matter. They really effect the playing field on an extensive level, to the point where you're actually-- gods FORBID-- performing acts of TEAMWORK with them! With them at my side, and the expansively hands-on battle system, I'm actually willing to put this on a pedestal with my JRPG favorites. I lean more towards turn-based JRPGs than ARPGs, but in this I really feel like I'm putting some tactical THOUGHT into my attacks and actions in battle, rather than just swinging blindly and eventually winning because I had enough potions on me to keep my health at. (tsk tsk Skyrim, you've made a lot of mistakes, haven't you?)

Leveling is a cinch, to boot. You don't exactly feel the need to 'grind', but if you must, you can just wander about the vast plains and check out every nook and cranny until you feel ready to progress in your quest lineup. And when you're exploring, you really feel like you're exploring. NO one place looks alike, and while landmarks are sparse, they're surrounded by vast fields of VARIETY. The job(/vocation) system is easy to digest, upgrading weapons is involving and fun, and there are so many item combinations I've only touched on about 30% of it!

The story isn't all that great so far as I've gathered, it's true-- but it is still INTERESTING, and the characters are memorable, and it does have a strange, eerie feel to it a lot of the time. ...I like it. I have no qualms at all with the story direction. Even the Arisen (whom I have designed to look like a cute dark elf boy with fiery dreds) is expansively expressive, regardless of their role as silent protagonist. Actually, the Arisen reminds me of Link. Hm.

Barring the flagrant use of 'aught' and 'naught', I see nothing wrong with the dialogue. The voice acting may not be top-notch, but it still passes for its expressive voice acting and proper line delivery. Could use some background chatter sound effects in towns and cities, however. It feels really empty when you enter Gran Soren and NOBODY IS TALKING BUT YOUR PAWNS.

Anyways, lastly the MUSIC-- while it's scarce during exploration, what bits you do get to hear are MARVELOUS. You just have to keep an ear out. It doesn't go in the 'cinematic' direction that recent AAA titles have recently, which makes me glad. I'm getting sick of that kind of pretentious drivel, and it's nice to hear a soundtrack that actually carries a note without sauntering off into a fadey mess of bullcrap.

There are a few things lacking, of course. Like rain and snow, for one. Very odd not having precipitation of any sort. Another would be the ability to at LEAST set up camp in the wild. There's been many a night where I simply wished I could just find a nice spot with my Pawns and camp out. Town chatter is another thing. Perhaps the distant sound of children yelling and playing, the occasional shopkeep hollering about fresh baked bread, women and men gossiping in hushed tones on the streets-- I know it's difficult to implement, but it really needs to exist. Lastly, I need a freaking mount of some sort. It really is a long trek from one place to the next, and sometimes we just DON'T WANT TO TRAVEL ON FOOT.

Either way, I don't think we'll ever get such a thing in this game as-is. But perhaps if Dragon's Dogma gets enough attention, Capcom will start working on a sequel, and these matters will be addressed. Oh, I can ONLY hope! Please help make this little dream of mine come true, and BUY DRAGON'S DOGMA. Give it a whirl. You might really like it. Don't even wait for a sale, do it NOW.

reviewText:
First off I am yet another person that bought this when it was originally released on the Xbox 360. I later bought the Dark Arisen version and now am essentially on my third copy of the same game after purchasing the PC version of DD: Dark Arisen.

I would also like to apologize if there are any spelling or grammar errors in my review because words are hard. ME SPEAK BETTER ENGLISH OF ALL AMERICAN!


GRAPHICS: They really leave a lot to be desired. It has it's moments where the lighting looks pretty good but then you wind up somewhere else and it looks muddy and bland. On top of this the truth is that the game never really looked good graphically, even on PC the textures (though improved) are still pretty bad overall. They are still more than servicable though so this isn't a huge critisism and shouldn't bother most people.

It performs VERY well on PC and I have a constant 60 FPS on a pretty (by todays standards) meh" computer. No slow downs or performance drops when tons of stuff is happening on screen. Lots of graphical options are appreciated which is honestly very surprising to me since many ports get away with the bare minimum. You have everything that most AAA games provide which even with the dated graphics is VERY nice to see.

STORY: The story is very awkward feeling at the start. I can never tell if this was intentional to make the player feel like they truly are somewhere unknown
date: with otherworldly things being treated as commonplace but still with a lack of understanding WHY they exist. The game tosses you into the deep end which isn't always necessarily a bad thing. You start the game and have your heart ripped from your chest and before you know it you're trying to find out why any of this happened in the first place. Why are you still alive? Why did the dragon do this in the first place? It feels like something that could either be a lucky mistake or a carefully planned sequence of events right from the start and sometimes you lose your curiosity for the story because you're too busy getting sucked into the world around you.\n\nGAMEPLAY: The example that many other action RPGs should take notes from. Enemies from small to large to behemoth are engaging and fulfilling to fight against. Whether they be goblins or bandits or cyclops or dragons there is always a feeling of intensity that a lot of other action RPGs lack. One of the other features that adds to the awesome combat is the ability to scale large enemies (freely
recommended: no quick time events) and grapple your way over to a weak point so that you can bring down one of the giants. Another great aspect of the game is that you can change your class at will once you reach the capital city and there are some skills that are cross class
hoursPlayed:
allowing for a nice mixture of freedom and the urge to invest just to see what other classes are like since you don't lose anything by doing so.

The last bit I should mention is probably just as important as the combat and how fluid it is. The pawn system of course! This is a system that allows you to create a second character however you like and choose a class for them (which can also be changed later). They learn over time based on your behaviours and will even pick up knowlege when rented by other players from the rift! This gives the game a lore friendly form of community even though the game is basically completely single player.

The game is good if you like action RPGs. There's more I could write but I'm lazy.
The end."

reviewText:
I played this on X360 beforehand (like many other reviewers) and put roughly 20 hours in to that version. I stopped playing it because *minor and kinda pointless spoiler* I couldn't save Fournival (just a side quest dude) and I wanted that gold idol.
Any who, back to my point, it released on PC which is an unexpected dream come true because there's no problems with loading times and the resolution is so much more clear and crisp. I've spent a lot more hours on this version so far and plan to spend even more.

To those who haven't played or heard of Dragon's Dogma before, if I had to explain its gameplay I would probably say it's an arcadey version of Dark Souls and Dragon Age with a more open world and has the monster climbing mechanics from Shadow of the Colossus, however it's difficult to compare or relate because this game is just so unique. It's how a good JRPG should be. The looting system is great and weapon and gear progression works well (although it's fairly easy to go to an area above your level and find overpowered loot).

The only thing I can recommend is watching gameplay as explaining it probably won't do any good.

This is one of my favourite games of last generation, I personally rate it a 9/10. Highly recommend for RPG fans!

reviewText:
In brief, this game is a gem in its generation of games because it does so well what so many games fail to do.

PROS:

Addictive Character Progression: There are 9 classes you can switch to any point in the game. You can mix and match some of the core abilities and augments you learn so you can build a character specific to your liking.

Character Aesthetics: There is enough unique equipment in the game to give you multiple chances to try out and find something that fits your aesthetics or build. I would argue that the only issue i had in this game was there wasnt enough ♥♥♥♥♥y armor for my girl lol.

Beautiful  Environment and Ambiance: the music and sound effects of some of the larger fights really bring you into the game as you become engaged with the visuals.

Unique equipment: A nice visual touch coming from the Dark Souls series is how each equipment looks unique and allows you to mix and match to find that outfit you're going for. One minor differnce between this and dark souls is that if there is an armor set in this game, its just 1 equipment item as the whole set. Whereas every individual equipment you pick up is unique in its own set giving a much more unique feel to the game instead of looting the whole 'white mage' set in a single go.

Equipment progression: In case you do find armor and weapons you would want to keep for a while, the game allows for simple weapon progression by the process of purchasing upgrades with money and materials. If you enjoy killing everything, you should have no problem finding the necessary parts.

Everything drops something you may want: Some games you kill something and it'll drop like 10 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ items you will never want to pick up and only pick up that upgraded weapon that barely surpasses your own. In this game, you often look at every item because whether its a material (junk) that you need to posses for upgrades, or herbs / potion you will find yourself needing that in the future. I find that almost all the time im picking up whatever I can unless i have an abundance of it.

Customizing your party: At any time you want to completely change you, and your pawn's classes and the ones whoa re recruited in your party you can do that by changing their vocations. This makes it a little bit more fun as you can just switch the style you play at any point in the game.

Playing with friends: While you cannot actually have a true online experience with other players in the game. You can still share your pawn with them, and they can in turn, tell you about how disasterously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your pawn was in their game. Thumbs up.

While there are a TON of things i would continue to boast about the game, I also want to insert some of the critiques and short comings of the game.

CONS:

Character Weight and Inventory Management: This part of the game is a bit painful. Characters all have their own weights they manage through equiped and inventory items belonging to that character. However if you want to continue a low level of weight, you often have to visit your inventory to move all Materials or other items onto another character and theres no quick way to do that. The AI of your party will also pick up items and thats a blessing, but they wont scour the room and pick up everything like you would.

Story Dialog: while the short quests make sense and your interaction with NPCs seem all fine. A lot of the cut scenes with your character make you think your character is either autistic or mute. Normally this would be totally fine as this whole game has a Dark Souls feel to it, and nobody says ♥♥♥♥ in that game lol.

All in all, I played this in 2012 and again and I didnt think I would enjoy it again as much as i did before. Even more with the DA expansion.

reviewText: Dragon's Dogma will remind you of how much you love that old-school pen and paper RPG feeling of reckless adventure and the classic fantasy tropes, and then it'll kick your ♥♥♥ as you both reminisce lovingly. The character customisation is excellent, and the Pawn system, though definitely flawed (and, as of this review, broken) is a stroke of genius. I think Dragon's Dogma may be the absolute definition of a flawed gem. If you're a fan of the genre, as I am, and love the throwback to the classic D&D tropes and monsters, as well as the gather-your-party-and-venture-forth mentality, you'll be in heaven. Understandably, for those for whom this game doesn't play on such nostalgia, you may be wondering what the fuss is about.

reviewText:
This is an incredible game.
CAPCOM has done the PC gaming community a solid in bringing what might possibly be the best ARPG in the last 10 years to the PC platform. It has the open-world exploration that is reminiscent of games like Skyrim. It has awesome loot that is reminiscent of Diablo II/III. It has great tight combat controls that is reminiscent of DMC. But what sets DD:DA apart from those other games is the pawn system. The asynchronous-multiplayer" aspect is one of the coolest features.
Pros:
+Tight gameplay. I wish Elder Scrolls and Dragon Ages had combat like this.
+Awesome visually impressive spells
+Pawn system
+Loot system
+Avatar customization options (seriously more games need to look at how DD:DA 	does layered armor/clothing).
+Day/Night cycle that actually is meaningful. (lamps are a neccesity in this game).
+Vastly improved graphics on the PC vs the old console versions along with vastly improved loading times           especially if  installed on an SSD.
+Replayability. This game is made to be played multiple times with NG++++

Cons:
-Story is not quite as compelling as say a Dragon Age game
date:
but it is serviceable and at times can be compelling.
-I wish they had more than just one "multiplayer bosses" (Ur Dragon). This idea is 	great and I wish they had expanded upon it a bit.

All in all
recommended: it is one of my favorite games in years. I cannot recommend it enough.\n"

reviewText: Dragons dogma appears to be a regular game, nothing special, and it is at first, graphics are not impressing anyone, the story is forgettable, voice acting and sound design are average at best (except for the music itself which is stunning and very unnusual for a game like this) and its overall presentation will make you doubt what ill tell you, but this game is actually amazing because its carried hard by its best aspect: the gameplay, everything about it feels great, movement is fluid, theres a party system in the game so you can have yourself plus up to 3 AI companions beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything that moves, theres a big variety of classes to choose all of which have many different and unique skills that look and feel great(you can actually feel some weight to your weapons when using a skill). Combat and exploration are what this game is all about, if thats not your main focus on a game stay away from this, if not have fun, i know i have!

reviewText:
Bought Dragons dogma on release for 360. Was stolen, bought Dark arisen for PS3. Now I have it on PC. The game was good enough I bought it and played it through multiple times on 3 platforms.

Overall this is a wel pieced together game. The more I play it the more of the story I ucover, and even now I'm still exploring new places. The combat is interesting, and with the ability to swap between 9 classes keeps it fresh.  Like items, they have tons of useful ones to ease your run through. Fightings too tough? Summon in a character made by another player to aid you on your quest. Want a light fun game to play? Run through it having fun. Looking for something heavy? Take the time to do side missions, and learn more about what happens in the world of gransys and min max your arisen for maximum effect.

All in all it's a great game, with a good appeal for many players who enjoy action rpgs. It's just a question of how deep you want to go.

reviewText:
Awesome game overall, but definitely didn't reach it's full potential. I loved the exploration and wonder of the game. The obtuse nature of how the game is explained was a positive for me as well. It took me a good 15 hours to understand how things worked. This may be a turn off to some folks.

The environment is incredible, and I don't think I've ever had more fun exploring a world in a game. Stumbling upon some crazy new monster or hidden ruins is always a rush of excitement.

The combat is technically fine, but didn't seem very refined to me (I played as a strider, assassin, and fighter). And the bosses and monsters are amazing in their design and epic in their scale, however boss fights can be EXTREMELY tedious and take an incredibly long time.

It's a game that I had a ton of fun with and would recommend to anyone who enjoys action rpgs. I really hope they finally release a real sequel that refines all the things that the first got so right.

reviewText:
If you're on the fence about buying this game, if you're wondering whether or not it's worth the money...IT IS.

Don't get me wrong, it has its flaws. This game starts off S-L-O-W and traveling to new places is fun the first couple of times because you're seeing all these places and enemies for the first time and you're learning new ways to fight them...but without strategically placing portcrystals around the map, traversal will become a hassle.

That's it for the negative!

The epic music keeps you in the zone, the rewarding feeling of discovery will keep you wanting to venture further and slay more and more enemies. From the small goblins to the massive Griffons, every fight feels just great. The amount of armor/weapons is awesome and were different enough to make every piece feel completely different.

Here's one of many unique experiences I had while playing through new game:
I was on a narow pathway high on a mountain
date: accompanied by my three pawns. A massive
recommended: armored cyclops stands our way. The battle begins. My main pawn grabs hold and starts to climb the beast in order to reach its eye
hoursPlayed: its weak point. She starts hitting away at its helmet but this only enrages it. It slings its oversized club wildly
voteText: throwing the other two pawns off the mountain and to their deaths. I bring it down by hacking at its legs until the beast falls. My main pawn and I were victorius but we take a moment to remember our fallen comrades."\n\nMoments like these are what make Dragon's Dogma a MASTERPIECE. I would highly recommend you give this game a try. You won't regret it."

reviewText:
I remember seeing a video of Dragon's Dogma for PS3 back in 2013 and thinking 'damn it, why isn't this on PC?' - 3 years later, I got my wish as DD: Dark Arisen has finally been released on Steam/Windows.  While this could have been a case of 'too little, too late' - as is often the case with years-late PC ports - it is my pleasure to say that this is an extremely competent release, with a wealth of graphic options and extremely well thought-out controls.  And more importantly, DD:DA is a really fun and original RPG that brings a lot to the dance.

Right away I noticed that DD has a very fluid, weighty combat system with a number of vocations (specializations/classes) and abilities for both primary and secondary weapons - it adds up to some of the most enjoyable battles I've seen in an RPG, in fact.  And you'll have plenty of chances to enjoy it, as basic enemies are plentiful and often a very real threat - as I learned when a pack of regular wolves tore my mage/healer pawn to bits and then mauled me as I tried to help him.

DD:DA also has some of the most insane boss fights that I've seen - for example, scarcely 3 hours into the game my character is taking a nap, only to be awoken by the commotion of a dinosaur-sized Hydra attacking the town she was in.  I watched helplessly as it swallowed one of my pawns, killed several guards and in general wrecked the place.  It wasn't until I blew off one of the Hydra's cow-sized heads with a barrel of explosive powder that the beast relented.  I actually said Wow..." out-loud as I watched this unfold.

That brings me to one of the key selling points of DD:DA
date: pawns - the legion of companions you'll have at your disposal.  To my surprise they are incredibly well-done
recommended: using abilities and strategies to a degree that would rival human players
hoursPlayed: and I actually enjoy the constant stream of banter and comments that they make.  Yes
voteText: it absolutely gets monotonous at times ("This road is shared by guards and fishermen!") but ironically
helpfulPercent: it makes them feel less like pawns and more like actual characters.  I also love that you get to create a permanent pawn with the same degree of detail and finetuning as your own character... that was a very cool touch
votesHelpful: IMO.  I've said for years that I'd like a game which allows you to create your own companions
votesTotal: so it was surprising that DD:DA granted that wish.\n\nSo what's wrong with the game
votesFunny: you ask?  Almost 13 hours in
commentsCount: and my only real complaint is that the player character doesn't speak.  Games like Dragon Age
column16: Mass Effect and more recently Fallout 4 have cemented my preference for a speaking player character
column17: so I was a tad disappointed with DD in that regard.\n\nOh
column18: and one of my pawns got stuck on a tree for a few seconds - but she quickly found her way to me.  And in the game's defense
column19: I was taking an extremely unorthodox path to reach my destination.\n\nI could write much
column20: much more about the game
column21: but the short of it is this: DD:DA is absolutely worth your money if you're a fan of RPGs.  It is both an excellent game and a great example of how to do a PC port
column22: and it is a refreshingly original take on the genre in an age of sequels and playing it safe.\n\nHere's hoping for DD2!"

reviewText:
Okay welcome to Dragon's Dogma the game that doesn't hold your hand like Skyrim.

The game starts you chasing through an area with tutorial where you play as a fighter.
You explore the surroundings and so on. Eventually fighting a boss" monster that i am not going to spoil.

After that you get this epic cinematic of a dragon falling through the sky. reaching your town...
Then you get to create your character who is a local fisherman in that town.
You then lose your heart to the dragon and get sent off on a magical quest to level up to reach the dragon.
Who is later your target in the future part of the game.

Not spoiling anything else about that part.

Also you get to get a "pawn" who is your servant that fights for you. An AI that learns within battle to beat your enemies. The only problem is that this "pawn" will never shut up. You can also recruit 2 other pawns (these are helpful and annoying).

At first i was playing the game without knowing that i had "skills" to do more damage. So i was fighting everything using the basic and heavy attacks... (About 2 hours in i notice RB and LB have the ability to use skills)
After i figured out that... It made every battle trivial...
Also Remember to save often as if you die... you can't respawn unless you have a "wakestone".

After fighting another 2 bosses...

You get the most annoying escort quest... It's annoying.

Once you do a series of main quests. You will unlock the best battle in the game...
THE DRAGON... He was easy to kill but falling was my downfall on several occasions...

Once you defeat him. The world changes... to become alot harder...
No spoiling anything else.

This game was enjoyable. The world felt more alive than skyrim. Even on a lower budget."

reviewText:
Seriously overlooked and underrated game!

Dragons Dogma origanally came out in 2012 for the PS3 and I loved it then and now I love it more. The PC Port is great with only minor problems such as pop-in and runs at smooth 60fps on high - max settings on a GTX 750Ti and Intel I5 4690K @ 3.5GHz. Keyboard controls were surprisingly viable to use considering its a 3rd person action RPG originally made for console. There is only one small quirk in that you cannot use the scroll wheel in menus.

Dragons Dogam has a very unique combat system which allows you to use abilites depending on your class as well as basic strong and weak attacks similar to that of dark souls. As well as that it use a system called 'pawns' which allows you to create a character who will follow you the whole game and fight for you and has a ton of customisation such as the equipment they wear, how they speak to you, how they will react to certain battle situations etc. You can then take other peoples pawns and use them in your game allowing for a party of up to 2 pawns, your pawn and you. My only problem with the game is that when you start out, it is slow going with a lot of walking and a painfully slow escort mission.

I Reccomend this game to anyone who likes action RPGs or a similar genre.

reviewText:
Despite clunky console import controls, this game runs beautifully and impressively on a fast PC.  Make sure to set your FOV slider in options to max.

In terms of gameplay, DD:DA is interesting in that the 'best part' of the game is going to be different for different people.  Basically, you have to play it for a few hours and then something will 'click' and suddenly, you'll find yourself in a very rewarding experience.

Downsides: The best plot elements are all in the last part of the game.

Advice for new players:  This is a game that is basically meant to be NG+'d.  Feel free to try and 100% it your first time through, but if you miss something, get it the next time.

reviewText:
An exceptional RPG experience, up there as one of the (almost the only) title worthy of sitting in the Souls-like genre.

The Pawn system in particular is brilliantly conceived. Pawns are non-human warriors that are uncoordinated without an Arisen to command them... you, of course, are the Arisen.

You'll create your main pawn, a character who accompanies you through your entire journey, but you can use two random pawns to pad out your party. Unlike your main, these two should be chosen for their class and how it complements you and your Main... and as they don't level alongside you, you'll need to swap them out continuously to ensure your party can survive the battles ahead. I've seen Hitler, Yennefer and a bevy of other fictional characters brought to life.

And here's the best part... those pawns you swap out belong to somebody else... and when you relinquish their service (or someone relinquishes your Main who flouts about while you're offline) they'll take back quest knowledge and monster killing experience with them. I came across a new enemy tonight and my newest pawn shouted that they were weak to fire and sure enough he was right.

Outside of that, you've got a spell system that looks utterly gorgeous as various flares and lights strobe across the landscape... and melee characters can grab onto the flanks and shoulders of larger bosses, ala Shadow of the Collosus, and work to bring them down. You can even focus on separate body parts in order to weaken a boss quicker... and you'll need to because fights can be up to 15 minutes of whittling away and trying to keep your party on their feet.

These above systems are the best bit about the game, other than the world being a single continuous space (but with small load times at major gates/doors). Otherwise it's fairly generic high fantasy and it's as pretty as you could expect from a small-title game from 2013. It's also very much a Capcom game, from the quitting the game by going back to the splash screen to hit start to get to the menu to quit... to the faintly japanese manga music in the background.


♥♥♥♥ing brilliant, in short.

reviewText:
Dragon's Dogma is one of my favorite games of all time.

It's not perfect. The story isn't the best, the graphics aren't the prettiest anymore, and the repetative dialogue can get annoying fast. Yet for me, the pure amount of fun completely overwhelms all the negative sides to this game.

Dragon's Dogma feels like a tabletop game. It's no Baldur's Gate or Pillars of Eternity, but the atmosphere is the same. Gather your party and set forth on quests in a fantastical and exciting world. Make sure you've got the right supplies, play to your class, and take down enemies (sometimes by climbing on them Shadow of the Colossus style!), then buy new gear for the next adventure.

The game runs really smoothly as well. Another plus.

reviewText:
Dragging Dog Man is the successor to the popular Nintendogs Series, and is one of the most innovative dating simulator games ever released. First released on the Commodore 64 in the year 2 (the same year of the release of popular franchise Garshasp), this game is now available on PC, including all DLC (Acronym for 'Down-Loadable Capcoms').

StoryIn Dragging Dog Man, you play as the Chosen Undead, and you must ring the bells of Awakening to succeed Lord Gwyn as the God-King of Lordran.

Yeah, that's all there is to it.

GameplayThere are a couple of ways you can deal with encounters in this game. One such way is to tactically plan out your strategy beforehand, and then carry out such plans in the midst of grueling combat with unyielding accuracy and skill. Or, the more common choice, is to fork over your wallet full of shekels and tell them 'you don't want no trouble'.

Pawn SystemA heavily advertized and touted mechanic of this game is the so-called 'Pawn System'. Put simply, it's a dumbed down game of chess, with only pawns... kind of like how Gwent in Witcher 3 is a dumbed down game of Magic: The Gathering.

The VerdictThis game is trash. Play the previous Nintendogs games, they're masterworks, all. You can't go wrong.

If you're looking for an RPG that doesn't hold your hand every quest; a game that gives you the opportunity to wonder and discover for your own then this game is one you should put more research into buying.

The negatives that I found were pop in issues, and rare glitches that would cause me to stop moving. This being an old game I believe it gets a pass on these minor bugs.

reviewText:
One of my favourite PS3 games of all time~
Time to spend another few hundred hours here on PC~ >:D
Good bye real life~ XI

And 65hrs later~
I actually almost finished the whole thing, proof i still remember the stat growth and stuff~

Review~
Upgraded graphics are welcome, with 60fps the game felt so much better though the shadows of the characters are kinda simple still~
No biggy still pretty awesome for how dated this game is~

Music in the game is still awesome as always, really loved the sound track~
Would listen to it often, cause it feels so darn epic~

The gameplay is fantastic, though the climbing may be a little wonky; its still pretty awesome a concept and fresh for what it is even now~ ( I might say that but i am a skull splitting strider, climbing exp. not needed~ :P )

Overall, this game is still a 10/10 for me~
It entertained me once 3-4 years back and it still managed to do the same now, that in itself stands for something~

So if you haven't already bought the game, do it~
I didn't regret it and in fact was glad i pre-purchased it~
So you shan't regret this decision either, have fun~ ;D

reviewText:
An exceptional RPG experience, up there as one of the (almost the only) title worthy of sitting in the Souls-like genre.

The Pawn system in particular is brilliantly conceived. Pawns are non-human warriors that are uncoordinated without an Arisen to command them... you, of course, are the Arisen.

You'll create your main pawn, a character who accompanies you through your entire journey, but you can use two random pawns to pad out your party. Unlike your main, these two should be chosen for their class and how it complements you and your Main... and as they don't level alongside you, you'll need to swap them out continuously to ensure your party can survive the battles ahead. I've seen Hitler, Yennefer and a bevy of other fictional characters brought to life.

And here's the best part... those pawns you swap out belong to somebody else... and when you relinquish their service (or someone relinquishes your Main who flouts about while you're offline) they'll take back quest knowledge and monster killing experience with them. I came across a new enemy tonight and my newest pawn shouted that they were weak to fire and sure enough he was right.

Outside of that, you've got a spell system that looks utterly gorgeous as various flares and lights strobe across the landscape... and melee characters can grab onto the flanks and shoulders of larger bosses, ala Shadow of the Collosus, and work to bring them down. You can even focus on separate body parts in order to weaken a boss quicker... and you'll need to because fights can be up to 15 minutes of whittling away and trying to keep your party on their feet.

These above systems are the best bit about the game, other than the world being a single continuous space (but with small load times at major gates/doors). Otherwise it's fairly generic high fantasy and it's as pretty as you could expect from a small-title game from 2013. It's also very much a Capcom game, from the quitting the game by going back to the splash screen to hit start to get to the menu to quit... to the faintly japanese manga music in the background.


♥♥♥♥ing brilliant, in short.

reviewText:
+ Same old Dragon's Dogma now in HD.
+ No more letterboxing.
+ You can mod your shaders and textures (just be careful of modding your Pawns since it will get corrupted on Capcom's server).
+ Wolves hunt in packs!

- No more Berserk armor sets due to licensing issues.
- Music, Dialogue and sound effects volume is too low for some reason.
- Some bugs regarding certain equipments crashing the game (male Arisens/Pawns cannot wear the Cursed King's Belt).

Hopefully Capcom can do aught to fix the minor issues, but all and all it's a great console game port.

reviewText:
I remember seeing a video of Dragon's Dogma for PS3 back in 2013 and thinking 'damn it, why isn't this on PC?' - 3 years later, I got my wish as DD: Dark Arisen has finally been released on Steam/Windows.  While this could have been a case of 'too little, too late' - as is often the case with years-late PC ports - it is my pleasure to say that this is an extremely competent release, with a wealth of graphic options and extremely well thought-out controls.  And more importantly, DD:DA is a really fun and original RPG that brings a lot to the dance.

Right away I noticed that DD has a very fluid, weighty combat system with a number of vocations (specializations/classes) and abilities for both primary and secondary weapons - it adds up to some of the most enjoyable battles I've seen in an RPG, in fact.  And you'll have plenty of chances to enjoy it, as basic enemies are plentiful and often a very real threat - as I learned when a pack of regular wolves tore my mage/healer pawn to bits and then mauled me as I tried to help him.

DD:DA also has some of the most insane boss fights that I've seen - for example, scarcely 3 hours into the game my character is taking a nap, only to be awoken by the commotion of a dinosaur-sized Hydra attacking the town she was in.  I watched helplessly as it swallowed one of my pawns, killed several guards and in general wrecked the place.  It wasn't until I blew off one of the Hydra's cow-sized heads with a barrel of explosive powder that the beast relented.  I actually said Wow..." out-loud as I watched this unfold.

That brings me to one of the key selling points of DD:DA
date: pawns - the legion of companions you'll have at your disposal.  To my surprise they are incredibly well-done
recommended: using abilities and strategies to a degree that would rival human players
hoursPlayed: and I actually enjoy the constant stream of banter and comments that they make.  Yes
voteText: it absolutely gets monotonous at times ("This road is shared by guards and fishermen!") but ironically
helpfulPercent: it makes them feel less like pawns and more like actual characters.  I also love that you get to create a permanent pawn with the same degree of detail and finetuning as your own character... that was a very cool touch
votesHelpful: IMO.  I've said for years that I'd like a game which allows you to create your own companions
votesTotal: so it was surprising that DD:DA granted that wish.\n\nSo what's wrong with the game
votesFunny: you ask?  Almost 13 hours in
commentsCount: and my only real complaint is that the player character doesn't speak.  Games like Dragon Age
column16: Mass Effect and more recently Fallout 4 have cemented my preference for a speaking player character
column17: so I was a tad disappointed with DD in that regard.\n\nOh
column18: and one of my pawns got stuck on a tree for a few seconds - but she quickly found her way to me.  And in the game's defense
column19: I was taking an extremely unorthodox path to reach my destination.\n\nI could write much
column20: much more about the game
column21: but the short of it is this: DD:DA is absolutely worth your money if you're a fan of RPGs.  It is both an excellent game and a great example of how to do a PC port
column22: and it is a refreshingly original take on the genre in an age of sequels and playing it safe.\n\nHere's hoping for DD2!"

reviewText:
I've put a lot of time into the Xbox version of this game, so don't let the hour count fool you. This game is fantastic. Lot's of fun. It's one of the few games I've played that felt like you were going on an actually adventure and facing adversity, running away from danger only to run into an even deadlier enemie.


The combat is fantastic, lots of cool skills to use with their own uses. The magic in particular is amazing, with a lot of very visually impressive and cool spells to cast. My favorite is Balero where you cause a ♥♥♥♥ing meteor to fall from the sky.

The port is really good too. 60 fps, runs real smooth. Some other small additions too like hotkeying items and what not.

If I had to ding the game on something, it would be that a lot of the game just feels...awkward? Just a little off. The story, the presentation just sometimes is a little meh. The romance system in particular is terrible, though it can be entertaining for a few minutes.

All in all, this game is fantastic. I highly recommend it. It's not perfect, but I'd love for Capcom to turn this into a franchise that gets better and better.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You owe it to yourself to play this game. It's so fun.

I can't even adequately explain why I love this game so much. It's flawed. It's absolutely flawed. It's flawed more than a lot of other games I like. But it still does what it sets out to do so ♥♥♥♥ing well that I can't ever put it down.

The combat is where the game shines the most. The combat starts out as basically Souls Lite, but once you face giant enemies, it comes into its own. This game excels at making fighting giant beasts feel incredible. It borrows climbing mechanics from Shadow of the Colossus, but watered down to make it far more accessible and easy to use instead of taxing and more realistic. It's not a realistic game at all, and that's what makes it so fun.

This was my GOTY in 2012, then my GOTY in 2013, and now I guess it's my GOTY 2016?

reviewText:
If you're a typical European gamer that loves quality RPG titles and is dying to play this game after reading the reviews and checking out its metarating, I've got one thing to tell you - you're going to hate this game. For the first few hours. And after that, you're going to adore it.

It barely follows a few (if any) established patterns in gaming and will punish you for A LOT of things but that's probably what makes it addictive as hell. Japanese obscurity and equivocal choices throughout the game only add to the collection.

Just give it a chance. Particularly if you're a fan of Souls games. You'll be wondering what the hell hooked you up on it and how you can play other games now.

reviewText:
PROS
Fantastic Combat: Every hit feels so punchy and the slowdowns are just right. Grabbing and climbing huge enemies to hit their weak points is fun. rewarding, and exciting.
Diverse Vocations: You start off with three basic archetypes, that being Fighter, Strider, and Mage, and expand to three advanced and three hybrid vocations. They all have their strengths and you should try them all out.
Pawn System: Think of this as Pokemon. I want to go fight a Griffin, but he keeps flying away when I try to hit him. I may hire another player’s mage pawn to give my team fire buffs while I have another one shoot it down with a longbow. In turn, others may rent my custom, outfitted pawn. It’s pretty satisfying to see my pawn gain knowledge of unknown quests, earn Rift Crystals (an important currency), and bring back whatever goodies they were sent with.
No Handholding: The game can often feel grueling in certain parts, even on Normal or Easy mode. Know that a simple tweak to one’s party or smarter usage of skills and positioning can fix this almost every time.
Sense of Adventure: I my opinion, this game has two major forms of gameplay, that being Preparation and Adventure. Preparation consists of stocking up on curatives, buying new equipment, upgrading existing equipment, and hiring skilled pawns. The adventure aspect comes from exploring new vistas and fighting unscripted enemies. You often need to improvise on the spot, which makes for some pretty cool scenarios.
Great PC Port: This port offers 60FPS and 4K resolution support which is something we rarely see from old console ports. The graphic settings are intuitive and keyboard binding is quick and easy. I’m also able to switch between keyboard and gamepad simply by using one or the other during gameplay. Even the button prompts immediately change! Furthermore, I’ve clocked in over 100 hours and I’ve only had two crashes (resulting in about 7 total minutes of lost progress).

CONS
Washed Out Detail: Although the game has a decent art direction and textures are a bit sharper than the console counterparts, the world’s soft and blurry greens and browns make it look very dated. It looks great when you look at the world as a whole, but a closer look reveals pretty ugly texture work.
Boring Story and Characters: The game starts off with your player character’s heart  getting eaten by a huge dragon. You end up surviving and are revealed to be the “Arisen”. From there, the story is filled in with bland characters and bizarre plot holes until the story decides to ramp up again near the end. The expansion, “Bitterblack Isle”, tells a more interesting narrative, but that’s not for a while.
Filler Quests: Unless you’re an insane completionist and want every unique weapon in the game, the billboard quests are best avoided. They usually consist of “kill X enemies that you’ve never encountered yet” or “Get X item that you’ve probably missed already”. Although the side quests are fairly serviceable, the frequent “task” quests usually make me dread talking to NPC’s with quest markers on their heads.
Unexplained Mechanics: I’m a fan of challenging games, but straight up not telling me important mechanics is a bit too obtuse. To name a few, there is a difference between clothing and armor, leveling up certain vocations add certain stat bonuses that cannot be reversed, and certain quests will become impossible when you progress certain main quests (better hope you don’t miss any if you’re a completionist!).

IN SUMMARY

Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen is a game for the patient RPG fan. The game has some pretty daunting issues, but it gets too much right to turn up. Give it a shot if you’re interested slashing up and burning a couple of goblins and cyclopes.

SIDENOTE

This port is most likely to see if the US has any interest in a Dragon’s Dogma type game. The current success will most likely mean that they will either localize Dragon’s Dogma Online (the Japanese MMO) or create a sequel.

reviewText:
Having played the PS3 and Xbox 360 versions a few years back, the improvements that have been made to this game are readily apparent. For example, they've found a way to address the lack of a fast travel system while also encouraging exploration of the world around you by adding many more Portcrystal locations to the game. This way, you can create more fast travel points as you progress through the game. They've also greatly improved the visual fidelity.

Now, on to the pros and cons.

Pros:
+open world with plenty to explore
+minor skirmishes are fun and engaging (even if it's with the same mobs)
+excellent party system
+incredibly flexible vocation (class) system to cover every play style
+challenging boss fights
+speedrun and hard modes for those interested
+real time combat
+extensive character creator

Cons:
-despite being presented well, the story isn't very strong
-no mounts, so Ferrystones will usually be the fastest but most limited form of transportation, as you can only warp to any location you've placed a Portcrystal
-pawns don't shut up, although this is more of a minor, personal gripe

All in all, I would definitely recommend this game for open-world RPG fans.

reviewText: I've played this game about two years ago, and all this time I've never seen a more unique and combat-packed RPG. The story holds a traditional, dragon-slaying medieval outlook mixed with magic and mixes it into something legendary. Sure, the storyline's short summary-wise, but with the amount of side-quests they added that can change it's outcome at every turn, it makes all the more enjoyable. The Dark Arisen expansion was a great touch and just made the game more interesting. Lock all of that with the new-game-plus and the online interactions, and you rarely get bored. I rate it a mind-blowing 11/10. Will never regret it taking up that one year of my life.

reviewText:
For those who have played and enjoyed this game on consoles:

It's absolutely worth the double dip. Dragon's Dogma always seemed like it felt at home on PC, and the narrow aspect ratio with poor framerate on consoles made it clear that this was a game with ambitions that exceeded what the PS360 were capable of fully realizing. This is an above average port, featuring a 150fps cap, a variety of resolutions, and the suite of settings that PC gamers expect. It's also very well optimized; my i3 3.1 Ghz with 4GB RAM and an R9 280 maintains 60 fps at a downsampled 1440p with all the bells and whistles enabled. I can't overstate how much of a gamechanger it is to enjoy the game without the black borders at a smooth 60 fps, with graphical enhancements that push the experience far beyond what the consoles were capable of.

Along with Red Dead Redemption, Dark Arisen was my dream PC port that I always hoped to see on the platform, and Capcom did not disappoint in delivering a version of Dark Arisen worthy of both the PC platform and the original vision of the game. The game also seems free of glitches and weird bugs at launch, with no crashes or other issues, and the ability to switch seamlessly between controller and the very playable KB&M controls at the press of a button. I've put over 100 hours into the PS3 version, and I can't wait to jump right back in. I can only hope that this version sees mods to expand the original vision, success to convince Capcom to work on a sequel, and the recognition that this diamond in the rough has always demanded.

For those who have never played Dragon's Dogma:

Dragon's Dogma is the quintessential flawed gem. To be honest, it falls short in some areas, but what it does right is nailed with such mastery that the game can be very hard to put down. It is an open-world RPG like Skyrim, but wandering in any direction you please is asking to be killed. Its relative difficulty and refusal to handhold is attractive to SoulsBorne fans, but Dragon's Dogma is much more transparent about how its systems work and the combat is more similar to a steroid-injected Monster Hunter.

Oh man, the combat. No matter what class you choose (or hybridize, or switch between), combat is visceral, tactical, and personally rivals only the Souls series in unique and excellently executed combat in an action RPG setting. It evokes Monster Hunter as much as it can evoke memories of playing Shadow of the Colossus as you climb up to the heads of absolutely giant enemies for the killing blow. Only it's possible to also summon an actual ♥♥♥♥ing tornado to take down said monster if you like.

I speak highly of the combat because it does carry much of the game. If you play RPGs to take part in an epic and fleshed out plot, and don't like completing sidequests just because you were asked to, it's very likely that the admittedly excellent combat won't be enough to keep such a player engaged. The plot starts strong, goes to the wayside for quite some time, and pays off after dozens of hours of exploration and dangerous dungeon crawling. Like the Souls series, this is an Eastern developer (the usual Devil May Cry team to be specific) working with very Western RPG conventions with a Japanese flair.

To avoid a wall of text, if you like games that are eager to challenge you without being cheap, wished that a game like Skyrim was more structured and had way better combat, or if you're a Souls fan willing to try a more conventional and open-world approach (while having some amazing dungeon layouts), you should definitely give this game a shot. Dark Arisen is a very well-laid foundation that can be very addictive, but it's dying for a sequel that expands on the design philosophies here and has more plot (or maybe not, this may be a deliberate design decision). I overall recommend, but advise caution for those who seek RPGs like Skyrim for its total freedom or Dragon Age for its fleshed out plot and player input in the story. Even then, maybe it's worth trying something new? I could never get into any Monster Hunter game, but the application of its combat mechanics in this RPG setting combined with its Shadow of the Colossus-ness makes me wonder if maybe I should give that series another shot. I guess I made a wall of text anyway, I'm off to put another 100 hours under my belt with the definitive and best version of a true RPG diamond in the rough.

reviewText:
I first encountered Dragon's Dogma in a Bro Team livestream of the console version, oddly enough. But what I saw of its character creation there was enough to deeply intrigue me, and the more I read about the game, the more intrigued I became. One hundred hours in I can say quite confidently that the hype was justified, and this is a truly great game.

First, the character creation. In some aspects it's not as flexible as, say, Skyrim, or Saints Row - in particular, faces are a much more daunting proposition to get right with this game compared to the former two. Fans celebrate its use of preset templates but I personally found that irritating and restricting. That said, Dragon's Dogma allows for a greater customization of body type than any game I have ever seen. Fat, thin, tall, short, muscular, lithe builds, all are in there. What's more, the body types have gameplay impact as well - taller, muscular frames are able to carry more items but are slower, and take longer to regenerate stamina, while small bodies recover more quickly and can fit through small holes, but can carry less weight.

Second, the combat. Comparisons to Dark Souls are rampant, but I only found it superficially similar. Overall, it is generally far less punishing than the Souls games. Timing of attacks is important, but mistakes are generally not as quickly fatal as they are in Dark Souls, and failure tends to be far less irritating, as the game allows you to simply reload where you left off and leaves out the soul-sucking regrind through respawned foes. The learning curve is overall much less steep.

Third, the boss fights. They are all very well done. There is not an incredible amount of variety - when you boil each boss fight down to its essence, there are, basically, about a half-dozen bosses total, and for the non-quest related open-world bosses you encounter, fighting them becomes routine fairly quickly. The plot-related boss fights, however, are generally quite well done, especially the final fight with the titular Dragon.

Fourth, is the companion or pawn" system. In my other life as a Skyrim modder
date: I made Follower Commentary Overhaul to try and spice up companions in Skyrim and give them a little more life by commenting on their surroundings
recommended: using recycled extant dialogue. Dragon's Dogma's pawn system is basically the platonic ideal dream mod I would have envisioned for Skyrim had I unlimited time
hoursPlayed: resources
voteText: and talent. Your main pawn can be customized just like your main character
helpfulPercent: for starters
votesHelpful: and beyond that just about anything is possible. You can designate them as healers
votesTotal: damage dealers
votesFunny: tanks
commentsCount: snipers

column17: on quests
column18: on how to deal with enemies
column19: or comment on nothing at all if you so choose. The best part
column20: though
column21: is that the game has a built-in system to share your pawns with all other players and enlist the help of their pawns in turn.\n\ntl;dr This game is absolutely outstanding on every metric I can measure an RPG on and worth every last cent."
