reviewText:
They're Masterworks all, you can't go wrong.

Alright. Now that I got the funny bits out of the way, lets get down to the meaty (And spoiler free) review:

There are a lot of fanboys/girls that give this game more credit than it deserves. There are also the few that absolutely hate this game's guts. I am here to stifle that and show no bias towards the game whatsoever.

To start things off, lets go with the good:

This game, as many have stated, has a lot in common with Dark Souls, Monster Hunter, Devil May Cry, and Shadow of the Collossus... but this is in gameplay only.

The combat you will dig yourself into for playing this game is equal parts skill, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ttery, tactics, and fun. It's combat system is extensive, one I have yet to be bored of. Nine classes (Vocations) are yours to choose from, and the game goes out of it's way to make sure you can't ♥♥♥♥ things up for yourself. No matter what you choose, when you change, how you play, you're going to have fun beating the everloving ♥♥♥♥ out of giant monsters. I have not even touched all nine classes yet and I'm looking forward to after maxing my character's level. For those that like grind and minmax... it has JUST the right amount of that in this game. Grinding isn't tedious thanks to how the end of the game works! Doubly so for it's expansion, Bitterback Isles. In between combat and managing your pawns, you'll barely notice the grind you're doing because you'll be focusing on how ♥♥♥♥ing awesome you are. TLDR; The combat has weight.

The equipment system is something I only wished Skyrim had. Mixing and matching parts (Or trying to match parts in my case) is fun and exciting, and you look forward to the next set of unlocks to buy as you work your way to the top. Equipment is only a fourth of your effectiveness in this game, however... though it pays to be well equipped. Equipment is handled in a fashion more realistically than some RPG's would normally do. The weight system shows you when too much is just too much, and unlike gaining the ability to carry more,  you realistically have a static limit on your weight. Gone are the days of carrying 600 lb's worth of equips because your character is well leveled. Instead, your weight limit is based on your character creation: The build, height, and weight all affect your most basic of stats in the game, and instead of the weight limit changing throughout the game, augments and class determine how much is very light, light, or heavy within that limit. Your armor weight doesn't disappear from simply wearing it, your healing items and special enhancement items have weight, so weight management is a must. Having party members to carry a lot of excess items is the best way to handle things. Armor is handled in such a way as to have multiple parts. Clothing to wear under armor, armor itself is all taken into account. For example, my main pawn has a very reasonable chain mail set under her normal armor to help with any weak points she may have! My main character, a strider, is wearing lightweight clothing underneath her leather armor to reduce weight and maintain mobility. This ties in to inventory and weight management. Sometimes there is too much you can carry, and not having proper mobility in a fight can be devastating, even for a tank or fighter.

The map is incredibly huge to say the least. It's up there with Skyrim... maybe even bigger than that if only slightly. There is plenty to explore, plenty to gather.

These are the great points of the game. Now onto the bad parts:

The exploration and backtracking can be tedious to some who don't like to smell the roses on the way to kick some ♥♥♥ and take some names. The quests are lackluster and aren't engaging to say the very least. There is no real fast travel mechanic until you can get your hands on some portcrystals. So there is no way to let your laziness shine in this game.

At first glance, there appears to be nearly no story. To those with low patience and a short attention span, this game will not catch their eye. This is no insult, of course... but in a gaming world dominated by people who fancy cutsenes, graphics, and incredible voice acting, this game is not attractive. One has to dig very deep into the lore to find the diamond burried under lumps of coal. While the story is deep and the philosophy of the game incredible, it's poorly executed by today's 'standards'.

Dialogue for pawns is incredibly repetitive... but the combat AI, once they have learned what to do in combat, is very well done. But the dialogue, man, if you can't stand it you need to turn it off in options, because it can drive you nuts.

It's graphics are not passable by todays high standards. But that's only because it was made a while back.

TLDR; The game could use more polish on the story execution and a comprehensive (Unrealistic) fast travel for the lazy western audience.

All in all, this is a game for those with patience. It is not perfect, but not trash either.
I would recommend this game to a lot of my friends, though it's up to you(the reader) whether or not to buy this title.

Personal rating (Bias): 9/10

Non-personal, objective rating (Unbiased): 7/10

reviewText:
I played this on X360 beforehand (like many other reviewers) and put roughly 20 hours in to that version. I stopped playing it because *minor and kinda pointless spoiler* I couldn't save Fournival (just a side quest dude) and I wanted that gold idol.
Any who, back to my point, it released on PC which is an unexpected dream come true because there's no problems with loading times and the resolution is so much more clear and crisp. I've spent a lot more hours on this version so far and plan to spend even more.

To those who haven't played or heard of Dragon's Dogma before, if I had to explain its gameplay I would probably say it's an arcadey version of Dark Souls and Dragon Age with a more open world and has the monster climbing mechanics from Shadow of the Colossus, however it's difficult to compare or relate because this game is just so unique. It's how a good JRPG should be. The looting system is great and weapon and gear progression works well (although it's fairly easy to go to an area above your level and find overpowered loot).

The only thing I can recommend is watching gameplay as explaining it probably won't do any good.

This is one of my favourite games of last generation, I personally rate it a 9/10. Highly recommend for RPG fans!

reviewText:
In brief, this game is a gem in its generation of games because it does so well what so many games fail to do.

PROS:

Addictive Character Progression: There are 9 classes you can switch to any point in the game. You can mix and match some of the core abilities and augments you learn so you can build a character specific to your liking.

Character Aesthetics: There is enough unique equipment in the game to give you multiple chances to try out and find something that fits your aesthetics or build. I would argue that the only issue i had in this game was there wasnt enough ♥♥♥♥♥y armor for my girl lol.

Beautiful  Environment and Ambiance: the music and sound effects of some of the larger fights really bring you into the game as you become engaged with the visuals.

Unique equipment: A nice visual touch coming from the Dark Souls series is how each equipment looks unique and allows you to mix and match to find that outfit you're going for. One minor differnce between this and dark souls is that if there is an armor set in this game, its just 1 equipment item as the whole set. Whereas every individual equipment you pick up is unique in its own set giving a much more unique feel to the game instead of looting the whole 'white mage' set in a single go.

Equipment progression: In case you do find armor and weapons you would want to keep for a while, the game allows for simple weapon progression by the process of purchasing upgrades with money and materials. If you enjoy killing everything, you should have no problem finding the necessary parts.

Everything drops something you may want: Some games you kill something and it'll drop like 10 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ items you will never want to pick up and only pick up that upgraded weapon that barely surpasses your own. In this game, you often look at every item because whether its a material (junk) that you need to posses for upgrades, or herbs / potion you will find yourself needing that in the future. I find that almost all the time im picking up whatever I can unless i have an abundance of it.

Customizing your party: At any time you want to completely change you, and your pawn's classes and the ones whoa re recruited in your party you can do that by changing their vocations. This makes it a little bit more fun as you can just switch the style you play at any point in the game.

Playing with friends: While you cannot actually have a true online experience with other players in the game. You can still share your pawn with them, and they can in turn, tell you about how disasterously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your pawn was in their game. Thumbs up.

While there are a TON of things i would continue to boast about the game, I also want to insert some of the critiques and short comings of the game.

CONS:

Character Weight and Inventory Management: This part of the game is a bit painful. Characters all have their own weights they manage through equiped and inventory items belonging to that character. However if you want to continue a low level of weight, you often have to visit your inventory to move all Materials or other items onto another character and theres no quick way to do that. The AI of your party will also pick up items and thats a blessing, but they wont scour the room and pick up everything like you would.

Story Dialog: while the short quests make sense and your interaction with NPCs seem all fine. A lot of the cut scenes with your character make you think your character is either autistic or mute. Normally this would be totally fine as this whole game has a Dark Souls feel to it, and nobody says ♥♥♥♥ in that game lol.

All in all, I played this in 2012 and again and I didnt think I would enjoy it again as much as i did before. Even more with the DA expansion.

reviewText: I got this game on the ps3 many years back and by god playing this game on the pc is a dream come true. reviewText:
I remember seeing a video of Dragon's Dogma for PS3 back in 2013 and thinking 'damn it, why isn't this on PC?' - 3 years later, I got my wish as DD: Dark Arisen has finally been released on Steam/Windows.  While this could have been a case of 'too little, too late' - as is often the case with years-late PC ports - it is my pleasure to say that this is an extremely competent release, with a wealth of graphic options and extremely well thought-out controls.  And more importantly, DD:DA is a really fun and original RPG that brings a lot to the dance.

Right away I noticed that DD has a very fluid, weighty combat system with a number of vocations (specializations/classes) and abilities for both primary and secondary weapons - it adds up to some of the most enjoyable battles I've seen in an RPG, in fact.  And you'll have plenty of chances to enjoy it, as basic enemies are plentiful and often a very real threat - as I learned when a pack of regular wolves tore my mage/healer pawn to bits and then mauled me as I tried to help him.

DD:DA also has some of the most insane boss fights that I've seen - for example, scarcely 3 hours into the game my character is taking a nap, only to be awoken by the commotion of a dinosaur-sized Hydra attacking the town she was in.  I watched helplessly as it swallowed one of my pawns, killed several guards and in general wrecked the place.  It wasn't until I blew off one of the Hydra's cow-sized heads with a barrel of explosive powder that the beast relented.  I actually said Wow..." out-loud as I watched this unfold.

That brings me to one of the key selling points of DD:DA
date: pawns - the legion of companions you'll have at your disposal.  To my surprise they are incredibly well-done
recommended: using abilities and strategies to a degree that would rival human players
hoursPlayed: and I actually enjoy the constant stream of banter and comments that they make.  Yes
voteText: it absolutely gets monotonous at times ("This road is shared by guards and fishermen!") but ironically
helpfulPercent: it makes them feel less like pawns and more like actual characters.  I also love that you get to create a permanent pawn with the same degree of detail and finetuning as your own character... that was a very cool touch
votesHelpful: IMO.  I've said for years that I'd like a game which allows you to create your own companions
votesTotal: so it was surprising that DD:DA granted that wish.\n\nSo what's wrong with the game
votesFunny: you ask?  Almost 13 hours in
commentsCount: and my only real complaint is that the player character doesn't speak.  Games like Dragon Age
column16: Mass Effect and more recently Fallout 4 have cemented my preference for a speaking player character
column17: so I was a tad disappointed with DD in that regard.\n\nOh
column18: and one of my pawns got stuck on a tree for a few seconds - but she quickly found her way to me.  And in the game's defense
column19: I was taking an extremely unorthodox path to reach my destination.\n\nI could write much
column20: much more about the game
column21: but the short of it is this: DD:DA is absolutely worth your money if you're a fan of RPGs.  It is both an excellent game and a great example of how to do a PC port
column22: and it is a refreshingly original take on the genre in an age of sequels and playing it safe.\n\nHere's hoping for DD2!"

reviewText:
This game may no achieve perfection but it is certainly worth every penny.
Fun open world with lots to explore, great fights against big enemies and small hordes and overall decent mechanics that do not hinder the player, even if they sometimes seem a little unpractical.

Having tons of fun with this one and it holds great potential for multiple playthroughs.
